Yuhei Takashima, a former Japanese school principal, has been arrested and charged with paying for sex with over 12,000 women, including some underage girls, in the Philippines. The alleged incidents occurred over a quarter of a century, starting in 1988, and involved paying for sex with women ranging in age from 13 to 70. Police officers seized 147,600 photos taken by Takashima, which included explicit images of the sex acts. Takashima faces criminal charges after being arrested in Manila in January 2014. The Philippines is known for its sex tourism industry, which is linked to human trafficking and poverty.

Gareth Bale's name appears on the back of a new Chelsea kit, which was allegedly sold through a Brazilian online retailer. The kit features the sponsor "Yokohama" across the front, but no Adidas logo. Three other Chelsea kits were released, each featuring the team's current sponsor. However, some fans may prefer to buy the kit without Gareth Bale's name on the back due to his recent struggles at Real Madrid. Meanwhile, Didier Drogba's Chelsea jersey is available for purchase, although his future remains uncertain.

Clarence Taylor, 44, faked his own kidnapping by duct-taping his mouth and tying himself to a tree in Akron, Ohio, claiming it was a prank gone wrong. His 45-year-old girlfriend reported him missing on November 1, and police later discovered he was still bound to the tree. The incident involved a group of men who allegedly stole $2,500 from him before abducting him and taking him away in a van. Taylor claims he was left tied to the tree for several days without showing signs of injury or dehydration. Police have charged Taylor with a first-degree misdemeanor charge of falsification due to the circumstances surrounding the incident.

A satirical new video from the Make it Fair Project promotes gender equality in Hollywood, featuring actresses highlighting the disparity between men and women in various industries, including film, politics, and business. The video, starring Rita Wilson, features a tongue-in-cheek performance that pokes fun at the idea that "men should have it all." The actresses claim that men hold 70-95% of key positions in these fields, and that women earn significantly less pay, with some groups making up 60% of college graduates but earning only 30% more than men. The video aims to raise awareness about the issue of gender inequality and encourage viewers to support initiatives working towards greater equality.

Researchers suggest that warmer climates around 1.4 million years ago enabled the spread of early human ancestors into Western Europe, specifically Spain, due to changes in temperature and humidity. These changes allowed them to adapt to their environment and eventually occupy the region. The discovery of ancient tools, such as those found at the Barranco León site, supports this theory. Climate change played a significant role in shaping the migration patterns of these early humans, while other factors like geography and culture also contributed to their expansion.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL running back, is suspected of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward, a 37-year-old inmate serving a life sentence for first-degree murder in Central California prison. Phillips, who was previously convicted of choking his girlfriend and driving into three teenagers, is believed to have killed Soward while sharing a cell. The incident occurred at Kern Valley State Prison, where Phillips is serving a 31-year sentence for another crime. Phillips' attorneys have not commented on the allegations. A second inmate, John Munoz, is also suspected of killing Soward, according to prison officials.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers' FA Cup semi-final defeat to Aston Villa has sparked concerns about the team's chances of achieving their ambitious goal of becoming Champions League regulars. Despite having a talented squad, Rodgers' inability to find consistency and form has raised questions about whether he can lead the team to success. The defeat has also highlighted the need for changes, particularly in the transfer department, where several players have struggled to impress. Rodgers has vowed to learn from his mistakes and improve, but it remains to be seen whether he can turn things around. With the pressure mounting, Rodgers must address the team's lack of depth and find ways to motivate his players to perform better.

Google Maps combines with Pac-Man game, allowing users to play a virtual version of the classic arcade game in real-time using their location. Users can simply pull up Google Maps on their computer or mobile device and click on the Pac-Man icon to transform the map into a Pac-Man course. This prank, part of Google's April Fools' Day tradition, has taken over social media platforms, with users sharing photos and videos of themselves playing the game in various locations around the world. The prank has become so popular that it's even inspired a new "Pokemon Challenge" where players must navigate through streets and landmarks like Times Square and Central Park.

Rangers manager Stuart McCall has reassured fans that the decision to remove the club from the AIM stock exchange will not affect his team's promotion push. The club was previously de-listed due to chairman-in-waiting Dave King failing to secure a new nominated advisor, but interim chairman Paul Murray attributed the decision to the previous board. McCall has stated that he doesn't expect the situation to impact his team's chances of promotion, despite the potential financial implications. Rangers welcomed newly-crowned Scottish Championship winners Hearts to Ibrox on Sunday, where they will give the league leaders a guard of honour. McCall expressed pride in the team's performance, particularly after winning the championship, and hopes that the season can still be successful despite the setback.

A US-based company, Vox Populi, is using the ".sucks" domain name to target celebrities and companies for extortion, charging them $2,499 per year to register the domain. The company claims this is necessary to "create destinations for companies to interact with their critics". However, experts say this is a coercive scheme, as the threat of opening a ".sucks" site to the average consumer is a significant deterrent. Vox Populi has already begun selling purchased domain names, including those of celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift, at prices ranging from $2,000 to $10 per year. The company's actions have sparked concerns about the potential abuse of the ".sucks" domain name system.

Manchester United have been linked with signing Edinson Cavani despite his disappointing 2-0 loss to Barcelona in the Champions League. Cavani's performance was described as "sterile" and he failed to impress, while Radamel Falcao's loan spell at Manchester United has left the club wary of signing him due to his struggles. Cavani's domestic form has also been underwhelming, scoring just 11 goals in 32 appearances in Ligue 1. Despite this, Cavani remains committed to seeing out his current contract and has expressed his desire to stay at Paris Saint-Germain. Barcelona's Luis Enrique may be looking to sign Cavani, but United will keep a close eye on the situation.

Leicester City appear to be safe from relegation with a predicted total of 26 points, thanks to their strong home record and favorable fixtures. Sunderland, meanwhile, are just 7 points behind, while Burnley, Everton, Aston Villa, and Steve Bruce's Hull are all struggling to avoid the drop. Arsenal, however, have a relatively easy run-in, with five home games left and a goal difference of +4, making them a potential candidate for safety. QPR, on the other hand, have a tough run-in, with seven games left and a goal difference of -11, making them likely to be relegated.

Karim Benzema, a Real Madrid forward, showcased his vocal talents by rapping along to Tupac's "All Eyez on Me" while driving his Bugatti Veyron. He also sang along to Tupac's "Check Out Time" during a recent match with Granada. Benzema aims to continue performing well for both Real Madrid and the French national team to potentially win the Ballon d'Or award. With 20 goals in all competitions this season, Benzema believes he can compete for the top honor. His teammates, including Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi, may be able to surpass him in the standings.

Pope Francis, 78, has been advised by doctors to cut down on his pasta intake due to concerns over his considerable weight gain since taking office. The Vatican has also warned him to reduce his daily walk routine, citing his sedentary lifestyle and potential exacerbation of his sciatica. Doctors have told the Pope that his weight gain may worsen his sciatica, particularly when combined with his busy travel schedule. Despite this, Pope Francis has responded by jokingly referring to himself as "the undisciplined one" and continuing to indulge in a daily bowl of pasta.

Google has released an update to its Android software allowing owners to unlock their phone with their voice, known as "trusted voice", which uses the device's front-facing camera to recognize the user's face. This feature is available on certain Android phones running Android 4.4 KitKat or later, and allows users to simply say "OK, Google" to unlock their device. The feature is considered secure, but not as secure as traditional locks, and requires a small margin of error to ensure correct identification. Users must also set up a screen lock pattern or PIN in addition to enabling the feature to protect against unauthorized access.

A lawyer for Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve deputy, has released documents that claim to verify some of Bates' training as a law enforcement officer. The documents show Bates attended multiple training classes, including a Taser training class and three firearms training sessions, and scored high on his pistol range tests. However, the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office has disputed these claims, citing a lack of evidence supporting the accuracy of the documents. The lawyer argues that Bates should not have been sworn in as a reserve deputy due to his questionable training record.

A headteacher at Sherborne Preparatory School in Dorset claims that parents have become "dervishes" focused solely on their children's education, putting their needs above those of the school and its staff. This trend stems from parents bombarding schools with information and demands for special treatment, rather than trusting the institutions to provide a balanced approach. The situation has led to an increase in abuse towards teachers, with many experiencing verbal and physical harassment online. Parents are urged to trust the school and its staff, allowing them to focus on teaching and nurturing their children's education. The issue highlights the growing divide between parents and educators, with some parents feeling entitled to intervene on behalf of their children.

Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized a deal struck by six world powers to limit Iran's nuclear ambitions, calling it a "bad deal" that would allow Iran to continue developing its nuclear program. The deal, which includes limits on Iran's enrichment and inspections, was endorsed by President Barack Obama but opposed by many Republicans, who argue it gives Iran too much flexibility. Netanyahu argued that the deal would not effectively prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons, citing concerns about Iran's history of cheating. The US Energy Secretary said the deal would extend the breakout time period for Iran to develop a nuclear bomb and allow for faster detection of attempts to evade the deal.

Catalans Dragons winger Vincent Duport has been ruled out for the rest of the season due to a shoulder injury sustained during their 33-22 loss to Hull FC. He underwent surgery as a result of the injury, which required his removal of a ruptured tendon. This setback comes just weeks after he returned from a previous injury. The loss drops Catalans to sixth place in the Super League table. The team's next match is against Wigan on Sunday.

A 36-year-old Indiana woman, Samantha Fleming, went missing with her 3-month-old newborn daughter Serenity in April. Police discovered her body in a home in Gary, Indiana, 180 miles away, where a woman claiming to be from Child Protective Services told her she needed to attend a court hearing. The woman allegedly took the baby to a nursery and had planned to care for it, but the baby was later found dead and taken into custody. The woman, who is now identified as a person of interest, was reportedly familiar with Fleming and had been texting her regularly leading up to her disappearance.

A team of scientists believe that a site in West Java, Indonesia, may hold the key to understanding one of the world's oldest pyramids, potentially rewriting prehistory and shedding new light on an obscure yet powerful ancient civilization. The site, Gunung Padang, is believed to be an ancient temple built between 9,000 and 20,000 years ago, possibly for worship or astronomy. This discovery could challenge current theories about the origins of human civilization and provide evidence of an advanced ancient culture. The site features terraces and retaining walls, suggesting a sophisticated construction method, and has been dated to be around 7,000 years old.

A 29-year-old man was stabbed by a 27-year-old man outside a Melbourne nightclub on Easter long weekend, sparking shock and disgust among police who described the incident as "disgusting". The attack occurred just hours after the man had been ejected from the club, and was caught on CCTV footage. A second security guard was also stabbed in a separate incident earlier in the day. The victims were treated for minor injuries and are receiving medical attention. The incidents highlight concerns about violence and safety in Melbourne's nightlife.

Carlisle United manager Keith Curle criticized his team's performance after a 3-1 loss at Accrington Stanley, calling some players "players who don't deserve to be professionals" due to their lack of effort. The Cumbrians are struggling in League Two, having lost five games in their last five matches and currently sit in the relegation zone. Curle expressed frustration with the team's morale, stating that the "strength of character in that changing room is alarmingly weak". A potential open forum for fans to discuss their concerns will be held by Curle, with the club chairman Andrew Jenkins expected to attend.

Victoria's Secret's new campaign features Candice Swanepoel, Elsa Hosk, and Jasmine Tookes showcasing their Dream Angels lingerie range, which includes white bras, push-up bras, and lace-trimmed tops. The campaign aims to promote the brand's new collection, described as "romantic" and "flirty". Candice Swanepoel, a 26-year-old model, shares her journey of overcoming shyness to work with the brand, while Elsa Hosk and Jasmine Tookes, 24 and 24 years old respectively, showcase the brand's new lingerie line. The campaign also highlights the importance of self-expression and individuality, with each model embracing their unique style.

A Ukrainian woman named Kristina Karo is suing Hollywood actress Mila Kunis for $5,000, claiming that she stole her pet chicken, "Doggie", 25 years ago while they were classmates in Ukraine. Karo alleges that Kunis confessed to the theft and offered her another chicken as payment. The incident occurred when Karo was just seven years old, and it allegedly traumatized her, forcing her to seek therapy. Karo claims that moving to Los Angeles, where she currently resides, has brought back painful memories of the incident.

Richard Howarth, a 35-year-old medical recruitment consultant, claims he has developed an allergy to Nigel Farage after repeatedly seeing him on TV, causing him to break out in a sweat and become anxious. His reactions are so severe that he must switch the channel or risk becoming physically ill. A psychologist attributes his symptoms to a phobia, stating that people can develop irrational fears based on perceived threats, even if there is no actual danger. Dr. Rick Norris agrees, suggesting that people may react to politicians or individuals with opposing views due to deep-seated emotional responses.

Rahul Kumar, a 17-year-old boy, jumped into a lions' enclosure at a zoo in Ahmedabad, thinking he'd have an advantage against the predators. He shouted "Today I kill a lion!" as he ran towards the animals, despite being intoxicated. Zoo security staff caught up with him and rescued him from the moat surrounding the enclosure. The incident highlights the dangers of intoxication and the importance of animal safety measures.

A traditional Easter egg typically contains around 7 teaspoons of sugar, which exceeds the recommended daily intake of 50g. Consuming such a large amount of sugar can lead to insulin resistance, a precursor to type 2 diabetes, and contribute to various health issues. Excessive sugar consumption during the Easter period can also cause tooth decay, nutrient deficiencies, and behavioral problems. Experts warn that eating too much sugar can lead to obesity, weight gain, and other negative health consequences. Regularly consuming sweets, especially those with added sugar, can negatively impact overall health.

The Havasupai tribe, a small Indian nation in Arizona, USA, lives in the remote village of Supai, nestled at the bottom of Havasu Canyon in the Grand Canyon National Park. With a population of around 600 people, the tribe relies heavily on tourism to support their way of life, which includes growing food and weaving. The village is accessible only by foot or helicopter, offering breathtaking views of the canyon below. The tribe's ancient traditions and customs are deeply rooted in the land, which they consider sacred.

A new malaria vaccine called RTS,S has been developed after 30 years of research, with the goal of preventing millions of cases worldwide. The vaccine, which has completed final-stage testing, has shown promising results, reducing the number of clinical cases of malaria among 15,500 toddlers and babies in sub-Saharan Africa by 36% after four years. Despite some decline in effectiveness over time, the vaccine is expected to provide substantial protection against the disease, with 1,363 cases prevented for every 1,000 children vaccinated. The vaccine is the first licensed malaria vaccine and could be approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) by October, making it a major breakthrough in the fight against the deadliest disease globally.

Chilean pickpockets have become the most effective thieves operating in central London, with undercover police teams identifying them as intelligent and organized groups that target wealthy tourists. These gangs, typically consisting of up to six members, use plain clothes and fake personas to blend in with locals, making it difficult to detect them. The Metropolitan Police have reported a significant increase in pickpocket crimes in London's busy shopping areas, particularly in areas such as Oxford Street, while also spotting two Chilean women wearing burkas being stopped by police after being targeted by these gangs. The police believe that these gangs are becoming increasingly sophisticated, with some members spending only brief periods in London before moving to other European cities to evade detection.

A new, sleeker version of the traditional electricity pylon has been unveiled in the UK, marking the country's first new pylon in nearly 90 years. This innovative design features a lower profile and reduced weight, making it a more efficient and environmentally friendly alternative to the traditional lattice pylon. The new T-pylon is part of a larger effort to reduce the number of pylons on the grid, with National Grid planning to use both new and existing lattice pylons in the future. The UK's first new pylon, built at the Eakring training academy in Nottinghamshire, is expected to be operational within the next few months.

Holly Nicole Solomon, a 31-year-old woman from Arizona, pleaded guilty to aggravated assault after hitting her husband Daniel with their SUV in a parking lot dispute over his decision not to vote in the 2012 presidential election. Solomon claimed she wanted to scare her husband, but accidentally drove the vehicle into him, causing serious injuries. Her husband Daniel Solomon was rushed to the hospital with severe injuries, including a shattered pelvis and a torn artery, and is currently in critical condition. Solomon faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted of aggravated assault. She pleaded guilty to the crime as part of a plea deal.

Student Drew Hollinshead, 21, stopped his car to help an elderly woman who collapsed on the pavement while he was parked in a disabled bay. A traffic warden issued him a £70 parking ticket despite seeing him assist the woman for just 30-45 seconds. Hollinshead initially tore up the ticket and threw it away but later retrieved it, saying "it's not the cost, it's the principle". He has since taken to social media to express his frustration, stating that the council does not care if the fine is paid or not.

A group of workers in China are constructing a rickety wooden walkway thousands of feet above the ground in Pingjiang County, Hunan province, using makeshift scaffolding poles and hard hats to support them. The walkway is part of an effort to extend a mountain road, with officials hoping to attract tourists to the area. Despite the risks, the workers are expected to haul heavy loads and work in hazardous conditions, with little safety equipment available. The construction process is precarious, with the walkway appearing flimsy and unstable, and officials have installed safety measures such as ropes and hard hats to mitigate the risks.

Two NHS trusts, Pennine Acute Hospitals NHS Trust and Royal Oldham, have conducted an internal investigation into the deaths of seven babies and three mothers at their respective hospitals over a period of eight months. An independent review found notable failures in clinical leadership, risk management, and patient care, particularly among obese mothers who may be more susceptible to complications. The investigation revealed inadequate planning and execution of care, including pushing babies back into the womb and failing to follow national guidelines for treating overweight women. The reports highlighted concerns about the safety of maternity services at both hospitals, with ten deaths occurring within a short time frame.

A new governing board has been elected to Ferguson, Missouri, replacing the previous 6-member City Council. Two African-American candidates, Ella Jones and Wesley Bell, won their respective seats, becoming the first black women and black men to serve on the council. The election was marked by high voter turnout, with over 20,000 people casting their ballots, and sparked renewed calls for change in Ferguson after the death of Michael Brown, who was shot by a white police officer in August. The new council members vowed to prioritize community policing and address issues of racism and inequality.

Australian cricketer Aaron Finch underwent surgery on his left hamstring after suffering a high-grade injury during the Indian Premier League. He had previously undergone scans that confirmed the severity of the injury, which required surgical intervention. Finch will miss up to three months of action due to the procedure. The 28-year-old batsman was initially expected to return to full fitness within 12 weeks but will instead undergo extensive rehabilitation. Finch was part of Australia's World Cup-winning team last year and was not included in the country's upcoming international schedule.

Here is a summary of the article:

AP McCoy won the Melling Chase at Aintree, riding Don Cossack, after Irishman Gordon Elliott chose to ride Cause of Causes instead of shutting the mount. McCoy celebrated his second win of the meeting, having previously won on Don Cossack. Elliott praised his decision, saying they made the right choice despite having another option available. The win marked Elliott's third victory at Aintree and his fourth overall.

Vince Cable, a closet Labour politician who previously served as a councillor, has announced his intention to join the Conservative Party and work alongside David Cameron as Business Secretary. He claims to have "stomached" working with the Tories despite previous clashes with them, citing his ability to "be business-like". Cable wants to replace George Osborne as Chancellor and has expressed admiration for Cameron and Osborne's intelligence, but also criticizes their handling of the financial crisis and proposes a different approach to economic policy. He has vowed to remain loyal to the Liberal Democrats, despite speculation about his potential departure.

A survey of 2000 British workers found that the average worker attends 6,239 meetings throughout their careers, with 70% finding most meetings "pretty pointless" and 50% admitting to zoning out during meetings. Many workers also confess to snoozing, doodling, or staring out the window during meetings, with 45% feeling that their company wastes money on unnecessary travel expenses. A significant proportion of workers believe that offsite meetings are not necessary, with 55% thinking they are "pretty pointless". The survey highlights the challenges of managing meetings, particularly when team members sneakily arrange offsite meetings to avoid attending.

A math problem was created for 14-year-olds called "So when is Cheryl's birthday?" where Cheryl gives Albert and Bernard a list of 10 possible dates for her birthday. Albert and Bernard try to figure out the correct date together, using a series of deductions based on the clues provided by Cheryl. They eventually determine that Cheryl's birthday must be July 16 due to the unique combination of single dates in each month. By working through the clues, they eliminate options and arrive at the correct answer.

A federal prosecutor is presenting evidence against an Army major and his wife, John and Carolyn Jackson, who allegedly abused their three young foster children over several years, leaving them with physical injuries and health problems. The couple's first child abuse trial ended in a mistrial due to a court ruling that prevented discussing the death of one of their sons. The Jacksons have three biological children and three adopted children, and the prosecution will present evidence that they subjected their foster children to physical abuse, including withholding food and water, hitting them with objects, and forcing them to drink hot sauce or eat hot pepper flakes. The couple has denied any wrongdoing, but the prosecution argues that their actions rose to the level of criminal behavior. The trial is ongoing, with the third child expected to testify.

Real Madrid is set to be without Karim Benzema due to a knee injury, which could impact their Champions League quarter-final second leg against Atletico Madrid. The French striker was injured during a 3-1 loss to Malaga earlier in the competition. Madrid boss Carlo Ancelotti has hinted that Benzema may return for the match, despite initial doubts about his availability. Meanwhile, Atletico Madrid face a tough test against Real Madrid, who are looking to bounce back from a 3-1 defeat in their own Champions League quarter-final second leg.

Thieves targeting 294 security vaults across Europe, including in Berlin and London, have been linked to a similar audacious burglary in 2013. The Hatton Garden raid in London, which netted £60 million, bears striking similarities to the Berlin heist, which saw thieves target 71 safety deposit boxes and valuables worth £8.3 million. Both heists involved tunneling, drilling, and disguising themselves as construction workers to gain access to the vaults. The investigation suggests that the thieves may have spent weeks digging tunnels and renting a lock-up garage to facilitate their crimes.

A young girl's heart-wrenching reaction to seeing her father watch The Lion King for the first time has been captured on camera, with her visibly distraught as she witnesses the tragic scene of Mufasa's murder by Scar. The video, shot by her father Barles Charkley, shows the toddler's distress as she tries to process the loss of her father. The scene is widely regarded as one of Disney's most haunting spectacles, and has already garnered millions of views online. The video has sparked a wave of comments and reactions from fans and well-wishers alike.

A couple in their 40s were denied a £250,000 mortgage application by HSBC due to the bank's age policy, which deemed the husband too old to qualify for an interest-only loan. The Financial Ombudsman Service ruled that HSBC was unfair in its decision, finding that the bank relied on untested assumptions about age rather than individual circumstances. The couple, who did not want to be named, claim they were victims of age discrimination. The ombudsman ordered HSBC to pay £500 in compensation for distress and inconvenience caused.

A Texas veterinarian, Kristen Lindsey, was fired from her job after posting a photo of herself holding an arrow through the neck of a cat on Facebook, claiming it was a "good feral tomcat". The cat, which was actually the pet of an elderly couple, was shot by Lindsey while she was working at the Washington Animal Clinic. Lindsey could face charges of animal cruelty and vandalism, and has since removed her social media accounts. An investigation is underway, and animal rights activists have offered a $7,500 reward for evidence leading to her conviction.

A pioneering facial surgeon, Professor Ninian Peckitt, has been accused of repeatedly punching a patient in the face during a closed reduction procedure to correct a fracture caused by an industrial accident. The patient, known as Patient A, allegedly suffered extensive injuries to the right side of their face, and Professor Peckitt claimed he "digitally manipulated" the patient's face to achieve the desired correction. However, witnesses testified that the actual action was more violent, with Professor Peckitt allegedly punching the patient multiple times. The incident occurred while he worked as an honorary locum consultant at Ipswich Hospital in February 2012. The Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service is set to determine whether Professor Peckitt should be struck off the medical register due to these allegations.

Actor Ben Powers, best known for his role as Thelma's husband Keith on the long-running sitcom Good Times, has died at the age of 64 after passing away at his home in New Bedford, Massachusetts. He was a talented artist before becoming an actor, studying painting and sketching at the Rhode Island School of Design. Powers also had notable roles on other TV shows such as Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer and Gimme a Break. His death comes just weeks after the final episode of Good Times aired, where Thelma marries her new husband Keith.

Derby drew 1-1 with Brentford in a thrilling match at the iPro Stadium. Alex Pritchard scored a stunning strike in the 21st minute to put Derby ahead, only for Brentford to equalize in stoppage time via Darren Bent's late goal. The Bees dominated the game, with Pritchard scoring again in the 92nd minute to send the match into extra time. Despite struggling to create clear-cut chances, Derby ultimately held on for a 1-1 draw. Darren Bent celebrated his 10th goal of the season with the winning goal.

A gang of armed robbers used pink umbrellas to disguise themselves during a two-month crime spree, stealing £145,000 from 13 shops in the West Midlands. The gang targeted supermarkets, convenience stores, and electrical shops, and used hammers, knives, and screwdrivers to threaten shop workers. Four members of the gang - Marcus Morgan, Ashleigh Evans, Liam Bell, and Trea Richardson - were arrested and jailed for over 27 years for their roles in the robberies. The gang's leader, Morgan, was sentenced to 7 years, while Evans was sentenced to 10 years, and Bell was sentenced to 6 years and 6 months.

Italian Alex Bellini, a 36-year-old explorer, plans to spend a year living inside a ball-shaped capsule on top of an iceberg in Greenland, highlighting the effects of melting icebergs due to global warming. The capsule, designed to withstand extreme conditions, will allow him to observe the melting process up close. Bellini aims to raise awareness about climate change through his project, "Adrift," which seeks funding to support his daring endeavor. The capsule's unique design includes features like roller-ball-mounted instruments and sensors to detect seismic activity, ensuring his safety during the potentially hazardous journey.

A photograph circulated on social media site SnapChat appears to show disgraced Geelong College principal Andrew Barr watching pornography in his office, despite an investigation finding no evidence of wrongdoing. The photograph shows Barr surfing for explicit content while on-duty, sparking outrage among students and staff. The incident led to his resignation, with the school council announcing its intention to begin searching for a replacement. The scandal has raised questions about the school's handling of the situation and whether it breached its own policies.

Francis Pusok, a 30-year-old man, was beaten by police on horseback after fleeing his home in San Bernardino County, California, on Thursday. The incident occurred just a day after he was arrested on identity theft charges. Pusok was subjected to a brutal beating by several deputies, including a sergeant and a detective, who allegedly used excessive force, including tasering and hitting him repeatedly. Pusok's girlfriend, Jolene Bindner, reported that the deputies threatened him with violence and called him a threat, sparking concerns about retaliation against her and their unborn child.

Mohammed Emwazi, also known as "Jihadi John", a former British ISIS recruiter, met with Hizb ut-Tahrir while studying at Westminster University. He later became embroiled in conflicts with the group, including attacking activists in Syria. Emwazi was linked to several individuals connected to ISIS, including a would-be MP, Maajid Nawaz, who was jailed for his role in radical Islamist groups. Nawaz attempted to touch a naked stripper at a London nightclub, sparking outrage.

A new tropical fruit called the 'Bouea macrophylla' or'mango plum' is being stocked by Marks & Spencer in the UK. This unique fruit combines characteristics of both a mango and a plum, with a bright orange edible skin and a sweet taste similar to an Alphonso mango. The fruit is smaller than a mango and has a softer texture, making it easy to eat. Marks & Spencer is one of several retailers stocking the fruit, which is also known as the 'plango'.

In South Africa, a protest is taking place at the University of Cape Town over the removal of a statue of British colonialist Cecil Rhodes, a figure widely regarded as racist and responsible for apartheid. The statue, a bronze representation of Rhodes, was removed due to concerns that it made black students feel uncomfortable and sparked protests among white Afrikaner solidarity groups. The decision comes after months of protests and vandalism targeting similar monuments across the country. The statue is expected to be taken to a museum, but its future remains uncertain.

Hannah Bluck, 18, a talented young footballer from Wales, has had her promising career cut short due to a rare condition called avascular necrosis, where her leg bone died due to a fracture and subsequent collapse. The condition, which affects the bone marrow, has left her unable to kick a ball again. Hannah, who plays for the Wales youth national teams, was diagnosed with the condition in 2013 and underwent treatment, but unfortunately, it did not work, ruling her out of the sport for two years. Now, she is undergoing further analysis of her MRI scan to determine the extent of the damage.

Edinson Cavani, Paris Saint-Germain forward, has denied rumors suggesting a rift between him and teammate Zlatan Ibrahimovic, insisting there is no issue beyond being played out of position. Despite reports of tension, Cavani claims to have a respectful relationship with Ibrahimovic, who has admitted to being frustrated with being shoehorned into a front three. Cavani has expressed frustration at being relegated to playing in a different position than his preferred role, but has reassured fans that everything else is going well. The two players were involved in a heated exchange with Marseille midfielder Mario Lemina during a recent match. Cavani has hinted at a possible departure from Paris Saint-Germain, but remains committed to honoring his contract until the end of the season.

The England U-17 team, led by coach John Peacock, has been named for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship. The squad includes several talented young players from Premier League clubs such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Arsenal's Chris Willock. The team faces off against Italy, Holland, and Ireland in Group D, while also competing in the penalty shootout format. The tournament begins on May 7, with England opening against Italy in Burgas. The team has a strong lineup, featuring many players who have previously competed at the elite level.

Fireball Cinnamon Whisky, a Canadian-made liquor, has experienced rapid growth since its introduction in 2006, becoming the sixth-most popular liquor brand in the US, with sales doubling and tripled in recent years. Known for its unique flavor profile, Fireball gained widespread attention due to its use of cinnamon and sweetener, particularly among young drinkers and women. Despite controversy surrounding its ingredient, Fireball has maintained a loyal fan base, with many enthusiasts praising its ease of consumption and lack of harsh effects. The brand's popularity led to the creation of various spin-offs, including Fireball Flavors, and it continues to thrive, with over 85,000 followers on social media.

Researchers conducted a study involving 11 male athletes who were divided into two groups: one ate fast food and another consumed dietary supplements. During a 12-hour fasting period, both groups were then subjected to a 90-minute endurance workout. The study found that eating fast food resulted in similar performance outcomes to consuming dietary supplements, with glycogen levels remaining stable despite the consumption of fast food. This suggests that short-term food options can be effective for initiating glycogen resynthesis, regardless of whether they come from fast food or supplements.

Gael Monfils defeated Roger Federer 6-4, 7-6 in a thrilling match at the Monte Carlo Masters. Monfils showed flashes of brilliance throughout the contest, displaying athleticism and shot-making ability that left Federer frustrated. Despite being down 4-4, Monfils took control of the second set, winning several key points and eventually taking the tiebreaker. In the final set, Monfils' determination paid off, as he hit 22 winners to Federer's 17 and ultimately emerged victorious. Monfils celebrated his impressive win by shaking hands with Federer, who congratulated him on his performance.

Rev. Al Sharpton delivered a sermon at Charity Missionary Baptist Church in South Carolina, criticizing the police shooting of Walter Scott, a black driver who was fatally shot by a white police officer after fleeing a traffic stop. Sharpton praised Mayor Keith Summey for firing the officer responsible, Michael Slager, and called for national reform in policing. He also criticized the city's police department and urged people to come together to address racial tensions and promote justice. Sharpton denied allegations that Scott's family did not want him to attend his funeral due to concerns about media attention. The shooting occurred when Scott, a veteran in the US Coast Guard, was stopped by Officer Michael Slager for a broken tail light, leading to a confrontation that ended with Slager firing his gun and Scott running away.

A report by Stewart Brand suggests that while there are concerns about the potential for mass extinctions due to human activities, the actual likelihood of this happening is low. Despite these threats, many species are still thriving, and conservation efforts are paying off. Brand argues that instead of focusing solely on extinction prevention, we should prioritize long-term solutions and consider introducing extinct species back into the wild. With the discovery of new species at a rapid pace, it is unlikely that all 23,214 species currently deemed threatened with extinction would die out.

ISIS, a self-proclaimed caliphate, operates under a radical interpretation of Islamic law, with officials issuing documents such as birth certificates and university curricula that reflect its governance principles. The group controls various aspects of society, including healthcare, education, and entertainment, with officials enforcing strict Sharia laws and regulations. Despite being considered a terrorist organization, ISIS presents itself as a legitimate government, with its own institutions, such as a hospital and a mobile vaccination unit. The group's goal is to establish a moral authority based on Islamic teachings, making it impervious to criticism and opposition.

A 2-year-old boy was killed when a van driven by Archie Brown Jr, a 15-year-old passenger, collided with another vehicle in a residential area in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. An unidentified gunman then shot Brown Jr and a 15-year-old boy, killing both. The driver of the van, who remains unidentified, was shot and killed at the scene. The motive behind the shooting is currently unknown, but Milwaukee police believe it may be related to the death of the 2-year-old boy.

The odds on the new royal baby being a girl have dropped significantly after a Scottish bookmaker revealed that 90% of bets were in favor of a female child. The betting market has shifted towards a girl, with names such as Alice, Victoria, and Alice Maud Marie gaining popularity. The odds suggest that the Duchess of Cambridge may give birth to a girl, while others believe she may give birth to a boy, with favorites including James, Arthur, and Prince George. The betting market is highly speculative, but the odds indicate that the public's hopes are leaning towards a girl.

Holly Willoughby and Davina McCall, two long-time TV presenters, have joined forces for a new campaign celebrating finding the perfect hair shade with Garnier Nutrisse. They starred in a photo shoot showcasing their matching 10.01 multi-tonal blonde hair color, with Davina revealing her perfect match is 4.3. The duo has also launched a new campaign, which includes a range of clothing designs inspired by their shared style. The campaign aims to celebrate finding one's perfect hair color and features a mix of vintage and modern elements.

Ellanora Arthur Baidoo, a Brooklyn woman, is seeking a divorce from her husband Victor Sena Blood-Dzraku after being unable to find a way to serve him with divorce papers due to his refusal to comply. She used Facebook to try to serve him, but was unsuccessful, and instead asked the New York judge to use alternative methods such as sending the papers via social media. A judge ruled that social media platforms like Facebook are now considered acceptable ways to deliver divorce papers, allowing Baidoo to proceed with her divorce proceedings. Her husband has refused to respond or provide a fixed address, leading to a potential "divorce by default".

A relic of the Holy Shroud, believed to be the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, has gone on display to the public for the first time in five years. The 14-foot-long linen features the image of a man who appears to have been crucified and is thought to be a medieval forgery. Despite being disputed, the shroud holds significant cultural and spiritual value, representing Christ's suffering. It will be displayed in Turin Cathedral from June 24 to July 4, allowing over one million people to view it before it returns to private ownership.

A new luxury mansion in Mayfair, London, has hit the market for £25 million. This four-bedroom property, formerly a milking parlour, has been transformed into a modern residence with an indoor swimming pool, gym, and cinema room. Located on a site previously used for milking cows, the property boasts stunning artwork and impressive finishes throughout, including marble flooring and high ceilings. With its unique history dating back to Tudor times, this luxurious home is a rare find in the heart of Mayfair.

Aidan Turner, the star of the popular BBC period drama Poldark, will reprise his role as Captain Ross Poldark in a second series, following the success of the show's revival. The new series will continue the story of Ross Poldark, who returns home after the death of his father and finds himself torn between his feelings for his former fiancée, Elizabeth, and his new love interest, Demelza. The show, which was originally based on Winston Graham's novels, has become a huge hit for BBC1, attracting millions of viewers and helping the channel reach an outstanding start to the year. With the release of the new series, the show is expected to continue its momentum, with many fans eagerly awaiting the next installment.

A gastrointestinal illness has affected 100 people on the cruise ship Celebrity Infinity, which departed from San Diego on March 29 and arrived in Puerto Vallarta on April 10. The CDC has confirmed 95 cases of the illness among the ship's 2,117 passengers, while two crew members were also infected. This is the third time the ship has experienced such an outbreak, following previous incidents in 2006 and 2013. The CDC has increased cleaning and disinfection procedures on board and taken samples for further testing.

Electronic devices such as smartphones, cars, and appliances can benefit from UltraHaptics' technology, which creates tactile three-dimensional shapes literally out of thin air using ultrasound. This allows users to experience a new level of interaction with virtual objects, providing a sense of touch and presence. By adding haptic feedback, devices can simulate real-world interactions, enhancing the overall user experience. Companies like Facebook, Oculus, and others are already exploring the potential of UltraHaptics' technology, with applications ranging from gaming to smart home devices.

Jodie Barden, a 28-year-old mother of two young daughters, Ella and Chloe, suffers from Cockayne Syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects premature aging and has a life expectancy of just 12. Despite the challenges, she has planned her daughters' funerals and is determined to spend quality time with them before they pass away. The couple, along with their 28-year-old husband Luke, have worked tirelessly to raise funds for the Cockayne Syndrome charity, raising over £14,000 for the cause. Their daughters, Ella and Chloe, are both living with the condition, with Ella using a wheelchair and Chloe unable to walk, but showing remarkable resilience and spirit.

Eleven-year-old Damon Muller from Gladstone, Queensland, has a rare autoimmune disease called Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM), which causes severe inflammation and swelling in his muscles, leading to significant growth issues and discomfort. Due to the severity of his symptoms, Damon has almost doubled in size and experienced severe swelling and bloating since his diagnosis. His rash, particularly on his face and thighs, became infected and caused him to experience intense pain and difficulty moving. As a result, his parents are seeking medical attention and hope to raise funds to attend an international conference to learn more about their condition and connect with others who may be going through similar experiences.

Chelsy Davy, a 29-year-old Zimbabwean socialite, attended a London restaurant launch event for The Ivy Chelsea Garden, where she showed off her stylish side by wearing a white layered chiffon top paired with navy trousers and tan wedges. The outing marked a change from her previous more casual style, as she opted for a sophisticated look to celebrate the restaurant's grand opening. Her friend Irene Forte was also spotted at the event, and the two shared laughs and posed for photos together. This marks a new chapter in Davy's life, following her split from Prince Harry in May 2010.

Women experiencing hair loss due to iron deficiency may consider taking iron supplements, but it's essential to note that the effectiveness of these supplements varies and more research is needed to confirm their benefits. Eating a balanced diet rich in protein is crucial for maintaining healthy hair, as it provides the necessary building blocks for hair growth. Some supplements, such as Florisene pills containing iron, have shown promise in promoting hair growth, but the scientific evidence supporting their use is limited. Other options like Alpecin caffeine liquid hair energiser may stimulate hair growth, but its effectiveness in humans is still unclear.

Orangutan Suma, aged 36, underwent a thorough health examination at Melbourne Zoo due to painful arthritis. The examination involved taking X-rays and performing a full check-up, including her ears, teeth, and eyes. To alleviate her pain, Suma received a steroid injection administered by an orthopedic surgeon. This treatment was necessary because Suma's arthritis is considered a common issue among middle-aged orangutans, despite being relatively rare in humans.

Louis Tomlinson, a member of the British boy band One Direction, was spotted having a wild night in London's Soho Hotel with five girls, including a woman who joked that he might be "one Direction" in a Snapchat video. The photos show Louis back in his hotel room, where he rolled a suspicious cigarette and was seen playing air guitar. The snaps also appear to show Louis returning to the hotel after a night of partying with his friends, including fellow bandmates Harry Styles and Niall Horan. The wild night came after Louis broke up with his girlfriend, Eleanor Calder, in March.

A series of old photographs taken between 1900 and 1911 during the Qing dynasty show Beijing's famous landmarks, including the Temple of Heaven, Summer Palace, and Western Qing Tombs, showcasing the city's tranquil atmosphere without crowds. These historic images provide a glimpse into Beijing's past, highlighting its unique character before the advent of tourism. The photographs also reveal the city's serene beauty, featuring locals and foreigners posing together in peaceful settings. The images have been preserved as UNESCO World Heritage Sites, offering a fascinating look back at Beijing's history.

Australian homeowners are experiencing record-breaking profits on their properties due to a surge in sales, with many homes selling for more than double their original price. According to a recent report, only 8.6% of homes sold for a loss, while 32.3% sold for more than double their original price. Homes in major cities like Sydney, Perth, and Melbourne are seeing significant gains, with some selling for over $3 million. In contrast, homes in regional areas are still struggling to find buyers, with prices remaining relatively stable or even decreasing slightly.

Tony Pulis, the manager of West Bromwich Albion, wore a traditional suit and tie to the match against Crystal Palace despite having previously worn a cap and tracksuit. He insisted on this uniform due to a personal preference, stating he'd never remove it during a game. The 2-0 victory secured West Brom's 36-point lead in the Premier League, ensuring their survival. James Morrison scored both goals, while Craig Gardner added one, as Pulis led his team to a dominant performance. This marked a rare instance where Pulis chose to wear a cap instead of his usual tracksuit.

Steve Parish, Crystal Palace co-chairman, celebrated a great moment after the team's 2-1 win over Manchester City, posing for a photo with Palace manager Alan Pardew, England boss Roy Hodgson, and former Rolling Stones member Bill Wyman. Wyman, who has been a lifelong fan of the club, was among the many supporters in attendance. Hodgson, who is also a former Palace player, praised Wyman's dedication to the team and its history. Parish noted that Wyman had been a regular attendee at Palace games since he was just 10 years old. The win marked a significant victory for the Eagles, who were led by manager Pardew and featuring several notable English players, including Jason Puncheon and Wilfried Zaha.

The Solar Impulse 2, a single-seater experimental plane, has been grounded due to bad weather in China, forcing a two-and-a-half-week stay. Pilot Bertrand Piccard and co-pilot Andre Borschberg have spent weeks preparing for the plane's journey, which aims to prove the power of renewable energy and inspire innovation. Despite the setback, the team remains optimistic, with a planned return to Abu Dhabi on Tuesday. The plane's technical issues include a need for near-perfect cross-winds and a fragile structure, but the team is working to resolve these problems.

Jordan Spieth visited the observation deck of the Empire State Building after winning the Masters tournament, where he was presented with the green jacket by Bubba Watson. Spieth became the Augusta record-equalling champion, breaking multiple records along the way, including equalling Tiger Woods' 18-under total in 1997. Spieth's victory was a culmination of his impressive performance at the Masters, where he overcame disappointment to claim his fourth major title. Justin Rose praised Spieth's clutch putter, saying it was "one of the best" he'd ever seen. Spieth's achievement solidified his position as golf's next big star, and he now sits at number two in the world rankings.

David Cameron's home features a stylish kitchen, complete with a cafetière and a collection of cookbooks, indicating a refined taste. His home also boasts a silver photo frame and a television, suggesting a comfortable and upscale lifestyle. However, his lack of a proper tea set and a cluttered bookshelf raise questions about his social status. Overall, Cameron's home appears to be a reflection of his upper-class background, with a focus on quality and sophistication.

Andy Murray tied the knot with British tennis star Kim Sears at Dunblane Cathedral, surrounded by thousands of fans and family members. The ceremony took place in the 12th-century cathedral, with Reverend Colin Renwick leading the service. The happy couple exchanged rings and shared a kiss as hundreds of well-wishers cheered outside. Murray's brother Jamie Murray was also in attendance, while local boy Andy was seen as a hero in his hometown. The couple is planning to marry in front of friends and family, with reports suggesting several tennis stars may attend, including Tim Henman and Ross Hutchins.

Alastair Cook played a decent innings against the West Indies, showing signs of improvement in his game, particularly with his front foot work. However, he appeared to overdo it in the first Test, with his front foot coming forward too much, leading to some awkward moments. This could be a concern for England's future success, especially considering his greatest asset is his mental strength. Despite this setback, Cook showed flashes of brilliance, particularly in the nets session where he looked good. His ability to adapt and settle quickly will be key to his continued development.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. He has been with the Catalan club for seven years, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. Alves's agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that he had rejected a three-year contract extension, citing that it was "not a good fit" for him. The move is expected to spark a transfer scramble for Alves, who has been linked with several top clubs including Manchester United and Manchester City.

Robin Ellis, now 73, was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in 1999 at the age of 58 after a chance encounter with a friend who was diagnosed with prostate cancer. Despite being overweight and smoking heavily, he had never had any symptoms of diabetes until he was tested. His mother had type 1 diabetes, and Robin's doctor suspected type 2 diabetes due to his normal BMI and lack of visible fat deposits. With lifestyle changes, including eliminating sugar and refined carbs, Robin has managed to control his blood sugar levels and is now taking medication to manage the disease.

Aaron Hernandez, a former New England Patriots tight end, has been transferred to the Souza-Baranowski Correctional Center in Shirley, Massachusetts, after being convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison. He was convicted of killing Odin Lloyd in 2013, who was dating the sister of Hernandez's fiancée. Hernandez was initially housed at Cedar Junction prison before being transferred due to safety concerns. His new prison is a maximum-security facility with 366 cameras monitoring its inmates' activities, and he will be housed in a cell block reserved for those serving life sentences.

A 35-year-old man named Jamie Robbins stole £1,600 from a convenience store in Birmingham, where he had previously worked. He handed himself into police after a year without being caught due to his preference for life inside rather than out. Robbins claimed he was seeking a new life behind bars, but later revealed that his girlfriend had become pregnant and changed his mind. He was sentenced to four-and-a-half years in prison for robbery and possession of a bladed article.

A camel named Injaz, who was cloned from ovarian cells in 2009, gave birth to a healthy calf, marking the world's first successful cloning of a camel. Scientists claim that Injaz, a six-year-old female, conceived naturally and was cloned through a process involving surrogate mothers. The cloning process involved taking cells from a slaughtered camel and planting them into an egg, which was then fertilized by a surrogate mother. This breakthrough demonstrates that cloned camels can reproduce naturally, proving that they are fertile and can produce offspring. The achievement has sparked excitement among scientists, who hope that it will lead to further advancements in genetic engineering and conservation efforts.

Sir Alex Ferguson, former Manchester United manager, revealed why he thinks Cristiano Ronaldo is better than Lionel Messi during an interview with John Parrott on the BBC's World Championship at the Crucible. Ferguson cited Ronaldo's versatility, athleticism, and bravery as reasons why he prefers the Portuguese star. He also praised Ronaldo's ability to play for any team and score goals, which he felt was unmatched by Messi. Ferguson had previously worked with Ronaldo at Manchester United and considers him one of his closest friends and former teammates. Ferguson's love for snooker was evident as he played a frame with a cue gifted to him by friend Ken Doherty.

A bus carrying Fenerbahce players and coaching staff was attacked while traveling from a match in Trabzon to Istanbul, resulting in injuries to the driver and potentially several other individuals. The driver, who was heading home from a game, was struck by gunfire and sustained a head injury. A shotgun was used in the attack, and the driver was rushed to hospital. Several people, including Fenerbahce midfielder Ludovic Obraniak, were also injured in the incident. The attack occurred near the city of Trabzon, where Fenerbahce was playing against Caykur Rizespor.

Nicola Ferguson Sturgeon, the leader of the Scottish National Party, gave a confident and charismatic performance on national television, impressing a wide audience with her poise and style. She addressed a large crowd, saying "GSM Sturgeon" and delivering a message of friendship to the people of England, Wales, and Northern Ireland. With a strong track record of governance, she has the experience and charisma to hold significant influence in Westminster, and her ability to unite her party and nation makes her a formidable force. A recent poll suggests that 28% of viewers thought she was the best performer, and her leadership could potentially sway opinion in the upcoming independence referendum.

Declan Fitzpatrick, a 31-year-old prop for Ulster Rugby, has announced his retirement from professional rugby due to medical reasons. The Irish prop suffered multiple concussions over the years, leading to progressive worsening of his symptoms. After consulting with a neurologist, Ulster Rugby advised Fitzpatrick to stop playing to ensure his long-term health. Fitzpatrick expressed gratitude to his medical team and the IRFU for their support throughout his career.

FLIR Systems Inc., a defense contractor based in Oregon, has agreed to pay $9.5 million to settle bribery charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) related to gifts and expenses given to Middle Eastern government officials. The SEC alleged that FLIR's CEO Andy Teich and two employees, Stephen Timms and Yasser Ramahi, accepted bribes in exchange for luxury items such as watches and vacations. The company will report to the SEC on its compliance with anti-bribery laws over the next two years. As part of the settlement, FLIR will pay $7 million in profits from sales influenced by the gifts, while also agreeing to cooperate with the investigation.

Floyd Mayweather Jr is preparing for his highly anticipated $300 million mega fight against Manny Pacquiao, which will take place on May 2 at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas. Inside his training camp, Mayweather is focusing hard to reach the 147-pound welterweight limit, having recently weighed in at 3.5 pounds under the mark. A short promotional video released by Showtime shows a glimpse into Mayweather's intense training sessions, where he is determined to push himself to the limit. This marks one of the biggest fights in boxing history, with both fighters vying for the WBA, WBO, and WBC welterweight titles. Mayweather is confident about the upcoming bout, stating that this is "the biggest fight I've ever wanted."

A 58-year-old woman, Diwalinen Vankar, bravely fought off a 13ft crocodile with a wooden washing paddle to rescue her 19-year-old daughter Kanta, who was being held captive by a mugger crocodile in the Vishwamitri River. The crocodile attacked while Diwalinen Vankar was trying to wash their clothes, dragging Kanta into the river. Despite being injured herself, Vankar managed to hit the crocodile with her paddle and eventually freed Kanta, who suffered a leg injury. The incident occurred in a village near Vadodara, India, where there is a high risk of crocodile attacks due to a lack of water and electricity.

The article discusses the 20 greatest shots ever seen at Augusta National Golf Club, counting down from 20 to 1. These iconic moments include notable performances by players such as Mark O'Meara, who shot two birdies in three holes to win the 1998 Masters, and Charl Schwartzel, who achieved a four-shot victory in 2011. Other highlights include Seve Ballesteros's dramatic hole-in-one, Byron Nelson's stunning eagle, and Louis Oosthuizen's record-breaking albatross. The article concludes with a look back at the first Masters where Billy Joe Patton came within one stroke of winning, and Mark O'Meara celebrated his winning putt in 1998.

Jaclyn Methuen, a former "runaway bride" who nearly left her husband Ryan Ranellone at the altar due to his perceived lack of attractiveness, is now embroiled in marital troubles on her honeymoon in Puerto Rico. Her new husband Ryan DeNiro struggles to connect with her, citing discomfort with her constant calls of "dude" and "bro", while Davina Kullar, another newlywed, finds herself feeling similarly disconnected from her husband Sean Varricchio. Despite their shared honeymoon experience, both couples face challenges in navigating their relationships amidst the pressures of marriage. In separate incidents, Jaclyn lets Ryan Rub sunscreen on her bottom, while Davina cries on a ski lift, highlighting the difficulties of maintaining intimacy in a long-distance marriage.

Mullah Mohammed Omar, the founder of the Taliban's self-declared Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan, remains the leader of the group despite rumors suggesting he may have died. Born in 1960 in a village in Afghanistan's Kandahar province, Omar studied at a religious school before joining the mujahedeen rebellion against the Soviet Union. The Taliban biography, released in several translations, aims to dispel rumors of his demise and provide insights into his life and leadership style. The biography describes Omar's early years as a commander of rebel groups fighting against the Soviets and his role in launching a struggle against corruption and anarchy.

The NFL investigation into the New England Patriots' alleged use of deflated footballs during the AFC Championship game against the Indianapolis Colts began in January, led by attorney Ted Wells. The investigation, which has been ongoing for over three months, aims to determine if the Patriots intentionally deflated the footballs to gain an unfair advantage. The league has hired several firms, including Renaissance Associates, to review electronic and video footage, and Commissioner Roger Goodell has stated that a thorough investigation will be completed by the end of the process. The Patriots could face fines and/or draft picks if the investigation finds wrongdoing, while the NFL has not yet determined the severity of the penalty. The investigation is focused on determining if the Patriots violated NFL rules regarding the inflation of footballs.

A 28-year-old woman named Bianca Gascoigne was mugged by a gang of eight on bikes in central London, with her phone reportedly stolen and containing private texts. The attacker grabbed her phone and tried to steal her bag before running away when she fought back. Bianca Gascoigne, the daughter of football legend Paul Gascoigne, took to social media to express her anger towards the thugs, calling them "lowlifes" and stating that her phone contained private texts. The incident occurred in Wimpole Road, Marylebone, and an investigation is underway.

Aberdeen striker Adam Rooney is determined to prevent a disappointing conclusion to the season, having won the Scotland Player of the Year award despite his team's struggles this campaign. Rooney wants to ensure that Aberdeen wins the league title, despite being eight points behind Celtic, who are currently second place. With a strong squad and a talented young forward in Adam Rooney, who has scored 27 goals this season, Aberdeen aims to build on their momentum and secure a fourth consecutive Premiership title. Rooney believes that if they can add more quality to the team, they can challenge Celtic for the title. The Scots are looking to bounce back from a 4-0 defeat to Celtic last weekend, which has left them feeling frustrated and eager to win the league.

Marion "Suge" Knight, a former rap mogul, was ordered to stand trial for murder and other charges related to a deadly hit-and-run incident on the set of the biopic "Straight Outta Compton". Knight, 49, faces up to life in prison if convicted, and his defense team argued that he was the victim, claiming he was attacked by his accuser, Cle Sloan, who was seeking immunity. A judge reduced Knight's bail to $10 million, and he will face one count of murder, one count of attempted murder, and one count of hit-and-run. Knight suffered from diabetes and clotting issues before the incident, and his attorney argued that he was not a threat to anyone, despite prosecutors' claims that he was involved in a "mutual combat situation".

Hillary Clinton's Iowa campaign held a staged meeting with three young Iowans at a coffee shop in LeClaire, Iowa, which was organized by campaign staffer Troy Price. The meeting was intended to gauge their opinions on various issues, but it appears to have been a setup for media attention. The attendees included Austin Bird, a Democratic Party insider who chauffeured Vice President Joe Biden in October 2014, and were later revealed to be part of Clinton's nascent campaign. This move could harm Clinton's reputation if seen as an attempt to deceive voters, particularly in a state where direct contact with candidates is valued.

A new HIV self-testing kit has been launched in the UK, allowing individuals to test their HIV status at home using a finger-prick blood sample. This 99.7% accurate test enables people to know their HIV status quickly and discreetly, reducing the risk of transmission. Those who remain undiagnosed despite having HIV face a higher risk of complications and death if left untreated. The test requires positive results to be confirmed by a healthcare professional, while those in high-risk groups should test regularly.

In California's prisons, many inmates are released from Level IV maximum-security facilities after serving significant time for gang-related crimes. These inmates often form exclusive housing units, known as Sensitive Needs Housing Units, where they live separately from other inmates and gang-affiliated individuals. Within these units, some inmates receive support and resources to help them reintegrate back into society, while others continue to engage in gang activities. Despite efforts to reduce gang influence, rival gangs like the Black Guerilla Family, Aryan Brotherhood, and Mexican Mafia still exert control over certain areas of the prison, leading to violent conflicts.

A personal injury claims company, Direct Assist, has been fined £80,000 by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) for allegedly causing nuisance calls to households despite receiving numerous complaints about its practice. The company instructed its staff to use phone numbers from the Telephone Preference Service (TPS), which includes those on the list of people who have opted out of unwanted calls. Despite being warned multiple times, Direct Assist continued to call these individuals, leaving them fearful of answering the phone. The ICO found that the company's behavior showed a "blatant disregard" for the law and its customers.

Jose Mourinho's defensive prowess has been instrumental in securing multiple Premier League titles for Chelsea, with a remarkable 101 clean sheets in 189 matches. The Portuguese manager has consistently topped the league table in terms of clean sheets, beating Rafa Benitez's record of 54.4%. This achievement comes after Mourinho's first stint at Chelsea, where he secured three league titles. Meanwhile, Arsene Wenger holds the record for most clean sheets in Premier League history, conceding just 277 goals in 708 games. With 0.95 clean-sheet percentage, Wenger is also the leader in this category.

A 15-year-old girl from Cape Town, South Africa was detained by authorities at Cape Town International Airport after they received information she was planning to join the terrorist group ISIS. The girl had been using social media to interact with individuals who suggested she join the group. Authorities found her on a flight bound for Johannesburg, where she was subsequently secured and released back to her family's care. The incident highlights concerns about the growing threat of terrorism among young people, particularly those under the age of 18.

Ben Powers, an actor known for his roles in the classic CBS sitcom "Good Times", passed away on April 6 after suffering a fatal injury during a football game. He played the character Keith Anderson on the show from 1978 to 1979. Powers also appeared in various TV shows, including "Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer", "Cheech & Chong's Next Movie", and "The Man Who Loved Women". He attended the Rhode Island School of Design for art and later pursued a career in stand-up comedy, performing in clubs in Los Angeles, New York, and Boston.

A 39-year-old man, identified as Karl Kay, was shot multiple times while sitting in his car in his mother's Altona Meadows driveway in a cold-blooded execution-style shooting. The shooting occurred around 2am on Sunday, leaving him mortally wounded. His mother, who was present at home, was also injured and taken to a hospital for assistance. Detectives are investigating the incident, which appears to be a targeted attack, and ballistics experts are combing through the vehicle for forensic evidence. The motive behind the shooting remains unknown.

A photographer visited the Ulusaba Game Reserve in South Africa's Sabi Sands, where he encountered a 4,500lb horned rhino, photographed several species, including a buffalo, impala antelope, and cheetah, and even spotted a leopard cub playing in a tree. The reserve is Sir Richard Branson's private property, offering stunning views of the African bush landscape. The photographer was accompanied by his friend James and mother, Sky TV presenter Kay Burley, who documented the experience. The visit was a highlight of the photographer's trip, which included seeing many endangered species, including the crash of rhinos and a lioness allowing a photographer to get close to a pride of lions.

George Lucas, the creator of Star Wars, has announced plans to build an affordable housing complex on his 1,039-acre ranch in Marin County, California, despite initial opposition from his neighbors. The project, valued at $200m, will include two complexes with 224 homes, one for low-income families and another for pensioners. Lucas has stated that he wants to use his wealth to benefit the community, rather than just his own interests. The project has sparked controversy, with some neighbors opposing the idea due to concerns about the impact on their property values.

A great grey owl swooped on a tiny field mouse in Ontario, Canada, capturing a bird's-eye view of the moment as it stalked and attacked its prey. The owl's exceptional senses allowed it to make a silent landing in the snow, where it snatched up the mouse with its sharp claws. With its impressive wingspan of five feet, the owl was able to launch itself into action, striking with lightning speed and precision. The owl's ability to hover silently over the ground before attacking made it nearly invisible, adding to the dramatic effect of the scene.

Manchester City defender Bacary Sagna has expressed no regrets about leaving Arsenal last summer, despite the club's struggles in the Premier League. He joined City after winning the FA Cup with them, but now finds himself facing a year without a trophy. Sagna believes Manchester City will return to winning ways under manager Manuel Pellegrini and hopes they can end the season strongly. He brushes off concerns that City could be usurped from the Champions League qualifying places. Sagna's decision to leave Arsenal remains unchanged, and he is confident that City will succeed under Pellegrini.

David Cameron, the former Prime Minister, has been accused by Nigel Farage of secretly using hair dye to try to reverse the effects of aging. The Ukip leader suggested that Cameron's decision to dye his hair is "jealous" of his apparent youthfulness. Cameron denied any wrongdoing, saying he simply wants to look younger. Farage claimed that some people worry excessively about their appearance, but others do not.
