Veteran World War II hero Robert Clark, 96, is facing eviction from his home due to Brent Council's refusal to increase funding for a live-in carer, despite receiving an emergency grant from Help for Heroes to cover his care costs. The council claims it cannot afford to provide the necessary care, citing financial constraints, but the charity says it wants to find a solution that meets Mr Clark's needs and allows him to stay in his own home. With over 165,000 people signing a petition calling for his help, Help for Heroes has launched a JustGiving page to raise funds to keep Mr Clark in his home. The charity has already provided an emergency grant to cover his immediate care needs, but now seeks donations to reach the remaining £2,736.22 needed to meet his full care requirements.

FC Chernomorets Odessa is selling luxury houses near the sea to cover their salary debts, offering them to their players as part of a plan to avoid relegation and disqualification from UEFA competitions. The club's general manager, Sergey Kernitskiy, claims the houses are valued at £67,000 each. Players who remain with the club will see their monthly salaries reduced to £2,000 per month. The move comes amid the club's struggles to pay off debts to its top players, which include some who have already left the team. FC Chernomorets currently sits 11th in the Ukrainian Premier League, just 12 points behind bottom side Karpaty.

Kestutis Martuzevicius, a Lithuanian gangster, was accused of 22 crimes, including two murders, while living in the UK. He repeatedly stalled efforts to extradite him due to mental health concerns, claiming he was depressed and would face retaliation from his homeland. Despite being deemed "manifestly ill-founded" by the European Court of Human Rights, Martuzevicius continued to appeal against extradition, citing his right to a fair trial and protection from harm. His case highlights concerns about how easily foreign criminals can exploit human rights laws.

A vigilante group of paedophile hunters, accused of posing as children online and filming their victims, have been linked to several attacks in the North-West of England. The group, known as NWNI Nonce Busters, allegedly tricked a 19-year-old man into meeting a 14-year-old girl in a church car park, where they beat him up and filmed the incident. The victim, who has not been named, reported the assault to police and was subsequently arrested and charged with attempting to meet a child under 16. The group's actions have sparked widespread condemnation, with Greater Manchester Police urging anyone with information to come forward. The investigation is ongoing, with another suspect, a 25-year-old man, also facing charges related to the same crimes.

Real Madrid's Champions League starting lineup took a break after the 0-0 draw against Atletico, with key players like Isco and James Rodriguez absent. The team returned to training on Wednesday, where they worked alongside regular first team players Pepe and Sami Khedira. In separate sessions, Isco and Alvaro Arbeloa participated, while Pepe climbed the stairs as he wasn't on the field. Real Madrid also welcomed back midfielder Lucas Silva, who had been linked with a transfer to the Premier League. The team will now look to bounce back from a disappointing loss to Atletico in La Liga before facing Malaga on Saturday.

David Hibbitt, a 33-year-old man from Stoke-on-Trent, England, was diagnosed with stage-three bowel cancer in July 2012 and underwent chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and surgery to remove his large bowel. Despite receiving a prognosis of 18 months to five years to live, he decided to try cannabis oil as a last resort, which he credits with his recovery. After researching options, he paid £50 per gram of cannabis oil, which helped alleviate his symptoms and led to a miraculous turnaround in his health. With the support of his fiancée, he went on to tie the knot and start a new chapter in his life.

President Barack Obama visited Everglades National Park today to highlight the impact of climate change on the environment and its potential consequences for America's "national treasures" such as the Everglades. He emphasized the need for immediate action to combat climate change, citing rising temperatures and sea levels as evidence of its threat. The president's visit coincided with Earth Day, and he used the opportunity to emphasize the importance of taking care of the Everglades and other natural wonders like it. His actions were met with applause from the crowd, who saw him as a champion of environmental protection.

Javier Hernandez returned to training with Real Madrid after a disappointing season, having failed to make any moves to join the club despite being allowed to leave on a free transfer. He had previously signed a loan deal with the team, allowing them to keep him until the end of the season. However, this deal expired at midnight, opening up opportunities for other clubs to bid for the Mexican striker. United have expressed interest in signing Hernandez, who scored five goals in his last six games, including a crucial goal in their Champions League quarter-final victory over Atletico Madrid. With the window closing, other teams may now be able to make a move for the 26-year-old striker.

Bonnie Doll, a 28-year-old Australian gamer, rose to fame playing Call Of Duty and has built a massive following on Twitch, with over 45,000 global followers and nearly one million views on her channel. Born in Sweden, Bonnie moved to Australia in 2007 and began live streaming on Twitch, initially playing Call Of Duty with friends before becoming a solo streamer. She has leveraged her gaming skills to build a lucrative career, earning significant income from subscriptions, donations, and ad revenue. With a strong online presence, Bonnie enjoys a comfortable lifestyle, often playing from home and interacting with her devoted fan base.

YouTube is introducing a new paid subscription service called YouTube Music Key, which allows creators to earn up to 55% of the revenue generated from subscription fees. This service will provide ad-free videos, offline playback, and access to exclusive content, including music videos, recommendations, and personalized playlists. The service will be available for creators to sign up for, and will require them to agree to updated terms on YouTube's Creator Studio Dashboard. The service is expected to launch in the UK, US, Ireland, Italy, Spain, and Finland later this year, with prices starting at £7.99 per month.

Marion "Suge" Knight, a former rapper and music mogul, has been hospitalized after a judge ruled he will stand trial on murder and attempted-murder charges related to a fatal hit-and-run incident involving two men. Knight, 49, allegedly struck and killed Terry Carter, 55, and seriously injured another man, Cle "Bone" Sloan, 45, who was left with severe injuries. Knight faces up to life in prison if convicted, despite having prior felony convictions for similar crimes. Sloan, a former gang member, testified about the incident, describing Knight as "deceptive" and claiming he was only on the stand to avoid incriminating himself. Knight's court hearings have been dramatic, with multiple medical conditions and previous run-ins with the law contributing to his struggles.

Bailey Murrill, a 7-year-old girl from Denton, Texas, was unexpectedly paralyzed for 11 days due to an inexplicable condition, which left her unable to move. Her favorite nurse, Becky Murrill, surprised her by getting up from her wheelchair and walking towards her, causing Bailey to scream with joy and then burst into tears. A video of the moment was captured, showing Becky embracing Bailey and hugging her tightly, prompting others to join in the emotional reunion. The incident was shared online, garnering over 1 million views and sparking widespread praise for the nurse's kindness.

Julian Assange, founder of WikiLeaks, has agreed to be interviewed by Swedish prosecutors in London after a pause in his asylum in the Ecuadorian Embassy since June 2012. The move comes as Swedish prosecutors seek to question him about allegations of rape and sexual molestation made against him in 2010. Assange had sought refuge in the Ecuadorian Embassy to avoid extradition to Sweden, but the country's prosecutor has changed their stance due to the statute of limitations. Ecuador granted Assange political asylum in 2012, allowing him to remain in the country until the case was resolved.

Pete Bennett, a former Big Brother star, has revealed that he is now homeless after struggling with homelessness for nine years. He credits his time on the show with starting a range of problems, including a dependence on the Class B drug ketamine. Bennett, who won the show in 2006, has spoken publicly about his struggles with Tourette's syndrome and his decision to leave the show due to the pressures of fame. He has since sought treatment and is now attempting to rebuild his life, including pursuing acting roles.

Borussia Dortmund returned to winning ways with a comfortable 4-2 victory over relegation-threatened Paderborn at Signal Iduna Park. Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang scored twice, including a goal in the 55th minute, to give Dortmund a 2-0 lead. Shinji Kagawa sealed the win with a late goal, while Henrikh Mkhitaryan provided the assist. The win moves Dortmund into third place, one point behind leaders Augsburg, and has given the club a realistic chance of qualifying for European competition. The win also marked a significant boost to the fans' morale, who celebrated with a banner thanking manager Jurgen Klopp for his achievements.

A North Korean defector is launching hundreds of balloons carrying DVDs and leaflets into North Korean territory, despite warnings from authorities about the potential consequences. The move is seen as an attempt to show the world how ordinary North Koreans feel about their leader, Kim Jong Un, who is portrayed in the movie "The Interview". Local residents near the border have been trying to stop the launches, fearing they may be putting themselves in harm's way. The defector claims the goal is to bring attention to the human side of the conflict between the two countries, rather than provoking further violence.

A new thermal protection case called Optimal has been developed to prevent phone overheating, which can damage devices. The case features micro-fans to cool the phone down and resistance coils to warm it up if necessary. It monitors the phone's temperature and alerts the user if it gets too hot, and can also use the built-in battery as a backup. The case is designed to work with various smartphones, including Apple, Samsung, Nexus, HTC, and Xperia models, and is expected to launch in early April through an Indiegogo campaign.

A Russian fishing vessel called the Dalniy Vostok freezer trawler went down in the Sea of Okhotsk after colliding with an obstacle, resulting in the deaths of at least 54 people. The incident occurred while the vessel was carrying 132 people, mostly Russians, who were on their way to deliver frozen seafood. Over 60 people were rescued from the water, but 15 remain missing. The cause of the sinking is believed to be a collision with an obstacle, and it appears that the trawler may have keeled over due to excessive weight being hauled onto its deck. A search operation is underway to locate the remaining crew members.

This article reviews ten food-related apps available for download, covering various aspects such as meal planning, recipe creation, and restaurant discovery. These apps cater to different needs, including planning meals, tracking food waste, finding the best restaurants, and exploring local food options. Some notable features include chefs' expert recommendations, personalized meal planning tools, and access to a vast database of recipes and wine information. Overall, these apps aim to simplify meal planning and exploration, providing users with convenient and informative solutions for their culinary interests.

Jeremy Clarkson's estranged wife Frances Clarkson has been enjoying a family break in Barbados, where she showed off her tan in a white bikini during a dip in the sea. The 53-year-old has been separated from her husband, 54-year-old Jeremy Clarkson, since 2011, after allegations of infidelity and racism surfaced. Frances has been spotted relaxing on the beach with her friend Phillipa Sage, who organized the trip, and has accessorized with a Help For Heroes wristband. Clarkson was seen kissing his ex-wife on the lips in 2011, sparking outrage and accusations of using racial slurs.

Aldi, a discount supermarket chain, has been criticized for failing to notify customers of a 0.5% credit card surcharge placed on transactions using their tap and go payment system, despite promising to do so. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) took action against the company after an investigation found that Aldi did not comply with disclosure requirements. Many Aldi stores still do not display signs indicating the presence of the surcharge, which applies to both credit and debit card payments. This lack of transparency has left customers unsure about the true cost of using the supermarket's services.

A group of Russian bullion, valued at millions of pounds, was lost in the River Clyde due to a wartime blunder involving the HMS Ulster Queen, a former Irish Sea ferry converted into a battle cruiser. The bullion was loaded onto the ship in Murmansk in 1942 and was intended to pay for American arms shipments to Russia. However, the case was lost overboard while transferring the bullion to a waiting boat, and despite efforts to recover it, it remains lost to this day. The incident involved the secret diary of the Ulster Queen's engineer, Leonard H. Thomas, which was recently uncovered and published, revealing the shocking tale of the lost cargo.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan soccer player, admitted to biting Italy defender Giorgio Chiellini during a World Cup match in Brazil, despite initially denying it. His wife Sofia revealed that he confessed to the incident 10 days after the fact, saying "he told me he hadn't done it" when she asked if he had bitten him. Suarez was subsequently banned for four months due to the incident, which occurred during a World Cup match between Uruguay and Italy. Since his release from the ban, Suarez has played well for Barcelona, scoring crucial goals for the team.

A 48-year-old man, Ranulfo Perez, was arrested in New York's Times Square for allegedly groping a 16-year-old girl who was dressed as the Cookie Monster. Perez was arrested after the girl claimed he touched her breasts without her consent. Perez denied any wrongdoing, saying he loved people and children, but was released due to concerns that the victim may not have identified him. This incident is part of a growing trend of costumed characters in Times Square, which has led to increased calls for regulation and licensing fees. Perez was arrested again last year for similar charges.

A gunfight erupted between two brothers, Marc Wabafiyebazu and Joshua Wright, and several individuals involved in a drug deal in Miami, resulting in the deaths of both brothers. The incident occurred at a home in the Coral Way area, where the brothers attempted to rob a group of drug dealers. Marc Wabafiyebazu was arrested for felony murder and robbery, while Joshua Wright was fatally shot. His brother Anthony Rodriguez was also injured in the shooting. The incident occurred after the brothers drove to the location with a third friend to purchase marijuana, leading to the violence.

Dr Omar Saadi Al-Atraqchi, a 42-year-old urology specialist, was found guilty of secretly filming men in gym showers while working at Custom House Surgery in North London. He cut holes in Lynx shampoo bottles to conceal iPhones and hid them in the bottles to film men using the showers. Al-Atraqchi pleaded guilty to four counts of voyeurism and was fined £500, ordered to pay costs of £85 and a victim surcharge of £25. He faces a hearing to determine whether he will be struck off the medical register due to his actions.

A former US Army enlistee, John T. Booker Jr., was arrested and charged with attempting to detonate a car bomb at Fort Riley military base in Kansas. Booker, who had expressed admiration for ISIS leader Maj. Nidal Hasan, planned to use explosives to harm American soldiers, including those at the base. He was found to have acquired components for a bomb and rented a storage locker, and was arrested along with another individual, Alexander E. Blair, who failed to report a felony. Both men are facing charges related to their involvement in a plot to detonate a vehicle bomb at the base.

A new study suggests that experiencing stressful events, particularly in childhood, may increase the likelihood of developing type 1 diabetes. The research analyzed data from over 10,000 families and found that children who experienced stressful events such as death, divorce, or separation had a higher risk of developing the condition. The study also found that genetic predisposition plays a significant role, with a 12-fold increased risk of developing type 1 diabetes if one parent has the condition. Furthermore, the study's findings suggest that damaging events in childhood can affect the development of beta cells in the pancreas, leading to an increased demand for insulin production.

A 15-year-old African American teenager, Jamar Nicholson, was shot by a police officer in South Los Angeles after being mistaken for carrying a real gun. He and his friend Jason Huerta were caught holding a toy gun, which was later determined to be fake, and were shot by an officer named Miguel Gutierrez. Nicholson and Huerta are suing the city of Los Angeles for $20 million, claiming they were unfairly targeted by the police. The incident occurred on February 10, 2024, and both men suffered injuries, with Nicholson missing school due to his condition.

A man was found asleep on a baggage reclaim conveyor belt at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport, causing concern among passengers who were waiting to claim their luggage. The unusual sight sparked amusement, but officials took action to prevent similar incidents in the future. The man was eventually released after being scanned through an X-ray machine. Passengers were entertained by the scene, even if they didn't want to claim their own luggage.

Cadbury is releasing a new super bar called the Dairy Milk Spectacular 7, featuring seven rows of different flavors, including Dairy Milk Caramel, Dairy Milk Fruit & Nut, Dairy Milk Whole Nut, Dairy Milk Oreo, Dairy Milk Daim, and Dairy Milk Turkish. This is the first time Cadbury has released a super bar with seven fillings. The bar was created by working with food artist Prudence Staite and was designed to encourage customers to try new flavors. The seven-row bar contains one row of each flavor, making it a unique offering from the brand.

A 72-year-old former Nigerian military leader, Muhammadu Buhari, has won the presidential election, marking a significant shift towards greater political maturity in West Africa. Buhari, who previously ruled Nigeria as a harsh military leader, campaigned on an anti-corruption platform, suggesting that ordinary Nigerians have grown tired of elite corruption. His victory represents a peaceful transfer of power from President Goodluck Jonathan, who may have benefited from the Boko Haram terrorist crisis, and marks a new era of stability in Nigeria. Despite criticism of his past rule, Buhari's campaign resonated with many Nigerians, particularly in urban areas, who felt disillusioned with the Jonathan government's inability to address poverty and corruption.

Daniel O'Reilly, a former British comedian known for his "laddish" persona, has traveled from London to Sydney via Doha and Melbourne, documenting his journey on social media. He met air stewards and cleaners, using his "Dapper Laughs" alter ego, and made jokes about their appearance and behavior. His TV show "Dapper Laughs: On The Pull" was canceled due to criticism over its sexist content, but he revived his character on Christmas Day. A petition calling for the show's cancellation reached over 60,000 signatures, and many comedians condemned his behavior.

A British Muslim family, including Councillor Shakil Ahmed's son Waheed, who was 21 years old when arrested for joining ISIS-controlled Syria, are returning to England after being caught trying to cross into the country. They were among nine individuals who attempted to enter Syria, where they were apprehended by Turkish authorities. The family, including Waheed's cousin and aunt, are believed to be involved in smuggling activities, and their actions are considered a threat to national security. The incident highlights the challenges faced by the government in preventing extremist individuals from entering the country.

Avril Lavigne, 30, has revealed she has Lyme disease, a debilitating bacterial infection caused by a tick bite. The singer, known for hits like "Losing Grip" and "Sk8er Boi", suffered from symptoms such as fever, joint pain, and fatigue due to the infection, which took five months to diagnose after she visited an emergency room. A doctor suggested she might have contracted the disease after being bitten by a tick, but initially dismissed her concerns. Now recovering, Lavigne credits her fans' support and her husband Chad Kroeger's help in taking care of her during her illness.

In August 2013, a fire broke out at the Virgin Mary Church in the Giza province village of Kafr Hakim, Egypt, resulting in the deaths of several people and the destruction of the building. A total of 71 individuals were sentenced to life in prison for their involvement in the attack, with 52 of them receiving sentences in absentia. Many others, including children, were also punished with fines and imprisonment. The incident was linked to the rise of the Muslim Brotherhood, which had supported President Mohamed Morsi before his ousting.

Two 18-year-old men, Sevdet Besim and two others, aged 19, have been charged with conspiring to carry out an ISIS-inspired terror plot in Australia. The suspects planned to target a major national commemoration event, including a ceremony honoring the soldiers who died in the Gallipoli Campaign in World War I, which is scheduled for April 25. The plot allegedly involved attacks against police officers. Sevdet Besim has been charged with conspiring to commit terrorist acts, while the other two men have been accused of conspiring to do so.

Carles N'Zogbia wore a flamboyant outfit to Aston Villa training, which included a gilet and sunglasses, prompting criticism from Tim Sherwood, who described it as the "worst ever". This comes after N'Zogbia joined the club in February. Sherwood, who also wore a gilet during his tenure as Tottenham manager, has been known for his bold fashion choices. N'Zogbia has become accustomed to wearing flashy outfits, having previously worn a camouflage jump suit. The incident occurred during a training session at Villa's Bodymoor Heath complex.

The British photographer Laura Stevens created a photography series "Another November" capturing the stages of grief following a breakup through posed photographs of women undergoing various emotional and physical transformations. The series, inspired by her own painful break-up, features women posing in intimate settings, showcasing feelings of pain, confusion, and loneliness. Each photograph is titled after the first name of the woman, creating a sense of intimacy and connection between the subjects. Through this project, Stevens aimed to process her emotions and gain insight into the healing process, ultimately revealing the complexities of love and loss.

Andy Murray, the British tennis player, had a nervous moment during his wedding rehearsal, where he ran through the ceremony with his fiancée Kim Sears. The couple met while playing at the 2005 US Open and got engaged last year, and they tied the knot in their hometown of Dunblane Cathedral on Saturday. After a brief separation, they reunited and planned to spend time together before their wedding. A surprise visit from sports coach Jonas Bjorkman added to the excitement, and the newlyweds will celebrate with homemade decorations and a special ceremony.

A female Pennsylvania police officer, Officer Lisa Mearkle, is charged with murder in connection with the fatal shooting of David Kassick, a 59-year-old man who was unarmed. Video footage of the incident shows Mearkle shooting two bullets into Kassick's back as he lay face down on the ground, which prosecutors claim is the strongest evidence in the case. Mearkle claims she shot Kassick in self-defense after he reached for a gun, despite being unarmed himself. The prosecution argues that the video makes it clear that Mearkle intended to kill Kassick, and that she should be charged with felony first-degree murder.

Mick Schumacher, the 16-year-old son of seven-time Formula 1 World Champion Michael Schumacher, made his Formula 4 debut at the Oschersleben circuit in Germany, where he was involved in an accidental 100mph crash. The incident occurred during a pre-season test session, and although it was minor, he walked away uninjured. Mick Schumacher's father, Michael, also a seven-time Formula 1 World Champion, is recovering from a previous skiing accident. Mick Schumacher finished second in the German Formula 4 championship last season and signed a contract with Van Amersfoort Racing to compete in the series.

Bruce Jenner, a 65-year-old Olympic gold medalist, is transitioning into a woman in an upcoming eight-episode docu-series on E!. His children, including stepdaughter Kim Kardashian, are reportedly worried about the potential impact on his public image and are urging him to slow down on sharing his journey. The series follows Bruce's transition, which he hopes will educate and inspire others, and features never-before-seen footage from a tell-all interview with Diane Sawyer. Bruce's family members, including his eldest daughter Casey and stepson Brody, are also involved in the project. The series aims to showcase Bruce's courage and commitment to being true to himself, despite facing criticism and backlash from those who may not support his transition.

The RSPCA is considering abandoning its policy of pursuing pointless fox hunting prosecutions after dropping a high-profile case involving William Bryer, a joint master of the Cattistock Hunt in Dorset. The charity had previously spent £22.5 million pursuing prosecutions under the Hunting Act, but has since reviewed its approach and may return to focusing solely on rescuing and rehabilitating animals rather than pursuing those involved in hunting. Critics argue that many individuals who engage in hunting are prosecuted under the law for poaching offenses, rather than fox hunting itself, and that the RSPCA should instead work with the police and Crown Prosecution Service to address the issue. The organization has no current hunt cases pending, but will reassess its stance on hunting after the case against Bryer comes to a close.

A former police officer, Darren Stanton, claims that liars often stare, contrary to the traditional saying that they cannot meet the eye. As the UK's top human lie detector and body expert, Stanton uses advanced techniques such as micro-expression training and neuro linguistic programming to detect deception. His methods show that people often exhibit certain physical cues, including twitching, blinking, and facial expressions, which can indicate dishonesty. Stanton's expertise has been showcased on TV shows, including ITV's This Morning, where he revealed that even celebrities like Amanda Holden and Philip Schofield had been caught fibbing.

The author discusses the significance of Easter, a Christian holiday that marks the culmination of Holy Week, which includes Good Friday, Holy Saturday, and Easter Sunday. These three days are significant because they represent a journey through the human condition, from darkness and suffering to hope and transformation. The author notes that Easter is not just a celebration of Jesus' resurrection, but also a reminder of the universal human experience of suffering and mortality. The Triduum, a term referring to the three days of Easter, represents a pattern of spiritual growth and transformation that occurs throughout the year, rather than just once a year. Ultimately, Easter is a call to move through darkness into light, embracing the mystery of transformation and renewal that lies at the heart of the Christian faith.

A new app called Camoji allows users to create and share animated GIFs on Facebook Messenger, using the platform's camera and editing capabilities. The app uses the Messenger service, which has over 600 million monthly active users, and integrates with popular messaging apps like WhatsApp and iMessage. Camoji lets users create GIFs with unique filters and text, and share them directly through Messenger. The app aims to transform Facebook's messaging service by providing a new way for users to express themselves and connect with others. With the introduction of Camoji, Facebook is expanding its offerings beyond its core social networking service.

Labour leader Ed Miliband has warned that everyone coming to Britain should learn to speak English, admitting that his party made mistakes on immigration in the past. He proposed a crackdown on illegal exploitation of migrant workers, with a new task force and increased prosecutions and fines for bad employers. However, Conservative immigration minister James Brokenshire dismissed these proposals, saying nothing Ed Miliband is proposing would help control immigration. Labour leader Ed Miliband acknowledged that his party's approach to immigration has driven low-skilled migration, while admitting that migrants must learn to use English to coexist with British communities.

Four terrified puppies were rescued after being strapped in a cage to the roof of a van on the freeway in Ohio. Wendell Steiner, a father of four, was stopped by police in Akron, Ohio, along with his wife and four children, due to concerns about animal welfare. The puppies belonged to Steiner, who claimed they were being transported to his wife's family in Pennsylvania due to his father's inability to care for them. The puppies were found to be traumatized but unharmed, and were taken to a local veterinarian hospital for examination and adoption.

British gymnast Louis Smith will represent Great Britain for the first time since his double Olympic medal-winning performance at London 2012. He was selected to compete in the European Championships, where he will face other top athletes such as reigning pommel horse champion Max Whitlock and Olympic team-mates Kristian Thomas, Sam Oldham, and Daniel Purvis. This marks a return to competition for Smith, who won silver and bronze at the 2012 Olympics. The European Championships take place from April 15 to 19.

Mohammed Dahbi, a New York taxi driver, was ordered to pay $10,000 in damages to a lesbian couple after he discriminated against them by telling them to stop kissing in the back of his cab. The incident occurred on September 18, 2011, when Dahbi ordered the couple to "keep that behavior for the bedroom" and threatened to throw them out if they didn't comply. The couple, Kassie Thornton and Christy Spitzer, reported the incident to the city's Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings, who found in their favor and ordered Dahbi to pay a $5,000 civil penalty. Dahbi denied any wrongdoing, claiming he had a "standard of decency," but was ultimately forced to pay the fine and attend anti-discrimination training.

Jonas Gutierrez, a 31-year-old midfielder, was dropped from Newcastle's starting lineup after a heated argument with head coach John Carver, who stated that he wanted to "treat" him poorly. Gutierrez had previously expressed frustration over being omitted from the team against Tottenham, tweeting that he was "tired about some things". Despite returning to form in recent games, including a goal against Swansea, Gutierrez was ultimately released by the club due to his poor treatment by Carver. His contract expires in the summer, and although he may still have options to join another team, he will not be offered a new deal.

ISIS militants infiltrated the Palestinian-run Yarmouk refugee camp in Damascus, killing a blindfolded and bound couple in a gruesome display of violence. The militants, affiliated with Al Qaeda, used stones to kill the couple, who were accused of "fornication", while standing in a crowded area. This marked the latest escalation of ISIS's presence in Syria, following clashes with government forces and rival groups. The incident occurred just days after Jordan closed its border with Syria due to clashes between rebels and government forces.

Amanda Peake Glover, a devoted mother of four, died suddenly after collapsing during the Palmetto Half Marathon in South Carolina. She was a fitness enthusiast and had recently completed the Myrtle Beach Marathon with her brother. Her friend Ashley Blocker described her as a "devoted" mother who was known for holding her family close. The cause of her death remains unclear, but it was reported that she collapsed shortly after crossing the finish line.

Labour's shadow chancellor Ed Balls was left briefly stumped when asked to calculate seven times six during a Q&A session in Leeds. The question was part of a routine maths test, but Balls' nervous laughter and subsequent pause led to speculation about his reliance on his mother-in-law for help with maths. This is not the first time Balls has faced maths questions on live TV, having also struggled with a similar question on Good Morning Britain earlier this year. His response, "the answer is 42", was met with amusement from host Susanna Reid.

Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott have formed a notable partnership of six times, scoring over 100 runs together, while also representing England as a captain. Their most recent partnership came in 2009, and they were joined by other notable figures such as Jonathan Trott and Michael Pietersen. In contrast, West Indies' Shannon Gabriel has been instrumental in keeping England's batsmen on their toes with his blistering speed, reaching 94.3mph. Meanwhile, England captain Alastair Cook has had a successful career, forming partnerships with several key players, including Jonathan Trott and Michael Pietersen.

A New York City skin clinic called Skin Laundry offers a popular laser treatment that promises to tighten skin and improve complexion after just 10 minutes. The treatment involves a two-step process, where a nurse applies gel and then a pulsed light to the skin, leaving it feeling "glowing" and reducing wrinkles, acne, and scarring. Clients must sign a waiver releasing their personal information to a funeral director and coroner, but claim that the risk of serious side effects is low. Despite concerns, the clinic has gained popularity among clients, with many reporting positive results and a loyal customer base.

Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao's highly anticipated boxing match has seen its tickets sell out quickly, with over 10,000 tickets available for the event. The fight took place earlier today, but the MGM property box offices reported that the tickets had gone on sale just minutes after they went live, with some tickets selling for as much as $7,500. The event featured a weigh-in, where both fighters weighed in together, and a number of super-ringside tickets were also available for purchase. The sale was facilitated through various online platforms, including Ticketmaster and StubHub, with prices ranging from £1,000 to £85,000.

Victoria's Secret Angel Alessandra Ambrosio, 34, is recovering at UCLA Hospital in Los Angeles after undergoing a medical procedure for "constant headaches" while attending the Coachella festival in California. She was seen partying with friends, including fellow model Kylie Jenner, before suddenly falling ill. Ambrosio had previously booked the appointment two weeks prior to the event. The supermodel is currently receiving treatment at the Ronald Reagan Medical Center.

A rowing team from Oxford University Women's Boat Race faced rescue by the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) after being swept away by strong winds and waves while training on the Thames. The team, consisting of women, were returning to their base when they became stranded. The RNLI responded quickly to assist, using its lifeboats to recover the stricken vessel. The incident occurred during the Oxford University Women's Boat Race, which takes place on April 11. The RNLI also participated in the Alternative Boat Race fundraising event on April 10, which drew thousands of spectators.

Lionel Messi has been lauded by Paris Saint-Germain playmaker Lucas Moura as one of the greatest players in the world, praising his exceptional skill and technique. Moura has expressed admiration for Messi's ability to dominate games and single-mindedly focus on his craft. The two South Americans come from rival nations, but Moura sees Messi as the best player in the world, while also acknowledging the importance of respecting opponents like Barcelona. The Paris Saint-Germain team faces off against Barcelona in the Champions League on Wednesday, with Moura vowing to put aside any pre-match rivalry to give them the best chance of success.

Zayn Malik's personal life has been under intense scrutiny due to multiple cheating allegations against him, including those involving Swedish model Martina Olsson, who claimed he cheated on his fiancée Perrie Edwards during a trip to Thailand. The allegations are similar to those leveled against Ashley Cole, a former footballer who was accused of cheating on his wife Cheryl in the early 2000s. Zayn has previously denied the allegations, stating that he loves Perrie and apologizing for any perceived betrayal. The situation has led to concerns about Zayn's character and whether he can maintain trust in his relationships.

A recent surge in "religious freedom" bills in Arkansas and Indiana has sparked widespread outrage, prompting surprise reactions from governors and businesses, particularly those aligned with socially conservative values. The backlash includes boycotts and threats of retaliation from organizations like the National Collegiate Athletic Association, Walmart, and Marriott International, which has launched a "#Love Travels" campaign to attract LGBTQ+ travelers. Despite initial opposition from some Christian leaders, a CNN poll shows that 72% of millennials support same-sex marriage, and 90% of young people under 24 agree that making their community a less biased place is essential. This shift in public opinion suggests that intolerance towards diversity is no longer a viable business strategy, and that promoting inclusivity and respect can be a lucrative one.

Jake Hall scored a crucial goal for Boston United, impressing his girlfriend Chloe Lewis in attendance at the match. On-screen partner James "Arg" Argent was also in the crowd, cheering him on. Hall's girlfriend Chloe Lewis was seen celebrating with him in the stands. Hall scored Boston's second goal, putting the pressure on Tamworth to lose, but ultimately securing a 2-0 win for the Pilgrims. Hall's impressive performance earned him praise from both his on-screen girlfriend and fellow TOWIE star James "Arg" Argent.

A US-led effort to combat ISIS is supplementing military training efforts with foreign volunteers, including Canadians and Americans, to bolster Kurdish forces in Iraq and Syria. These individuals are part of a larger effort to provide training and support to local militias, with the goal of countering ISIS' expansionist regime. Foreign fighters are completing training programs, while others are volunteering to serve alongside Iraqi and Kurdish troops. The US military believes that these external contributions will enhance their effectiveness in the fight against ISIS, particularly in the region where sectarian divisions are already playing a major role. The international community is divided on whether to intervene militarily, but the focus remains on providing non-combat support to those fighting against ISIS.

A British soldier, Sergeant Norman Turgel, met a teenage Polish girl, Gena, during the liberation of Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in 1945. Despite being separated due to the dangers of the situation, they fell in love and got married shortly after the camp was liberated. However, their happiness was short-lived as Major Leonard Berney, the commanding officer of the camp, intervened and helped them rekindle their romance. The couple eventually married and had three children, but Norman died two months shy of their golden wedding anniversary.

In Gorkha, Nepal, a town northwest of Kathmandu, a devastating earthquake has caused widespread destruction, with only 10 collapsed or severely damaged houses out of approximately 200,000 residents. The hospital in Gorkha is overcrowded with injured patients, many of whom require immediate attention due to severe injuries, including broken legs and spinal cord damage. Medical teams from various countries, including Switzerland, Denmark, and Germany, are working together to provide aid and treatment, with a focus on supporting mothers and children. The hospital's emergency room is equipped to handle the influx of patients, while others receive necessary first aid and are then transferred to larger hospitals in Kathmandu or other nearby districts. The humanitarian efforts aim to alleviate the suffering of those affected by the disaster.

Australian drug smugglers Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, part of the so-called Bali Nine, have been sentenced to death for their role in a failed heroin smuggling plot. The pair, along with six others, were arrested in Indonesia and charged with trafficking over 8 kilograms of heroin. One member, Renae Lawrence, a 37-year-old woman, was sentenced to 20 years in prison after claiming she was forced to participate in the scheme due to death threats. Chan, who was sentenced to life in prison, had previously denied making threats against Lawrence during his own trial.

A recent study suggests that the Earth may have collided with a body similar to the planet Mercury, potentially explaining the presence of a hot core and unusual elemental ratios in the planet's mantle. The collision, which occurred around 4.5 billion years ago, would have generated heat and created the Earth's core, as well as producing the moon through a process involving radioactive decay. Researchers propose that a Mars-sized body, possibly composed of sulfur-rich material, struck the Earth, leading to the formation of the moon. This theory challenges the traditional understanding of Earth's formation and raises questions about how the planet ended up in its current state.

Daniel Ricciardo practiced with a martial artist at Guyi Garden ahead of the Chinese Grand Prix, seeking to improve his stance and prepare for the upcoming race. Despite struggling to find the perfect form, Ricciardo seems determined to bounce back from a disappointing season where he finished sixth in Australia and tenth in Malaysia. Red Bull's struggles continue, with the team falling behind Ferrari in the championship standings. Ricciardo's efforts to master a martial art technique may provide an unexpected boost to his performance, but he still faces stiff competition from rival drivers such as Sebastian Vettel and Nico Rosberg. This weekend's Chinese Grand Prix marks a crucial test for both Ricciardo and Red Bull as they seek to stop their slide down the grid.

A drone carrying small traces of radioactive material landed on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's office in Tokyo, sparking concerns about nuclear safety. The drone, estimated to be 4 inches wide, was discovered by a member of the Prime Minister's staff while inspecting the roof. The drone contained a small amount of radioactive cesium, a harmless metal to humans, and was later removed. The incident has raised questions about the use of drones in Japan, where there are growing concerns about nuclear power plants and the potential risks associated with them.

ISIS is a complex and multifaceted terrorist organization that presents itself as a global entity, but is ultimately driven by a desire for power and control. Its message is rooted in a radical interpretation of Islam, but its actions are guided by a lust for dominance over others, particularly in Iraq and Syria. Despite being defeated in several battles, ISIS continues to thrive due to its ability to spread its influence through social media and online platforms. The group's ultimate goal is to establish a caliphate in Iraq and Syria, and it sees the US as a major obstacle to achieving this goal.

A group of British politicians participated in a televised debate, featuring Prime Minister David Cameron, Labour leader Ed Miliband, and others. The event included a humorous twist where they were superimposed onto characters from popular culture, such as David Cameron being sat on the Gogglebox sofa and Ed Miliband posing as Kate Winslet in Titanic. The debate itself focused on leadership, with Labour leader Ed Miliband calling out Prime Minister David Cameron for not engaging in a direct conversation. The event was notable for its use of memes and references to popular culture, particularly those involving the Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon and the rapper Plan B.

Manchester City fans were ejected from Old Trafford for allegedly mocking the Munich Air Disaster during a 4-2 derby defeat to Manchester United. The incident occurred after a scuffle broke out between rival fans outside the stadium, with some visitors accused of making airplane wings in a reference to the 1958 crash. Former Manchester City goalkeeper Frank Swift was among those killed in the disaster, while many fans were also arrested for various offenses, including public order and disorderly conduct. The majority of fans were praised for their behavior, with police hailing them as having made the match "a safe and enjoyable environment".

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has hinted that the club may look to buy English players to meet the Premier League's homegrown quota requirement, as his own academy players are not yet ready to step into the first team. Pellegrini's comments may lead to James Milner potentially leaving the club, while striker Raheem Sterling is also open to discussing a new contract. The situation is complicated by the fact that City's current homegrown players, such as Patrick Vieira and John Guidetti, may be sold or released before the summer break. Pellegrini has expressed confidence that City will find ways to meet the quota despite the challenges posed by the lack of productivity in their youth system.

A 28-year-old heavily pregnant Jehovah's Witness, Jenny-Lee, refused a blood transfusion during childbirth despite medical advice, leading to the death of her unborn baby, Aroura. The baby died just three days after birth due to complications related to the pregnancy and its complications. Jenny-Lee's refusal of the blood transfusion was motivated by her strong adherence to her faith, which prohibits consuming blood. Her mother, Heather, believes that Jenny-Lee prioritized her own life over that of her unborn child. The incident highlights the challenges faced by women who choose to follow certain religious beliefs, particularly those regarding blood transfusions.

A Muslim father, Mohammad Liaqat, launched a racist tirade against Xavier Bowers, the headteacher of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic High School in Accrington, after two teenage pupils were banned from attending due to their refusal to shave their beards. Liaqat, who also assaulted the headteacher, was arrested and charged with assault and racially aggravated behavior. The incident occurred when Liaqat stormed into the school, shouting racist insults at staff and physically attacking them, despite being told that beards were not allowed. Two teenage pupils were subsequently banned from the school, while Liaqat was later charged with assault and sentenced to prison.

Chinese authorities have arrested over 133,000 people and seized 43.3 tons of illegal narcotics during a six-month anti-drug campaign, with 115,000 drug-related crimes being handled. The crackdown targeted both traditional and online drug trafficking, resulting in 606,000 cases of drug use. A total of 137,000 people were arrested for drug offenses, including those involved in online drug trafficking. The government has also banned drug use in hundreds of cities and charged several high-profile celebrities, including Jaycee Chan, son of Jackie Chan, with drug charges.

A new species of glass frog, Hyalinobatrachium dianae, has been discovered in eastern Costa Rica, characterized by its translucent skin and distinctive call. The frog's heart and internal organs are visible due to its transparent skin, unlike other glass frogs whose skin is opaque. The species was named after its discoverer, Brian Kubicki, and is distinct from other glass frogs due to its black and white eyes and long, thin feet. Researchers believe the frog's unique characteristics make it a potential candidate for use as an aphrodisiac, with studies showing that a supplement added to water can increase reproduction in various aquatic animals.

Prince William, Duke of Cambridge, has returned to Kensington Palace to prepare for the upcoming birth of his second child, following a weekend trip to his family's farm in Berkshire. The couple, along with Prince Harry, will spend the next six weeks' paternity leave around the birth of their new baby. Prince William, who completed his air ambulance pilot training early, will take unpaid leave until June 1, while Prince Harry will return to the UK to present the winners' medals at the London Marathon and meet his new niece or nephew. The couple's eldest son, Prince George, is set to welcome a new sibling, and the family will reunite at Kensington Palace.

Maurice Thibaux, a 67-year-old neighbor of the Carriageworks venue, stormed onto the catwalk during Sydney's Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, claiming the noise from the music was similar to a jumbo jet taking off. The French native was escorted off the runway by security guards after making a complaint about the disturbance. The incident occurred during the opening show of the fashion week, which featured Australian fashion designer Kym Ellery. The noise was described as "disgraceful" by eyewitnesses, who noted that the music was "way too loud".

FBI agents are undergoing compulsory fitness tests due to concerns over their declining physical fitness, with 135,000 agents facing the possibility of having their performance reviews marked if they fail. The tests include running a mile in 12.5 minutes, sprinting 300 meters in 59 seconds, performing 24 push-ups without stopping, and 35 sit-ups in a minute. The tests aim to assess agents' ability to 'run, fight, and shoot', with older agents receiving longer times. The move follows fears among some agents that their increasing size and sedentary lifestyle are putting them at risk of failing the tests.

A volcano in Chile's south, known as Calbuco, erupted suddenly and violently, forcing 1,500 people to flee their homes due to a massive ash cloud and pyroclastic flows. This makes it one of the three most dangerous volcanoes in Chile, along with Villarrica and Calbuco. The eruption occurred without warning, sparking a red alert in the surrounding areas, and prompted evacuation orders for thousands of people. The volcano is part of a chain of over 500 active volcanoes in Chile, and its last major eruption occurred in 1961. The eruption caused widespread destruction and panic among those affected, with many fleeing their homes and seeking shelter elsewhere.

Prime Minister David Cameron defended the Church of England against accusations of dismissing welfare policies as "game-playing" and criticized the idea that the church is dismissive of those struggling financially. The Church published a guide to its approach to the upcoming general election, which some saw as indirectly criticizing the Coalition's welfare policies. The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, called the policies "game-playing", while the Prime Minister argued that the church's values align with those of the UK. The Conservative Party is facing a tight election campaign, with polls suggesting that Labour may gain ground.

A man named Freddie Gray died in police custody after being arrested in Baltimore, sparking protests and calls for justice. A police chase ensued, during which Gray was injured and eventually died from a severe spinal cord injury. Protesters claim that police used excessive force during the arrest, citing a Supreme Court ruling that allows officers to make arrests without probable cause. The police union disputes this, saying that officers acted within their authority and that the situation was handled properly. The US Justice Department is investigating the incident, and several officers involved have been suspended with pay.

A 33-year-old airport worker, Brandon Afoa, was awarded $40 million in compensation after a freak runway accident left him paralyzed from the waist down. The accident occurred on December 26, 2007, while Afoa was working at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, where he was pushing a luggage lift. Afoa sued the Port of Seattle, claiming the company failed to maintain a safe working environment due to inadequate maintenance of the equipment. The court ultimately found the Port of Seattle liable for the accident and awarded Afoa $40 million in damages.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is set to meet with Sir Alex Ferguson, who has expressed interest in discussing progress with the team. Van Gaal hopes to have tangible results after Manchester United's recent wins over Tottenham and Liverpool, which have left both teams struggling. The Premier League table is becoming increasingly competitive, with Manchester City potentially taking advantage of Manchester United's struggles, and Arsenal facing a tough test against Liverpool. Van Gaal believes United can still challenge for the title, but acknowledges that the competition is fierce and that the team needs to improve quickly.

A passenger at Newcastle Airport was detained after airport staff thought his pease pudding was Semtex, a type of plastic explosive. The passenger, a part-time actor, had six tubs of traditional pease pudding in his hand luggage, which included several Greggs pies. Staff initially thought the pudding was Semtex due to its shape and containers, but the passenger admitted he was carrying the pudding for personal use. He was allowed to continue his journey after offering to test the pudding to prove it wasn't Semtex.

The West Indies cricket team has announced its 14-man squad for the upcoming three-match Test series against England. Jason Holder will lead the team, while Denesh Ramdin will take over as captain after being named in the squad. The uncapped duo of Shai Hope and Carlos Brathwaite have been retained, along with other key players such as Sheldon Cottrell, Miguel Cummins, and Veerasammy Permaul. The series begins in Antigua on Monday, with Denesh Ramdin set to captain the team alongside Kraigg Brathwaite. The 21-year-old wicketkeeper-batsman Shai Hope and 17-year-old pace bowler Carlos Brathwaite have been added to the squad.

A 27-year-old sex trade worker, Rejean Hermel Perron, was accused of holding a woman captive for five days and subjecting her to multiple sexual assaults, including "ritualistic actions", while she was restrained with duct tape and handcuffs. The woman was found naked and in handcuffs outside her home, where she had been held against her will. Police believe there may be additional victims who have yet to come forward. Perron was arrested and charged with various crimes, including sexual assault with a weapon, kidnapping, and assault. The incident occurred in the Sherbourne and Shuter Street area of Toronto, Canada.

A controversy erupted between the Liberal Democrats and the Conservatives over claims that David Cameron is planning to slash support for families through secret plans to cut Child Benefit and Child Tax Credits. The plans, allegedly drawn up in the last government, include limiting the amount of money available to families to £3,500 per child, with some families potentially losing up to £1,500. The Lib Dems have vowed to block the plan, citing concerns that it would disproportionately affect vulnerable families. The Tories have denied the allegations, claiming that the plans were drawn up by civil servants on the orders of the Prime Minister, David Cameron.

Sergio Garcia is focusing on winning his first PGA Tour title since 2012 at the Shell Houston Open, despite the Masters being near. He hopes to capitalize on the momentum from last year's Open, where he finished second, and the upcoming Masters, which could be his last chance to win a major before hanging up his golf clubs. Garcia played comfortably at the tournament, having won the previous year's Open, and is determined to repeat his success. With Rory McIlroy's bid for a third major victory in succession dominating the headlines, Garcia is prioritizing his own goal. The tournament will serve as a test of his ability to perform under pressure, particularly against the likes of Tiger Woods, who is seeking to end his self-imposed exile from the sport.

In Nepal, a group of pranksters filmed an internet comedy series while on location for a video shoot, but their plans were disrupted by a magnitude-7.8 earthquake that struck the country. The quake caused widespread destruction and chaos, but the pranksters managed to capture footage despite being in the midst of the disaster. Their hidden camera series documented the aftermath, including scenes of heroism and destruction at Nepal's famous Central Zoo. The earthquake also brought out the resilience of the Nepali people, who were seen crawling through rubble and helping each other after the disaster.

Max Azria's 30,000 sq ft Los Angeles mansion features a stunning 2-story-tall chandelier, 17 bedrooms, and 60 rooms to explore, including a private movie theater, guesthouse, and 6,000 sq ft movie theater with popcorn and snack bar. The property boasts a unique blend of French, Japanese, English, Moroccan, and herb gardens, as well as a private tennis court with its own viewing box and a zero-edged swimming pool. The mansion was built in 1939 by architect Paul Williams and was once owned by TV writer and novelist Sidney Sheldon before being purchased by Max Azria in 2005. The property is part of the Platinum Triangle neighborhood in Holmby Hills and features a luxurious interior design, including a domed gold-leaf ceiling and one-of-a-kind lighting fixtures throughout.

A 50-year-old woman, Mei Ru, and her husband, Song Ming, 53, were involved in a fatal car accident in Fuzhou, Fujian province, China, after Mei Ru's husband climbed out of the car while she was parking and reversed over him. The incident occurred on a busy street in front of a supermarket. Mei Ru was reportedly hysterical and begged her husband to wake up, but he was pronounced dead at the hospital due to massive internal bleeding and broken ribs. The driver of the car, who was not identified, was also injured but survived.

NBC News chief foreign correspondent Richard Engel was taken captive in Syria in 2012, along with Turkish reporter Aziz Akyavas and photographer John Kooistra, and was initially believed to be held by forces affiliated with President Bashar al-Assad. However, Engel later revealed that the group that kidnapped them was a Sunni rebel group, and that they were likely taken for propaganda purposes rather than being held by government forces. The incident occurred near Ma-arrat Misrin, and Engel reported experiencing extreme physical and psychological trauma during his five-day captivity, including hearing gunfire and seeing a dead body. In 2019, Engel confirmed that the kidnapping was staged to create a dramatic narrative, and that he was not actually held by the Syrian government.

Lidia Quilligana, a nanny from Connecticut, was arrested and charged with first-degree assault of a child under 10 years old and criminal mischief after a video surfaced showing her allegedly beating a 3-year-old girl. The incident occurred when the family installed a nanny cam to monitor the child's well-being, which captured footage of Quilligana choking and burning the girl's legs, arms, and hands on a hot stove. The video was obtained by police, who described it as "the worst video" they have ever seen. Quilligana claims she knew she was being filmed and denies all allegations.

Michelle Obama gave a surprise hug to a 7-year-old girl named Anya Brodie during an event where they discussed parenting and family life. An 8-year-old girl complimented Mrs. Obama with "you're too young" for being 51, prompting Obama to ask her to repeat the comment. The exchange left the audience in stitches as Obama laughed and said "say that again," and then gave the little girl a big hug. The event featured many other children and adults who attended, including those from the White House staff, the Boys and Girls Club, and local organizations serving families in need.

Philip Garrod, a 43-year-old paramedic, was caught speeding on his powerful Suzuki motorbike at 105mph on a speed camera in Wales. He lied about a colleague contacting him to claim a cyclist was injured on the A470, which led to a disciplinary hearing where he was found guilty of misconduct. Garrod claimed he was rushing to work, but was later found to have falsified documents and provided false information. As a result, he was struck off the workforce due to his dishonest behavior.

Vin Los, a 24-year-old Canadian model, has gained attention for his 24 body tattoos, including a Sharpie-like design on his face, neck, arms, and torso. Despite initial skepticism about his career prospects due to his unusual appearance, Vin has successfully modeled for brands such as Garçon Model and has appeared in campaigns featuring his extensive body art. His tattoos, including the phrase "fame" on his forehead, have become a defining aspect of his identity and persona. Vin's unique look has led to opportunities in various fields, including modeling, writing, and even designing wallets.

Sir Stirling Moss, widely regarded as the greatest all-round racer of all time, has revealed his unusual daily routine at 85, which includes 77 press-ups and half a bottle of Chardonnay per day. He drives a tiny electric car, the Renault Twizy, which he uses for recreational purposes, swapping it for a refurbished Austin-Healey Sprite after a crash at Goodwood in 1962. Moss won 212 races in his 14-year career, including the 1962 Sebring three-hour race, and has been married to his third wife, Lady Susan Moss, since 1980. Despite being knighted in 2000, Moss feels that professional racing is becoming increasingly rare and prefers to focus on his personal life and hobbies.

Taylor Lynn Fast, 21, was arrested and charged with endangering the welfare of a child after her 16-month-old daughter Layla was found beaten to death at their home in Festus, Missouri. The baby had severe injuries, including bruises and a broken neck, and was pronounced dead shortly after arrival at the hospital. Fast allegedly claimed a spider bite caused the injuries, despite paramedics describing them as similar to those of a car crash victim. Her boyfriend, who is still at large, is also being sought by authorities.

Officer Jared Forsyth, a 33-year-old member of the Ocala Police Department, was accidentally shot while participating in firearms training at the Lowell Correctional Institution's gun range. He was wearing a bulletproof vest but suffered fatal injuries when a round entered his arm and went through his chest. Forsyth was rushed to the hospital in critical condition and underwent surgery, but unfortunately, he died shortly thereafter. The incident is currently being investigated by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement.
