The church has been the subject of controversy over the years due to allegations of child abuse linked to the church's former pastor, Ronald Pickering.

Shaquille Omar Hallisey, a 20-year-old from Cardiff, attacked a 38-year-old victim, Matthew Leeke, over the head with a bottle, fracturing his skull. Hallisey pleaded guilty to wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm and was sentenced to four years in prison. Leeke suffered serious injuries, including cuts to his back and forehead, and was left with a fractured skull. Hallisey's guilty plea came after a lengthy investigation, and he expressed remorse for his actions, stating he would not return to court again.

A recent survey found that many pets enjoy watching TV, particularly dogs, who spend an average of 3 hours a day watching their favorite programs. Pigs also have a strong affinity for TV, with 28 hours spent watching per week. In contrast, humans tend to prefer reality shows like "Keeping Up With The Kardashians" and "TOWIE", but these preferences vary greatly among different species. Overall, pets seem to be drawn to programming that features other animals, with natural documentaries being a clear favorite among both dog and pig owners.

Four sisters, Claire, Emily, Christine, and Lily Vincenti, were separated from their mother, Laura Garrett, due to allegations of abuse by their father, Tomaso Vincenti, and were taken to Australia without their consent. They later returned to Italy, where they lived with their father, Tomaso, and spoke to 60 Minutes about their experiences. The sisters, now aged 16 and 17, express regret over the way they handled the situation, feeling that they were "a little bit selfish" and prioritized their own lives. They have since spoken positively about their new life in Italy, where they attend school and spend time with their father.

Mary Kay Letourneau, a former teacher, and her husband Vili Fualaau, whom she met in her second-grade class, began a romantic relationship when she was 32 and he was 12. Their relationship led to a highly publicized affair, resulting in Letourneau giving birth to their two daughters, Audrey and Georgia, while she was in prison for the crime. The couple got married in 2004 and have been together ever since. After Letourneau's release from prison, the couple reunited and appeared on Barbara Walters' show, discussing their tumultuous past and their decision to stay together despite the challenges.

Carl Froch is expected to return to the ring after a year-long layoff, with three potential opponents lined up for him in the next two months. Froch, who weighed in at 12st 7lbs, has been training hard and is eager to regain his form. His next fight could be against Anthony Dirrell or James DeGale, both of whom are highly regarded boxers. Froch's team has reportedly rejected a bid from Anthony Frampton to fight him, while Anthony Joshua is set to face Rafael Zumbano Love in May.

Annabel Beam, a 12-year-old girl, survived a 30ft fall from a hollowed-out tree while unconscious, but miraculously escaped with only minor injuries. Her mother, Christy Beam, 42, believes Annabel's experience was a spiritual encounter with Jesus Christ, which led to her recovery. Annabel's mother says her daughter believes she went to heaven and sat in Jesus's lap during the fall, describing a peaceful and serene scene. Annabel's survival and miraculous recovery have left her family stunned and believing that Jesus intervened to save her life.

Three cars were vandalized in the Richard Dunn Sports Centre car park in Bradford after a match between Bradford Bulls and Hull KR. The incident occurred on Sunday, resulting in damage to vehicles. The Bulls are investigating the matter and appealing for witnesses. This is not the first time there have been reported incidents of vandalism in the area. The team has promised to work with authorities to improve security measures in the car park.

A dispute over legroom on a flight from London Heathrow to Oman resulted in a brawl on Oman Air Flight 102, which landed safely at Muscat International Airport. The incident occurred after one passenger allegedly attacked another with a shoe, prompting a row among passengers. The situation escalated further when a third passenger joined in, leading to punches being thrown and a man being taken away for questioning by police. The flight crew intervened and managed to calm the situation, and all passengers were eventually questioned by authorities.

A US Navy helicopter, carrying an armed MH-60R aircraft, was flown within 50 yards of an Iranian observation aircraft over the Persian Gulf, prompting concerns about Iranian control. The incident occurred while the US was negotiating a deal with Iran to limit its nuclear program. The observation aircraft made two passes at the US helicopter, but the US Navy intervened, breaking off contact and flying away. The incident has raised questions about whether the Iranian military was acting independently or under orders from a superior commander. The US military is considering a possible protest against Iran due to the close proximity of the two aircraft.

A survey found that the "perfect" dog is a hybrid of various breeds, including an English bulldog, King Charles spaniel, Irish setter, and Labrador, with a mix of characteristics such as a short, low-maintenance coat, floppy ears, and a rounded snout. The survey also revealed that 41% of respondents preferred small dogs, particularly those from London, while 19% chose Great Danes from East Anglia. In contrast, 29% opted for human-like names, such as Dave or Lucy, and 33% preferred traditional dog names like Rover and Bailey. The survey highlighted regional preferences, with Londoners favoring small dogs and East Anglians preferring Great Danes.

Scottish soldiers, Jason Collins, 22, and Shaun Smith, 25, were convicted of kicking and punching a civilian, James Wormald, 25, near their barracks in North Yorkshire. Collins was found guilty of two counts of occasioning actual bodily harm, while Smith was found guilty of two counts of causing actual bodily harm. The pair were sentenced to 12 months suspended jail time, with Collins receiving a 12-month community order and Smith receiving a 12-month sentence suspended. Collins was also ordered to pay £1,000 compensation to Wormald.

Leicester City boss Nigel Pearson has defended his former teammate Sam Allardyce after criticizing him for his behavior during a recent incident involving Crystal Palace midfielder James McArthur. Allardyce, who managed Leicester in 2007, felt that Pearson did an "unbelievable job" despite the team's struggles in the Premier League. The two were reunited when West Ham face Leicester at the King Power Stadium, where Allardyce praised Pearson's "methods" and believed he would be frustrated about the team's lack of results. West Ham scored a 2-0 win over Leicester in December, and Allardyce hopes to end a goal drought for the team.

A 18-month-old boy and his sister drowned while playing near a canal in Yuma, Arizona, after their mother tried to fend off a bee and let go of their stroller, which rolled into the water. The toddler's mother attempted to rescue them, but was unable to retrieve them due to the steep sides of the canal and strong currents. The incident occurred on a Friday afternoon, and the boys were later found and taken to a hospital, where they were pronounced dead. Authorities attributed the tragedy to the dangers of the canal paths, which are popular for jogging and cycling, despite being hazardous.

Terry McCarty, a 29-year-old former firefighter from Hawthorne, Nevada, survived a childhood accident that left him with third-degree burns covering 70% of his body. At six years old, he was severely injured when his brothers filled a bowl with kerosene and set it on fire, causing severe burns. Despite facing cruel taunts and bullying due to his appearance, McCarty persevered and eventually became a firefighter after completing 58 operations and overcoming his fears. Now a successful firefighter, McCarty is working with the Burned Children Recovery Foundation to help others who have experienced similar traumas.

Veteran Robert Clark, a former soldier, has raised £10,000 to stay in his own home with a live-in carer due to a London council's refusal to provide funding. Despite raising £10,000, the council has stated it cannot afford to continue paying for a live-in carer, forcing the 90-year-old man to consider moving to a local care home. The council claims it wants to find a solution that meets his needs and provides value for money for taxpayers, but has already received support from a local charity, Help for Heroes, which aims to raise £15,000 to cover the cost of care. The campaign has garnered nearly 170,000 signatures and is urging the council to reconsider its decision.

A Conservative councillor in Scotland has accused "nationalists" of spraying graffiti at his office and other buildings, including Labour offices, in Aberdeen. The vandalism includes a swastika, a white "Q", and the word "scum". The incidents come six months after similar acts of vandalism occurred in the lead-up to the Scottish referendum. Police are investigating and reports suggest that the graffiti was carried out by individuals targeting both Labour and Conservative offices.

Ruslan Provodnikov lost a majority decision to Lucas Matthysse in a 12-round super lightweight bout. Despite being knocked down twice, Matthysse landed two hard right hook-left hook combos in the fourth round, regaining control and eventually winning by majority decision. Provodnikov put Matthysse on the ropes late in the third round and landed several punches in the later rounds, but couldn't knock down his opponent. Matthysse celebrated his victory with a hug with Provodnikov at the end of the fight.

Kimi Raikkonen finished his first podium finish in 26 years at the Bahrain Grand Prix, beating Lewis Hamilton to the top step of the podium. Ferrari team principal Maurizio Arrivabene believes Raikkonen's performance shows he remains committed to the team despite rumors of a potential departure. Arrivabene has stated that Raikkonen's chances of staying with Ferrari depend on his performance, but has expressed confidence in his ability to deliver results. Raikkonen's impressive showing helped Ferrari close the gap between themselves and Mercedes, who dominated the race. The win marked a significant improvement from their previous performances, particularly considering they struggled to find speed on long runs.

Jamaica tops the list as the country with the highest percentage of female bosses, with nearly 60% of managers holding this position. This is followed closely by Saint Lucia and Colombia, which have the second and third spots respectively. In contrast, Britain ranks poorly, with only 34.2% of managers being women. The global trend shows that women are increasingly taking on leadership roles in various industries, but there is still significant disparity between developed and developing regions. Overall, the report highlights the progress made towards achieving gender equality in the workplace.

A 17-year-old Australian teenager named Violeta Tupuola has joined the #kyliejennerchallenge by using a shot glass to pump up her lips to ridiculous proportions, emulating Kylie Jenner's famous plump lips. She initially tried the method, but ended up with protruding lips that caused her to compare herself to a duck on social media. The viral challenge, which encourages users to suck in air through a glass or jar to cause their lips to swell, has sparked widespread criticism and ridicule online. Many have expressed concerns about the safety and long-term effects of the method, with some reporting sore-looking red marks and discomfort.

Stuart McCall, the Ibrox manager, urged Rangers to respond immediately to their second Championship defeat of the season, despite being outplayed by Queen of the South. McCall remained defiant, saying "we've got to make sure on Sunday that we don't have another setback" and expected his players to bounce back strongly. Rangers' victory over Palmerston has boosted their play-off hopes, while also dented their confidence. McCall praised his team's performance, particularly striker Derek Lyle, who scored a goal against the Saints. The Ibrox side remains third in the table, behind Hibernian on goal difference, but ahead of Raith Rovers.

A horse named Charly was tagged with the phrase "RBS" by a vandal while patrolling Venice Beach with its minders. The act of tagging a living creature is considered cruel and disrespectful, but the LAPD hopes to identify the perpetrator through the unique signature "RBS". Authorities have received reports of the tag being sprayed on Charly's flank with silver paint, which was removed without issue. The LAPD is seeking the public's help in tracing the identity of the tagger.

Queens Park Rangers drew 3-3 with Aston Villa at Villa Park, despite trailing 2-1 at halftime. Tony Fernandes, Rangers chairman, expressed his frustration over the team throwing away the lead twice. Clint Hill scored twice for Villa, including one in the second half, while QPR's Clint Hill scored to level the score. Fernandes took to social media to express his emotions, tweeting about his experience of watching the game from afar due to his iPhone.

Tottenham's Harry Kane topped the EA Sports' Performance Index this week, scoring his 30th goal of the season in a 3-1 win over Newcastle United. He is the top scorer in the Premier League with 20 goals so far this season. Kane's teammate Christian Erisken scored a goal in the game, while Eden Hazard scored the winner for Chelsea against Manchester United. Kane's impressive form earns him the top spot in the EA Sports' Performance Index, ahead of Southampton midfielder Morgan Schneiderlin. This marks the first time Kane has been named Player of the Year nominee since the start of the season.

A father in Australia created a humorous t-shirt with a message warning boys to stay clear of his daughter, who looks unimpressed. The image, which was first posted on Reddit's "Dad" community, features the father wearing a shirt with the words "Stay Clear Boys" emblazoned across it. The post quickly went viral, garnering over 370,000 likes and 45,000 shares. Some commenters praised the father's creativity, while others ridiculed him for trying to exert control over his child.

A New York woman's body was found hanging from a fire escape in her apartment building on Sunday, leaving authorities stunned and traumatized by the discovery. The woman, whose identity has not been released, was reportedly hanging for over an hour before being rescued. Witnesses described the scene as "traumatizing" and claimed she initially thought the body was a "Halloween prank." The incident occurred on Sunday afternoon, with some witnesses believing the body was fake.

Inverness Caledonian Thistle won the Scottish Cup semi-final against Inverness, with David Raven scoring the winning goal. Celtic's actions in the Scottish Cup semi-final, including writing to the SFA complaining about a disputed penalty, sparked outrage among fans and critics. Celtic's behavior is seen as arrogant and entitled, with captain Scott Brown appealing to the referee for a penalty. The Scottish Football Association has called for greater accountability from Celtic, who have been criticized for their treatment of players and fans.

Real Madrid won their Champions League final against Atletico Madrid in Lisbon one year ago, but since then they've lost six of their last seven matches against their city rivals. This includes a 2-1 loss in the quarter-finals last week, where Fernando Torres scored twice for Atletico. In contrast, Atletico Madrid has had success against Real Madrid, having won four times in their last eight meetings. On Wednesday night's match, Real Madrid drew 0-0 with Atletico, while Atletico won 2-1. This was their third win against Real Madrid this season, and their first win in over four years.

A guest can stay on the secluded Ile Louët island in Brittany, France, for two nights for around £145, or rent a 19th-century lighthouse cottage for up to 10 guests for approximately £200. The island offers stunning ocean views, a picturesque setting, and a unique experience, although it comes with some limitations such as no hot running water and limited amenities. The lighthouse keeper's cottage is a charming spot where guests can enjoy breathtaking views and a BBQ on the patio. Due to its popularity, bookings are usually taken well in advance, especially during peak season.

Two teenage girls, Kelly McKay and Payge Olds, helped rescue a 26-year-old man named Boobesh Palani from Wellington Harbour while he was struggling to stay afloat. Palani, a student from India, was identified through a social media post by a New Zealander who recognized his name. The girls' bravery and quick thinking saved Palani's life, and he was taken to hospital, where he sadly passed away. The public's help in identifying Palani allowed his friends to say goodbye to him, and the girls received praise for their heroic actions.

Scientists have developed a new material that can generate hydrogen from water, making it a cleaner alternative to traditional methods of producing hydrogen. This breakthrough uses a patented catalyst to split water into hydrogen and oxygen, reducing the amount of energy required and minimizing energy losses. The new catalyst is more efficient than existing materials, allowing for direct application to various electrode surfaces and high-energy storage. This technology has the potential to revolutionize the production of clean hydrogen power, enabling widespread adoption of hydrogen fuel cells and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

Labour leader Ed Miliband made his first campaign appearance in three days after taking a break over the Easter weekend, attending events in Bristol and meeting with his family. His rival David Cameron campaigned extensively over the weekend, visiting various constituencies across the UK, including Doncaster and Kent. Meanwhile, Labour leader Ed Miliband addressed a crowd in Bristol, criticizing the Conservative government's handling of the NHS and promising to improve healthcare services. The Labour leader also appeared on social media, posting a statement on Facebook, while Ukip leader Nigel Farage attended a rally in South Thanet, Kent.

Saudi airstrikes targeted a school in Yemen, injuring at least a half-dozen students, while also hitting a nearby military base, Al Hamza, which was defended by Houthis. The strikes occurred after Yemeni officials reported that Saudi Arabia was bombing the country, prompting the US to provide more support to the Saudi-led coalition. The US has shared intelligence with Saudi Arabia to identify targets, but its guidance does not allow direct involvement in selecting targets, citing concerns about civilian casualties. The airstrikes have resulted in significant damage to infrastructure and displaced thousands of people, including evacuees seeking refuge in neighboring countries.

A 38-year-old woman, Julieane Jablonski, has been charged with providing marijuana to a minor and felony tampering with a witness in connection with a case involving her 19-year-old son, Austin Essig, who jumped out of a third-story window while under the influence of a marijuana-laced brownie. Essig had eaten the brownie before jumping out of the apartment building, and witnesses reported that he acted strangely after consuming it. The Fort Collins police department's Facebook page was used to share details of the incident, which included a comment from another user stating that the experience was "quite the trip." Jablonski was booked on suspicion of these charges.

Liverpool forward Divock Origi has expressed his enthusiasm for joining the club after witnessing the progress of its young players, particularly winger Jordan Ibe, and winger Raheem Sterling. He credits the support of Liverpool fans for boosting his confidence and motivation. Origi, who impressed at Lille, believes he will be a better player due to the experience he gained during his time there. His own progress at Lille has prepared him well for the challenges ahead, including the demands of the Premier League. With the backing of the club, Origi feels ready to take his game to the next level.

ESPN sports reporter Britt McHenry, known for advocating for women's rights, was suspended for one week after being caught on camera verbally attacking a parking attendant at an Advanced Towing company in Arlington, Virginia. The video showed her making derogatory comments about the attendant's appearance, weight, and job, prompting outrage among women's rights advocates and supporters. McHenry later apologized for her actions, stating that she let her emotions get the better of her, but the backlash continues, with several organizations calling for her to be fired from her position. McHenry's suspension is seen as a setback for her efforts to promote women's empowerment through her blog and media appearances.

A Scottish illustrator, Johanna Basford, has seen a surge in sales of her children's book "Secret Garden", which encourages adults to engage in a creative activity called colouring. Her book has been translated into 22 languages and outsold traditional cookbooks, with over 1.4 million copies sold worldwide. Colouring has become a popular pastime among adults, who find it appealing due to its ability to provide a relaxing and creative outlet from the stresses of modern life. Experts attribute this trend to the growing desire for non-screen activities and a need for mental stimulation.

The National Health Service (NHS) spent £13 million handing out suncream and £29 million on indigestion pills in 2014, despite having a significant shortage of funds. This comes as the NHS faces a £8 billion shortfall in its annual budget by 2020/21. Patients are being prescribed unnecessary items like toothpaste, Calpol, and Vaseline, leading critics to call for greater flexibility in prescribing decisions. Many doctors argue that GPs should only issue prescriptions for necessary medications, rather than "demanding" them.

Pilots like flying Boeing 747s due to their spacious cabins and comfortable seating. A troubled co-pilot named Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed a Germanwings flight into the French Alps, sparking a national conversation about stress and depression among pilots. Mark Vanhoenacker's book explores the joys and challenges of being a pilot, including the unique aspects of flying 747s and the camaraderie among pilots. The book delves into the world of air traffic control and the daily routines of a commercial airliner, from boarding to landing.

Manchester City manager Alan Pardew has stated that despite Chelsea being six points clear at the top of the Barclays Premier League table, he believes the title race is not over yet. The Eagles' manager insists that the current standings do not necessarily mean the title is secure, citing the fact that Manchester City were able to overtake Liverpool last season. In fact, Pardew recalls that the same team also secured their first Premier League title in 2012, where Sergio Aguero scored a late winner. This experience suggests that even if City lose this match, they can still catch up. With Palace hosting City, Pardew remains optimistic about the title race, saying "of course they are still in the title race".

Michael Carrick, a 33-year-old Manchester United midfielder, has expressed his desire to pursue a career in motorsport, revealing he wants to try his hand at Formula One after retiring from football. He recently celebrated Manchester United's win with a goal against Liverpool, and later watched the match on MUTV. Carrick credits his experience playing for Manchester United, which included a challenging move from his hometown of Newcastle to London at 15, for helping shape him into the person he is today. When asked about his future plans, Carrick stated that he would "love to have a go" at Formula One, citing his passion for the sport and desire to maintain a healthy lifestyle.

A non-profit organization called Wood Green animal charity is partnering with Handy, a cleaning and DIY app, to offer a cat fostering service to help homeowners rid their homes of mice infestations. The charity is providing 200 cats to help deter rodents, while also offering a "Goat Grazer Beta" service that uses goats to control unruly vegetation. This innovative approach aims to provide a humane and effective solution to the issue of mice infestations. The cats are trained to use their pheromones to scare away mice, making them a natural and non-toxic method of pest control.

The Coachella festival saw a range of unusual and often outrageous outfit choices from celebrities, with many opting for bright colors and bold patterns. Paris Hilton and Kylie Jenner were two notable examples, both wearing elaborate and eye-catching outfits, including a mini-dress and a full-body suit. Other celebrities, such as Jaden Smith and Khloe Kardashian, also made headlines for their unique and sometimes questionable fashion choices, including a mummy costume and a Peter Pan-inspired ensemble. Despite the overall sense of chaos and excess, some attendees appeared to be trying to tone things down, opting for more subdued and modest outfits.

The Sandringham museum at the Norfolk estate has undergone significant changes after being closed for a winter period, with 62 pieces of hunting memorabilia removed and replaced with "trinkets and bric-a-brac". The removal includes stuffed animals such as rhino heads, tusked skulls, and skins, as well as items related to the hunting of endangered species like elephants and lions. The museum makes a pointed reference to the changing times, stating that it is "the destructive era" of hunting and the use of endangered materials. Around five items remain unaccounted for, sparking questions about their legitimacy.

. £13.50, Waitrose. Finally, if you want to splurge, this one is worth considering. Richer, more complex, and with a slightly more pronounced acidity, it’s perfect for sipping on its own or pairing with a meal.

**The Verdict:** Prosecco is the clear winner in terms of taste, with its crisp, refreshing qualities and affordable price point. However, it’s essential to remember that the quality varies greatly depending on the producer and the specific vintage.

A former Adelaide doctor, Tareq Kamleh, who fled to join the Islamic State, is still practicing medicine in Australia despite appearing in a propaganda video encouraging foreign medics to join the terrorist group. He features in a video urging people to join the Islamic State Health Service, which has led to concerns about his suitability to practice medicine. Kamleh completed his medical degree at Adelaide University and worked at several hospitals before leaving Australia on a flight to Kuala Lumpur. His actions have raised questions about whether he will face prosecution under Australia's laws, particularly since he is still registered to practice medicine.

A devastating car crash occurred on Wyee Road near Doyalson in NSW Central Coast, resulting in the deaths of two siblings, Piper Kulk, 8, and William Kulk, 9, who were traveling in a car driven by their grandmother, Helen Boddy. The crash happened on Saturday evening, and all seven occupants were severely injured, with some sustaining broken bones. The incident followed a car spinning out of control and colliding with an ute, causing a fatal head-on collision. The bodies of the two siblings were found in the wreckage, and their parents, Daniel and Chantelle, are currently receiving treatment in hospital. Seven people were involved in the crash, with multiple injuries sustained.

Dino Maglio, a former Italian policeman, was found guilty of raping a 16-year-old girl via a Couchsurfing website. He claimed the sex was consensual, despite admitting to spiking the girl with a tranquilizer and then having sex with her. The girl testified that she felt "woozy and intensely tired" after being served a drink containing the sedative, which rendered her unable to resist. Maglio's claims of consent were rejected by prosecutors, who believe he used the girl as a "rag doll".

Politicians such as Ed Miliband, Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg, and Green Party leader Natalie Bennett advise against sexting due to its risks, particularly for younger individuals like Brooks Newmark who received hundreds of nude photos from a disgraced Tory MP. A quiz for Cosmopolitan magazine asked politicians about their views on sexting, with some responding candidly about the risks associated with it. Disgraced Co-op boss Paul Flowers and former US Representative Anthony Weiner are examples of politicians who have faced consequences for sexting scandals. The quiz highlighted the dangers of sexting, especially for those in positions of power or authority.

A 48-year-old man, Ian Walters, is accused of murdering his 48-year-old wife, Tracy, after intentionally crashing their Mitsubishi L200 into a tree on the M1 motorway last year while driving erratically. Walters, a former driving test examiner, claimed that his wife's inability to satisfy his sex demands led to the breakdown of their relationship, but prosecutors argue that conflict over sex was a main issue. Walters denied murder, saying he fell asleep at the wheel due to medication, but admitted to having "fainting" twice in the two years leading up to the crash. The couple had been married for two years and had a troubled relationship, with allegations of abuse against Walters towards his wife.

A drone was spotted near Manchester Airport, causing disruptions to flights due to a potential sighting. Flights were temporarily suspended for 20 minutes before being resumed after a police search failed to find any evidence of a drone in operation. The incident highlights concerns over the increasing popularity of radio-controlled drones, which can pose a risk to aircraft and pilots if not flown safely. Manchester Airport reopened its second runway after the situation was resolved, but flights continued to experience delays and diversions.

Chinese authorities have developed a powerful new cyberattack called the "Great Cannon", which uses a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack to target servers outside of China, including those of Western news websites and social media platforms. The Great Cannon is a significant improvement over the country's existing "Great Firewall", which monitors and blocks internet traffic entering China. The attack is believed to be triggered by Chinese censors seeking to suppress critical content, and has been linked to several high-profile incidents, including the destruction of online services like GreatFire.org and GitHub. The Great Cannon's ability to target multiple servers simultaneously makes it a formidable threat, and experts warn that it could be used to disrupt global communication networks.

Spain's Ciudad Real airport, located near Madrid, was built in 2009 at a cost of €1 billion and was intended to serve both Madrid and the coastal region. Despite being operational for nearly four years, the airport remains idle due to financial difficulties and lack of demand. The airport stood vacant after its parent company went bankrupt, and it was eventually sold for £86 million. The abandoned airport, once a symbol of modern Spain's affluence, now stands as a relic of a failed project.

Detective Patrick Cherry, a member of the NYPD's Joint Terrorism Task Force, appeared on NBC 4 New York to apologize for his behavior during a traffic stop, where he shouted at an Uber driver, Humayun, who had honked his horn. Cherry was subsequently stripped of his badge and gun and placed on administrative duty due to the incident. The incident involved a heated exchange between Cherry and Humayun, with Cherry using profanity and making derogatory comments about the driver's accent and pronunciation. Cherry was later found guilty of misconduct and will face disciplinary action. The NYPD has launched an investigation into the incident, which led to Cherry's transfer to a different unit.

Edwin van der Sar, a former Manchester United goalkeeper, has expressed his confidence that Louis van Gaal's return as manager will help bring back the "glory days" for the Red Devils. Van Gaal's team, currently sitting second in the Premier League, face Chelsea on Saturday and are likely to be heavy favorites to win the title. However, Van Gaal admitted that the title is probably beyond their grasp this season due to Chelsea's strong performances. Despite this, Van Gaal remains optimistic about the team's chances of challenging for the championship next year. He also hinted that he plans to add new signings to strengthen the team during the summer transfer window.

Bournemouth drew 2-2 with Sheffield Wednesday despite trailing to a Kieran Lee sucker punch in the 36th minute. The Cherries' Simon Francis was sent off in the 78th minute due to a red card, while Chris Maguire converted an injury-time penalty to seal the win for Wednesday. Bournemouth had 15 penalties throughout the season, which may have contributed to their frustration. Manager Eddie Howe expressed heartbreak over the missed opportunities, feeling that Callum Wilson deserved a penalty in the second half.

A 18-year-old woman named Billy-Anne Huxham was abducted by her ex-partner Carl Garry Chapman while walking home from a friend's house on the Sunshine Coast. She was held hostage for several hours and subjected to physical abuse, including being tortured and attacked with a machete. Chapman was arrested and charged with multiple offenses, including unlawful use of a motor vehicle, entering a dwelling with intent, and assault occasioning bodily harm. Huxham was finally found safe and sound after making contact with a family member, who alerted police, and was subsequently charged with various crimes. Chapman will appear in court on Saturday.

Southampton manager Ronald Koeman wants his team to focus on themselves and start scoring goals after struggling to find form in recent weeks. His striker Graziano Pelle has been struggling to replicate his early-season form, while Koeman also hopes to recall Senegalese striker Sadio Mane to the starting lineup. With the pressure on to finish in the top half of the Premier League table, Koeman believes that his team needs to improve their goal-scoring record. To achieve this, he is urging his players to work harder and bring more quality to the pitch. This includes improving their ability to create scoring opportunities, which could see them score more goals.

A large population of goldfish has invaded Teller Lake in Boulder, Colorado, after being dumped into the water by someone two or three years ago. The invasive species poses a threat to the local aquatic ecosystem, including native fish such as channel catfish, blue gill fish, and sunfish. To address the problem, Colorado Parks and Wildlife officials are considering removing the fish using electrofishing, which involves shocking the fish with an electrical current to kill them. The removal effort aims to prevent further harm to the native species and restore balance to the ecosystem.

Everton goalkeeper Tim Howard believes the Europa League is not to blame for the team's disappointing performance in the Premier League, despite playing 10 European games. The Toffees' worst season in nine years may be attributed to factors beyond the competition, as they finished 25 points behind their target of finishing in the top 10. Everton's 4-2-3-1 formation and 32-game schedule may have contributed to their struggles. The team's inability to replicate the form of last season's Champions League winners has led to concerns over their chances of qualifying for European competitions. With only one win from their last six matches, Everton's hopes of improving their position in the Premier League may be slipping away.

The Atlanta Hawks defeated the Brooklyn Nets 131-99 on Saturday night, thanks in part to Al Horford's 20 points and 20 points from DeMarre Carroll. Paul Millsap suffered a right shoulder injury in the first half and did not return. The Hawks improved to 57 wins this season, matching their franchise record. Meanwhile, the Boston Celtics beat the Miami Heat 117-166 in overtime, securing a spot in the playoffs.

New 4G mobile phone services in the UK are not meeting expectations, with average download speeds averaging 2.5 times faster than promised, according to a recent study by Ofcom. The study found that EE's 4G network delivers the fastest average download speed of 18.6Mbit/s, while Vodafone's 4G speeds range from 6.6 to 16.4Mbit/s. The study also found that upload speeds are improving, but overall, 4G speeds are slowing down due to increased usage. The UK's largest mobile operator, EE, boasts the fastest average download speed, but its 4G network covers only 81% of homes and businesses.

Jimmy Anderson reached 100 Test matches for England, receiving a special silver cap from Mike Atherton to mark the occasion. Chris Gayle, West Indies' best batsman, chose to play in the Indian Premier League (IPL) over playing for his country. Meanwhile, Moeen Ali returned to action for Worcestershire, scoring 62 runs and taking 9 wickets in an innings. The West Indies Cricket Board president, Dave Cameron, emphasized the importance of teamwork and unity, while Sir Vivian Richards Stadium was renamed in honor of both Sir Curtly Ambrose and Sir Andy Roberts.

Ellia Beasley, a 22-year-old model from New Milton, Hampshire, got a tattoo of the lyrics "scream your heart out" from the song "Rooftops" by Lost Prophet, featuring the band's lead singer Ian Watkins, who was later convicted of child sex offenses. The tattoo was a regrettable choice made in 2012, but Ellia has since removed it due to its association with Watkins' crimes. A tattoo artist, Kevin Paul, helped her come up with a new design to cover the lyrics, resulting in a giant owl tattoo on her stomach. The experience left her feeling horrifically painful, but she has no regrets about the change.

Taxi driver Uncle Teng from Shenyang, North China, has taken 30,000 selfies with passengers since 2004, starting with just two people. He uses a unique tipping system where passengers pay him instead of giving cash, which has led to him becoming one of the most recognized faces in the region. With over 7,000 selfies taken, Uncle Teng has become known for his infectious smile, which he attributes to its genuine nature. His efforts have earned him numerous awards, including the Shanghai Big World Jinisi Record for his 30,000 selfies with passengers.

Mindy Kaling, the star of the TV show "The Mindy Project", has denied knowledge of her brother Vijay Chokal-Ingam's decision to pretend to be black to get into medical school. Chokal-Ingam, 38, admitted to his sister that he revealed his secret to her ahead of the release of his new book, "Almost Black", which details his experiences gaining admission to medical school under a different name and race. Chokal-Ingam claims he was unaware of his sister's involvement in the revelation and denies denying anything about his actions. However, his brother's claims have sparked controversy, with many accusing him of perpetuating racist stereotypes and ignoring systemic inequalities faced by black individuals.

A 53-year-old woman named Julie McKenzie visited her GP about her nagging back pain, initially thinking it was due to scoliosis. After undergoing X-rays, her GP reassured her that the pain was likely due to mild curvature of the spine, but Julie suspected otherwise. She sought a second opinion from a private surgeon, who confirmed that she had a malignant tumour in her coccyx, a benign tumour that occurs in the spine. Despite initial relief from surgery, Julie continues to experience chronic pain, although she believes that dealing with the issue has improved her quality of life.

A French Bulldog in California became enraged when left alone in a car, continuously honking its horn due to frustration. Ryan Burns captured footage of the incident on his camera phone, which showed the dog standing firm despite attempts to calm it down. The dog's owner disputes the claim, stating the dog was well-cared for and not mistreated. The disturbing video has garnered over a million views, sparking outrage and debate about animal welfare.

Photographer Anthony Barbour, 33, from Liverpool, creates surreal 360-degree photographs by spending hours taking pictures at various locations, such as Sefton Park, Mudeford Beach, and Durdle Door in Dorset. He uses a Canon 1100d DSLR and edits the photos in PhotoShop to create unique "planets" showcasing his surroundings. Barbour finds inspiration in unexpected places, often capturing interesting landscapes without much movement, and believes photography helps him cope with his recent illness. His work showcases his creativity and skill in turning ordinary locations into extraordinary images.

A 21-year-old son of a Labour councillor, Waheed Ahmed, was arrested at Manchester Airport on suspicion of terrorism offences while attempting to enter Syria with eight of his relatives. Aaron Murphy scored twice in a seven-try romp as Huddersfield beat Catalans Dragons 38-14 in a Super League match. Three people, possibly more, poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger at a gas station in South Los Angeles, setting it on fire. Hillary Clinton's Twitter follower count appears to be inflated due to artificial engagement, with many of her followers being fake or inactive. A rescue operation freed nearly 100 dogs from a Tennessee property, where they had been living in a dark, filthy barn for an unknown period. Michael Easy, 29, a serial offender with multiple convictions, was jailed for 15 months after posting Facebook photos of himself in Dame Edna Everage-style sunglasses and a platinum wig, taunting police while on the run from a 2013 assault charge. A 18-year-old Long Island resident, Harold Ekeh, has received acceptance letters from all eight Ivy League colleges, including Harvard, Yale, and several others. A 21-year-old man, Thomas Buckett, was left seriously injured after falling 15ft through a roof of a school's tuck shop in Newcastle-under-Lyme, England, during a break-in. Jose Mourinho, Chelsea manager, believes he is improving in various aspects of his job despite facing criticism for his honesty with the media. Chelsea will face Paris Saint-Germain in a pre-season friendly in North Carolina on July 25. Burnley manager Sean Dyche has called on his teammates to share the goalscoring burden to keep the team in the Premier League, despite striker Danny Ings' recent struggles. John Chapple is a British photographer known for capturing stunning panoramic images of various landscapes around the world, including England, the US, Australia, and other locations. NBC's "World News Tonight" with David Muir has officially overtaken underfire rival "Nightly News" in the ratings war for the first time in over five and a half years. Robert Downey Jr, the actor playing Iron Man in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, has been accused of making a racist remark about Oscar-winning Mexican director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, stating that superhero movies are "cultural genocide". A prisoner who rode in a police van with Freddie Gray claimed that Gray was trying to injure himself before dying from unexplained spinal cord injuries. Sir Paul McCartney married Heather Mills in 2002, but their wedding reception was marred by tension due to the fact that she was still grieving the loss of her previous husband, Sir Paul's first wife Linda. Ferrari driver Sebastian Vettel celebrated his fourth Formula One World Championship title win at the Malaysian Grand Prix, marking the team's first victory in 35 years. A 51-year-old mother and daughter, Iona Costello, and her 45-year-old daughter Emily, were found safe and well in New York City's Upper West Side neighborhood after being missing since March 30. A four-month-old baby named Evan Summerfield died from meningitis, just 12 hours after laughing for the first time. Krista Dotzenrod, a 24-year-old Chicago Cubs fan, caught a foul ball while attending a game between the Cubs and the San Diego Padres. The Oshun Café, located in London, is opening a new single-item menu eatery offering acai berry bowls, toasties, and other dishes. A study warns that children who play rugby may suffer serious injuries, with up to 7 training sessions or matches resulting in injuries ranging from bruises to concussions and potentially life-threatening damage to the brain and spinal cord. Andy Murray defeated 21-year-old Austrian Dominic Thiem in the Miami Open semi-finals, securing a spot in the final. The match saw Murray pump his fist in celebration after winning 6-4, 6-4, 6-1. Hillary Clinton's aide Huma Abedin spent a relaxing day out with her husband Anthony Weiner and two-year-old son Jordan, enjoying a meal at Tortaria in New York. QUINTON "RAMAGE" JACKSON returns to the UFC after a two-year hiatus, facing off against FABIO MALDONADO at UFC 186 in Montreal. A pregnant woman and her partner were rescued after their trimaran overturned in the English Channel while they were trying to retrieve an emergency flare. The woman was left clinging to the hull in the water, where her partner tied a rope around himself to dive down to retrieve the flare. The alarm was raised when a witness spotted the couple in distress a mile from Dungeness Point, Kent, and a rescue boat was dispatched immediately. The woman and her partner were safely retrieved by a rescue boat, which took them to the hospital, where they received medical attention.

Cassandra C., a 17-year-old teenager from Connecticut, has completed chemotherapy treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma, which was ordered by a judge due to her high risk of death without it. A 10-year-old boy whose body was found in the Mississippi River near Crystal, Minnesota, was identified as Barway Edward Collins, a 10-year-old boy whose body was discovered by a search team from a Boy Scout troop on Saturday. Massive mass cremations are underway in Kathmandu, Nepal, as the country continues to deal with the aftermath of a devastating earthquake that has claimed over 4,000 lives. The National Front's leadership has expressed disappointment, while opinion polls suggest Marion could still make it to the second round of the presidential election. Marion has been described as more socially conservative than her aunt Marine, who is seen as a strong contender.

Andrew Getty, 47, the grandson of oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, died Tuesday afternoon in his home in Los Angeles after being found unresponsive by a female friend. The cause of death is believed to be natural, but further investigation is pending. Gordon Getty, 81, is also deceased, according to court records showing he filed a restraining order against a woman just days before his death. A restraining order was set to be heard next week.

A diverse range of cricketers from around the world showcase their skills in various settings, including Bangladesh, Australia, England, India, and South Africa. The Wisden-MCC Cricket Photograph of the Year award winner, Matthew Lewis's image of Dwayne Bravo taking a remarkable catch, highlights the athleticism and skill of professional cricketers. Amateur players like Nurul Hasan and Jimmy Anderson also feature in the photographs, demonstrating the diversity of the sport. The competition's winning image showcases the excitement and drama of international cricket matches. The photographs capture the beauty of the game, highlighting its global appeal.

A Reddit thread on the website FEMAIL has garnered over 18,000 comments in just 24 hours, featuring some truly horrific baby names. The thread includes submissions from individuals sharing their own experiences with awful names, such as "Obamaniqua", "Like", and "Gwenyth Paltrow". Many of these names are deemed unusual or even disturbing, while others combine two names together, like "Hazel" and "Hellzel". The thread also highlights instances where parents have used celebrity names, such as Britney Shakira Beyonce and Lil' Kim.

Hay fever sufferers in the UK are predicted to face a severe summer due to a predicted 20 million cases, with around 5 million expected to experience symptoms for the first time. High grass pollen counts are forecasted to cause widespread suffering, with symptoms including streaming eyes, sneezing, and itchy throats. The pollen counts are expected to surge due to warmer temperatures and increased plant growth, with the average hayfever season stretching from April to August. A leading pollen expert warns that the situation is expected to worsen by 2030, with 31.8 million expected to be affected.

Raheem Sterling, 20, has rejected a new deal with Liverpool and put off contract talks until the summer due to concerns about his future. The forward, who has impressed with his performances for England and Liverpool, has chosen to wait until the summer to decide on his future. Sterling's decision comes after he was offered a new contract by Liverpool, which would see him earn £100,000 per week. However, he has expressed doubts about staying at the club, citing his desire to avoid being perceived as a "money-grabbing" 20-year-old. Sterling's current £35,000-a-week deal expires at the end of the season, and he has already signed a new deal with Everton, which pays him £35,000 per week.

TV star Karren Brady helped Prime Minister David Cameron announce 16,000 new apprenticeships today at a National Grid training centre in Newark, Nottinghamshire. Baroness Brady appeared alongside Mr Cameron to promote the initiative, which aims to deliver 3 million high-quality apprenticeships over the next five years. This follows the creation of 2.2 million apprenticeships since 2010, and marks a significant step towards strengthening the UK's economy and providing financial security for millions of people. The announcement comes ahead of the general election, with Mr Cameron pledging to create three million more apprenticeships under a Conservative government.

A daredevil adventurer, Oscar Hübinette, attempted to ski down the slopes of the 12,000-foot-tall Tolbachik volcano on the Kamchatka Peninsula in Russia after its recent eruption. The volcano's lava flowed furiously behind him, creating a striking contrast between the black and red molten rock and the white snow. Photographer Fredrik Schenholm captured stunning images of the scene, including Oscar flying down the mountain and the volcano's still erupting activity. The volcano has been active since 1976, with frequent eruptions occurring over the past few years, including a prolonged period of six months in 2012.

Newcastle United manager John Carver has vowed to motivate his players ahead of their upcoming Premier League match against Sunderland, saying he will "whip" them to ensure they beat their North-East rivals. The Magpies have struggled in recent derbies against Sunderland, losing four of their last five meetings, and Carver believes this is an opportunity for them to turn things around. With a comfortable mid-table position, Carver wants to keep Sunderland's record intact, but notes that the Black Cats are fighting for Premier League survival. Newcastle players such as Moussa Sissoko and Mehdi Abeid will be key to keeping Sunderland's record going, while Carver also expects defenders like Massadio Haidara to be back in action after missing the last game due to knee surgery.

Rangers goalkeeper Steve Simonsen's suspension for breaching betting laws has been upheld by the Scottish FA after his appeal was rejected. Simonsen admitted to betting on 50 games in a year, despite being warned about the SFA's zero-tolerance policy. His legal team argued that the punishment was too lenient, citing previous cases where players received harsher penalties for similar offenses. The SFA ultimately upheld the original ban, which means Simonsen will serve a one-game suspension.

A former England player Bobby Moore famously hugged Brazilian star Pelé during a 1970 World Cup match, setting a standard for sportsmanship in football. Newcastle United goalkeeper Tim Krul recently showed similar courtesy to Sunderland striker Jermain Defoe by congratulating him on scoring a goal in a hard-fought match. However, some critics argue that Krul's behavior was inappropriate, particularly given his nationality and position as a foreign import. They point to Jamie Carragher's criticism of Krul's actions as evidence of the game's decline in showing genuine sportsmanship. Despite this, the incident highlights the tension between old-school values and modern-day rivalries in English football.

The Obamas paid over $93,000 in federal taxes last year on an adjusted gross income of over $477,000, with an effective tax rate of 19.6%. They claimed nearly $160,000 in itemized deductions, including $70,712 in charitable donations. The couple donated nearly 15% of their income to various charities, including the Fisher House Foundation and Sidwell Friends School. The Obamas' tax returns were released ahead of the filing deadline, showing a total of $20,641 in a tax refund.

Marcelo Bosch, an Argentine centre, has signed a contract extension with Saracens, ending a 9-year tenure at the club. He kicked a crucial penalty in their European Champions Cup quarter-final win over Racing Metro, securing a 12-11 victory. Bosch joins fellow forwards George Kruis and Maro Itoje on new deals. This move comes after Saracens director Mark McCall praised Bosch's improvement and renewed commitment to improving as a player. The signing marks a significant development in the team's ongoing pursuit of European glory.

Amal Clooney, a high-powered human rights lawyer, called for the release of imprisoned former Maldivian President Mohamed Nasheed during a press conference in Washington DC today. Nasheed, who was convicted under anti-terrorism laws, was sentenced to 13 years in prison. Clooney, married to George Clooney, is part of a high-profile legal team representing Nasheed, who was ousted in 2012. Clooney expressed determination to see Nasheed released, saying he would "not rest" until he walks free.

41-year-old mother-of-two has spoken about her journey to becoming a mother and balancing her career and family life. 'I've learned that it's okay to ask for help and that it's okay to prioritize your health', she said. Paula's story is one of determination and perseverance and her legacy continues to inspire millions around the world.

Arsenal midfielder Aaron Ramsey scored a dramatic extra-time winner in the 2014 FA Cup final against Burnley, dedicating the goal to his late grandmother, Eileen, who had passed away recently. He celebrated with teammates Hector Bellerin and was mobbed by fans after scoring. The victory marked a significant milestone in Ramsey's career, coming after a tough period of personal loss and injury. Manager Arsene Wenger praised the team's resilience and determination, saying they had overcome adversity to achieve their goal. With 25 goals scored since the start of the season, Ramsey cemented his status as one of the top scorers in the league.

Teenager Lily Sharp fakes her own kidnapping to play a prank on her mother, but things escalate when she convinces her mother that an intruder has taken her daughter. The prank becomes increasingly absurd when Lily sends threatening messages and demands a ransom, prompting her mother to call the police. Eventually, Lily reveals the joke to the authorities, who arrive to find the "kidnapped" daughter perched on the sofa, and arrest the real intruder. Despite the initial shock, the tweet about the prank goes viral, garnering over 20,000 likes and 30,000 retweets.

Italy has seen a significant increase in migrant arrivals since last weekend, with over 10,000 people arriving on its islands since January 13th. The majority of these migrants came from North Africa, particularly Libya, where they were rescued by the Italian Coast Guard and later released into the open sea. A recent program aimed at rescuing migrants has resulted in over 160,000 being rescued in Italy since 2013, with many more expected to follow. The program, known as Mare Nostrum, was discontinued due to budget constraints and criticism from the EU, but has been replaced by a new initiative called Triton, which relies on European member states to provide vessels and resources.

West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has defended his team despite their poor form, saying they should focus on results rather than individual performances. Co-owner David Sullivan had criticized the team's recent results, calling them "exceedingly disappointing". However, Allardyce disagrees, stating that the team's overall performance is more important than their individual results from 2015. He believes that the team has shown improvement throughout the season, although still needs to improve in terms of wins. With Enner Valencia set to return to the starting lineup after suffering an injury, Allardyce hopes to see a better performance from his striker.

Pupils who experience anxiety ahead of exams tend to perform poorly, according to a new study by Lancashire's Edge Hill University. The study found a direct link between anxiety and lower grades, suggesting that managing anxiety can improve exam performance. To help alleviate stress, parents can encourage their children to create a revision plan, use revision aids like flashcards and highlighters, and prioritize self-care. By doing so, parents can help their offspring feel more confident and prepared for the exam season.

Scotland's European Challenge Cup hopes have been dealt a significant blow after centre Matt Scott underwent surgery on his injured left shoulder, leaving him out until at least the end of the season. The 25-time capped centre, who played a key role in Scotland's recent run to the European Challenge Cup semi-final, is also doubtful for the World Cup due to another injury. Coach Vern Cotter is facing a major challenge without Scott, who could miss the World Cup, while hooker Ross Ford is also struggling with a shoulder injury. The Scottish team faces a tough task in the European Challenge Cup semi-final against Newport Gwent Dragons, which could see them fall behind the Welsh side, who are currently in the lower half of the table.

Bobby Flay, a 50-year-old celebrity chef, has filed for divorce from his 40-year-old wife Stephanie March, citing irreconcilable differences. According to Page Six, Flay allegedly cheated on March with his 28-year-old assistant Eliyse Tirrell, who works at his restaurant Bar Americain. The two were married for 10 years before filing for divorce, with Flay reportedly paying $5,000 per month in alimony to March. Tirrell is described as a singer and actress who worked at Flay's restaurant in 2008.

Emma Louise Connolly models Ann Summers' new bridal wear lingerie collection, featuring a range of intimate pieces such as curve-skimming dresses, nightgowns, and silk and lace sets. The collection is inspired by the brand's iconic "Fifty Shades of Grey" line and includes items like a daring cut-out bra and a barely-there peek-a-boo thong. Emma, who is currently dating Ollie Proudlock, is the face of the brand and has been promoting it since their relationship began in October. The collection is available in sizes 8-12 and features prices ranging from £14 to £85.

The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has removed the name "Isis" from its list of future Pacific hurricane names due to its association with the militant group ISIS, which has committed brutal atrocities against civilians. The decision comes after the WMO Hurricane Committee deemed the name inappropriate due to its connection to the terrorist organization. The WMO has a rotating list of storm names that alternates between male and female names, and the removal of "Isis" means it will no longer be used for any future storms. This move follows the WMO's previous decision to retire the name "Odile", which was used for a devastating hurricane that struck Mexico in 2014.

A leak of Game of Thrones' first four episodes has occurred, with nearly half of the season's content being shared online. The leaks came from a group approved by HBO to receive the material, and include key scenes featuring popular characters like Jon Snow and Tyrion Lannister. The leaked episodes are part of a larger trend of high-profile shows being pirated, with Game of Thrones being the second-most pirated series after Walking Dead. The leak is seen as a challenge for HBO to promote the show's fifth season, which debuts tonight.

A Scottish National Party (SNP) poll shows that more than half of voters do not want to see Nicola Sturgeon or the SNP calling the shots in the next British government, with 59% opposing a SNP-Labour deal. The party's manifesto demands include extra spending, ending benefits cuts, and scrapping Trident, while also making it clear that they will support Labour on key issues. A recent ComRes poll found that 54% of voters want the SNP kept out of the next UK government, and 71% of those aged 65 and over oppose having Sturgeon in power. The SNP has been ruling out a formal coalition with Labour MPs, but may consider supporting a Labour government on a vote-by-vote basis.

Dressed in a Barbie doll-inspired Moschino collection, Olivia Phillips took to the streets of Dubai to gauge the impact of the iconic fashion brand's latest collection. She wore a spray-on leather skirt suit to the supermarket, navigating the aisles with ease despite feeling like a "saucy Stepford Wife". The collection, featuring bright pink leathers and super-girly dresses, seemed to bring joy to those around her, with people smiling and greeting her everywhere she went. The experience proved that Moschino's latest collection can indeed make a statement, even in everyday settings.

Chelsea are planning a victory parade through the streets around Stamford Bridge after winning the Premier League title, with a planned route starting at Fulham Road and ending at Eel Brook Common. The parade will take place on May 25 if Chelsea win the title, with buses departing from the west entrance of Stamford Bridge and traveling east along Fulham Road and King's Road. The parade will also include a clean-up operation. If Chelsea win the title, the city council has provided funding for the event, which will be announced separately.

Jack Henry Doshay, 22, was arrested for allegedly attempting to kidnap a 7-year-old girl from a Solana Beach elementary school. The girl was reportedly dragged away by Doshay, who used packing tape to try to smother her while trying to silence her screams. Doshay was arrested nine days later after a tip from the public led to a search warrant and his capture. He is facing charges of kidnapping, false imprisonment with violence, and child cruelty. Doshay's parents, Glenn and Karen, have been noticeably absent from the courtroom during his arraignment.

Kumar Sangakkara, a 37-year-old Sri Lankan cricketer, should reconsider retiring from limited overs cricket due to his disappointing performance in the World Cup quarter-final loss. As the country's sports minister, Navin Dissanayake humbly requested Sangakkara to remain in the team for another year. Sangakkara had previously played four successive centuries in the World Cup, but ultimately decided to retire. With over 14,000 one-day runs under his belt, Sangakkara is considered one of the greatest wicketkeepers in cricket history. His decision to bid farewell to the one-day format may be reversed if he receives further encouragement from the country's sports minister.

Nicola Sturgeon, the leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), has called for the retirement age to be frozen in Scotland due to concerns that raising it would disproportionately affect pensioners, who tend to live shorter lives compared to those in other parts of the UK. The SNP demands a freeze on the current retirement age of 66, citing the relatively low life expectancy in Scotland, where men typically live to be around 73 and women to be around 79. The party argues that this would result in a significant financial burden on pensioners, who contribute to the state pension through taxes. The SNP leader stated that her party would ensure that pensioners' contributions are recognized and rewarded, while also opposing any increases to the state pension age.

A Kentucky judge, Olu Stevens, is facing criticism for criticizing a couple's victim impact statements during a sentencing hearing. The couple, Gregory Wallace and his accomplice Marquis McAfee, were sentenced to 5 years' probation each after pleading guilty to robbery. However, the judge, Stevens, took issue with the couple's statements, which included accusations of fostering racist stereotypes in their 3-year-old daughter's mind. Stevens denied that the statements had any bearing on his judgment, despite the fact that the child's mother described feeling "constant fear" of black men after the crime. The couple's lawyer argued that the judge's comments were racist and unprofessional.

A series of mysterious cardboard signs with heartfelt messages have appeared across the Surrey village of Milford, sparking speculation about the identity of the author and the reason behind the contrite gesture. The signs feature messages such as "I love you" and "please forgive me", and were seen appearing on lampposts and street signs. Residents are speculating about the identity of the person responsible, but most agree that desperate measures seem to be working, with some people saying sorry with flowers, a romantic dinner, or chocolates. The appearance of the signs has brought attention to the village, which is known for its affluent residents.

Five Chinese feminist activists, including Li Tingting, Wei Tingting, Wang Man, Zheng Churan, and Wu Rongrong, have been detained by police for over a month for allegedly "picking quarrels and provoking trouble" while handing out leaflets about sexual harassment on public transport. The women, aged 25-30, were arrested on International Women's Day and face up to five-year prison terms if convicted. The Chinese government has accused them of "provoking trouble", a charge often used to justify detentions of dissidents and protesters. The women's family members have pleaded for their release, citing poor treatment and lack of explanation, and have received support from international organizations like the US and UK.

A group of over 10,000 Australians and New Zealanders have gathered on the Gallipoli peninsula to honor the diggers who fought and fell in the bloody landings of the Gallipoli campaign, which took place in 1915. The Anzac Dawn Service marked the 100th anniversary of the event, where Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott and New Zealand Prime Minister John Key paid tribute to the sacrifices made by the soldiers who fought and died in the war. The service included speeches from prominent figures, including Prince Charles and Prince Harry, who remembered the bravery and sacrifice of the Anzacs and the importance of their legacy. The event was part of a global celebration of Anzac Day, observed annually on April 25, which commemorates the lives lost in the wars of the past.

Fernando Torres scored his first league goal for Atletico Madrid, pulling Malaga back into the game with an own goal in the 45th minute. The Spanish striker had previously struggled to find form since returning to the team in January. Malaga goalkeeper Carlos Kameni made a crucial save to prevent a clean sheet, while Atletico Madrid equalized through Antoinne Griezmann's chip over the bar. The match ended in a 2-2 draw, keeping Atletico Madrid in third place in La Liga. Torres' goal marked a rare success for the Spanish striker, who has only scored once since his return to the club.

Danny Lennon has been appointed as the new interim manager of Scotland's Under 21 football team, replacing Paddy Connolly. He will lead the team until the summer of 2016. Lennon previously managed St Mirren before taking over as interim manager of Scotland's Under 21 team. His tenure ends with the official announcement of his departure. The Scottish Football Association has expressed its gratitude to Lennon for his service to the team.

A 1993 film starring Harrison Ford, The Fugitive, features a memorable action scene where Dr. Richard Kimble escapes from a prison transport by jumping from a bus that collides with an onrushing train. The scene was filmed using a real train and a real bus, lying abandoned in the Great Smoky Mountains in North Carolina. Directed by Andrew Davis, the film was a huge success, grossing $370 million worldwide and featuring 13 cameras capturing the intense 60-second sequence. The abandoned bus, now covered in weeds, serves as a popular tourist attraction, with the train lying nearby, and is considered one of the most iconic scenes in movie history.

A 28-year-old man, believed to be 20-year-old Bradley James Brooks, was charged with murder after stabbing a 28-year-old rugby player, Greg Gibbins, outside a pizza shop in the early hours of Monday morning. Gibbins was attacked while walking home from a party with his friend, who was also stabbed in the chest. The incident occurred allegedly due to a random attack, and police are still investigating the motive behind the attack. Gibbins died in hospital after suffering serious stab wounds, while his friend survived. The investigation is ongoing, and police are seeking witnesses who have not yet spoken with them.

A Reddit thread on Reddit has sparked discussions about the lives of men who have purchased mail-order brides from Russia and the Philippines, revealing surprising reactions to starting relationships with foreign women. Many men reported feeling awkwardness and discomfort when meeting their wives, who often spoke similarly to how they spoke about household chores. Some reported paying upwards of $50,000 for a bride, with translators required to facilitate communication due to language barriers. Despite the initial excitement, many men later expressed disappointment and sadness upon discovering that their wives were seeking financial support back home, leading to unhappy endings.

Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart expressed disappointment after a 4-2 defeat to Manchester United, stating that the team's bid to retain the Premier League title is over. He described the game as "one of his worst in a Manchester City shirt" and acknowledged that the team's performance was "hard to take". Hart also stated that the team's struggles in recent games suggest that they may not be good enough to compete with top teams like Manchester United. The defeat sees Manchester City four points behind their arch-rivals Manchester United, who now hold a 12-point lead in the league table. Hart's comments come after a disappointing start to the season, which has seen the team struggle to find consistency.

A labourer in the Northern Territory spotted a phallic-shaped cloud while taking a break at a construction site in Zuccoli, 25km southeast of Darwin. The unusual formation caught her off guard, leaving her speechless. She shared a photo of the cloud with friends, saying "I couldn't believe my eyes" and joked about it being a "X-rated cloud". The incident sparked widespread amusement online, with some calling it the most surreal moment ever captured.

Loren Mathieson filmed her pet Boston Terrier, Gizmo, performing a gravity-defying paw-stand walking trick at home. The dog took several steps forward before planting his front feet and launching into the air, showcasing his newfound ability. Mathieson laughed as she watched her pet perform the trick, which has garnered over 80,000 views online. Gizmo's impressive feat was achieved by trying on new black booties, prompting Mathieson to say it was just an accident.

Porto, the only undefeated side in the Champions League, face off against Bayern Munich in their quarter-final first leg. Julen Lopetegui, the manager of Porto, believes his team has room to improve and enjoys their recent success. The match marks a clash between two of Europe's top teams, with Lopetegui calling out Bayern Munich's "winner" Pep Guardiola. Porto's defense has been impressive, conceding just five goals all season, while Bayern Munich has struggled to score against smaller opponents. Lopetegui praises Bayern's former teammate Guardiola, who is set to manage Porto in the second leg.

A 9-year-old boy named Frankie Franz from Dagenham and Redbridge Football Club attempted a daring basketball hoop shot, scoring two goals in quick succession using a 27-yard pass from his father, who is a schoolboy footballer. The video of the incident, recorded at Barcelona's training ground, shows Frankie kicking the ball into the net, followed by a second attempt that also succeeds. The viral clip has made Frankie's dream of playing professional football seem more achievable. Frankie's talent has caught the attention of Barcelona scouts, who may consider him for their youth academy.

Maksims Uvarenko, a goalkeeper for CSKA Sofia, has been struggling financially due to unpaid salaries and rent, having asked his parents to cover the costs. Despite this, he remains optimistic about the team's unique fans and their passion. CSKA Sofia has been facing financial difficulties since billionaire Vasil Bozhkov sold the club nine years ago, leading to a series of disputes with fans and staff. The team has recently announced plans to meet the Bulgarian Football Union's licensing criteria, but it remains uncertain whether they will be able to recover from their current debt woes. Uvarenko has expressed gratitude towards the fans for their support, stating that every game is a thrilling experience.
