In a surprising result, Parma beat runaway leaders Juventus 1-0, thanks to a goal from Ishak Belfodil in the 90+1 minute. The win lifted Parma to safety, ending their financial struggles and putting them above crisis-hit club Juventus. Meanwhile, Inter Milan edged out Verona 3-0, while Genoa drew 1-1 against Cagliari. Parma goalkeeper Antonio Mirante made several crucial saves to help his team secure a much-needed win, while Jose Mauri celebrated with his teammates after scoring the decisive goal.

Photographer Simon Brann Thorpe created the documentary-style photograph series "Toy Soldiers", which captures images of soldiers posing as green plastic figurines in the desert of Western Sahara, highlighting the contrast between the harsh environment and the presence of real soldiers. The project aims to spark a deeper understanding of the conflict in the region by presenting a fresh perspective on war and its impact. Through his photographs, Thorpe raises questions about the consumption of images of war in today's digital age. The project involves working with the Polisario Front, a group fighting for independence in Western Sahara, and features soldiers who pose as toy soldiers to avoid detection.

A seven-year-old boy was brutally raped and set on fire by two youths while buying food in Pagma Nagar, Mumbai. The incident occurred when the boy resisted the attackers, leading them to burn him with a fire. The boy suffered severe burns covering 30% of his body and escaped unharmed after managing to break free. The incident has sparked widespread outrage and calls for justice, with police investigating the matter.

German football manager Jurgen Klopp has confirmed he will leave Borussia Dortmund at the end of the season after seven years in charge. The 47-year-old coach believes Dortmund need a change due to the team's struggles, particularly after losing key players such as Mats Hummels and Ilkay Gundogan. Klopp has expressed his desire to find a new opportunity where he can lead a team to success, citing his experience and achievements with Liverpool and Bayern Munich as reasons for his decision. This comes after rumors of potential moves to Manchester City, Liverpool, Arsenal, and Bayern Munich.

Sean McCabe, a father of three, was diagnosed with stage four Hodgkin lymphoma when he was 28 and underwent intensive chemotherapy. After initially having a 20% chance of survival, he was told his cancer had returned and was given the all-clear in September 2013. However, he was told his cancer had returned again in an even more aggressive form, forcing him to rebook the church for his funeral. Two months later, he was declared in remission and was able to get married to his fiancée Lisa Williams, who had been waiting patiently for him to recover. They are now planning to get married on July 25.

A 4-year-old boy and his 13-year-old brother died after their car crashed into the Los Angeles harbor, while their father drove away in the vehicle. The car plunged into the water, killing both children, and their mother was rescued by firefighters who dove into the water to pull them from the car. A firefighter named Miguel Meza was praised for his heroic actions, jumping into the water to rescue the children. The incident occurred near the San Pedro harbor, where nearly 100 emergency responders responded to the scene.

Qatar's investment arm, Qatar Holding, has acquired a majority stake in the hotel company Coroin, which owns several iconic London hotels, including Claridge's and The Berkeley. This move tightens Qatar's grip on London's real estate market. The acquisition is part of Qatar's expanding portfolio of high-profile properties, including the Shard and Canary Wharf. Qatar's investment arm has also made significant investments in other notable properties, such as Barclays Bank and British Airways.

A 35-year-old woman, Akon Guode, whose mother is a Sudanese national, was arrested and charged with murder after crashing a 2005 Toyota Kluger into a lake near Melbourne's outer west, killing three children aged one, four, and six years old. Her mother, Akon Manang, claimed she was "a good mother" and said she did not plan the accident. The children's father, Joseph Manyang, described his wife as loving and caring, and said she would take care of the children. The incident occurred on Manor Lakes Boulevard in Wyndham Vale, near Melbourne, and the car plunged into the lake after traveling towards Pedder St and Minindee Road. An investigation is ongoing, with police seeking witnesses and information about the incident.

Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed an algorithm that analyzes keystrokes to detect early signs of Parkinson's disease. The six-minute test measures "key hold time," which can indicate motor skill deterioration. The algorithm claims to accurately diagnose Parkinson's disease with a 85% success rate, potentially allowing for early detection and intervention. The technology could be applied to various diseases affecting motor skills, including rheumatoid arthritis.

Raheem Sterling, 20, has expressed his commitment to staying at Liverpool despite being offered a new £100,000-a-week contract by Arsenal, stating he is "flattered" by the offer. Sterling has also revealed he is not ready to sign a new contract at Anfield, citing his desire to focus solely on improving his football skills. Manager Brendan Rodgers believes Sterling's ambition aligns with the club's goals, and the club is willing to nurture him to become a top player. Sterling has been linked to Arsenal, but Rodgers insists the focus remains on developing Sterling at Liverpool.

Stoke City manager Mark Hughes has dismissed recent reports linking the club with signing Asmir Begovic, a goalkeeper who has been linked with a transfer to Real Madrid. Despite these rumors, Hughes remains optimistic that Begovic will sign a new deal with the Potters. The club is also hopeful of completing the signing of teenager Moah El Ouriachi from Barcelona, who is set to join from another Premier League club. Stoke City are currently 10th in the league table and are working towards improving their record Premier League haul of 50 points from last season. Hughes is focused on keeping his team's momentum going despite recent setbacks, including the absence of key players like Marc Muniesa and Victor Moses.

clashed in a chaotic finale. In the 90th minute, a wild tackle by Mason on Weimann resulted in a red card for the Villa captain. The final whistle blew and the players celebrated with joyous abandon. It was a fitting end to what was a rollercoaster of emotions for Villa fans.

Gerard "The Frenchman" Ouimette, a notorious mob enforcer from Rhode Island, died in a federal prison in North Carolina on Sunday at the age of 75. Ouimette was convicted of up to eight murders and controlled a vast underworld network involved in extortion, loansharking, and other crimes. He spent nearly 46 years behind bars, including time in high-security facilities, and was known for smuggling liquor, food, and even bringing children to prison for visits. Ouimette's death marks the end of a tumultuous life marked by violence and law enforcement crackdowns, including a falling out with fellow inmate Charles "The Ghost" Kennedy.

Danny Cipriani helped Sale Sharks to a 23-6 victory against Gloucester last Saturday, contributing 13 points from the boot after taking advantage of a rare free weekend. As part of their last four Aviva Premiership games, Sale are now looking to secure a top-six finish and qualification for the European Champions Cup. Cipriani has been in excellent form for Sale, making appearances in several key matches, including a notable cameo in the 47-17 victory over Italy. With the team out of contention in Europe, Cipriani took time off to relax in Dubai, where he will return to help them prepare for their upcoming games. This break comes as Sale aim to qualify for the Champions Cup, which could see them finish in the top six.

Owen Farrell, the Saracens fly-half, is hopeful of returning to form after suffering a knee ligament injury that kept him sidelined for the RBS 6 Nations campaign. He missed the entire tournament due to the injury, which occurred during a match against Clermont Auvergne in January. Farrell hopes to be fit enough to face Clermont in the European Champions Cup semi-final on April 18. With Saracens set to return to the Premiership this weekend, Farrell is looking forward to getting back into action. His injury has left him feeling well, but he needs to assess his fitness level before making a final decision about whether to participate in the semi-final.

Officer Michael Slager, 33, is being held in isolation due to his alleged role in the murder of Walter Scott, 50, after opening fire on him while stopped over a broken tail light in North Charleston, South Carolina. Slager is facing murder charges and is currently housed in a room with limited interaction with other inmates. The incident occurred on Saturday, and witnesses reported that Slager's patrol car caught footage of the shooting, showing him using a Taser on Scott before firing multiple shots. Slager is being held in a secure location pending further investigation.

Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino is confident that goalkeeper Michel Vorm can fill in for injured Hugo Lloris in the Capital One Cup final against Burnley. Vorm, who replaced Lloris in the previous round, has shown his ability to perform under pressure and has a strong reputation as a reliable backup. Pochettino praises Vorm's mental toughness after Lloris' injury, saying he "took it very well" and is ready to make a crucial contribution. Despite being behind Lloris in the pecking order, Vorm has impressed Pochettino with his professionalism and mentality. The Spurs manager believes that Vorm's experience and calm demeanor will help the team bounce back from the disappointment of losing Lloris due to injury.

A woman in New York City was billed $16,000 by Uber after a 35-minute car ride from East Williamsburg to Midtown East, despite being unaware of the driver's erratic behavior, including cutting across lanes and driving down bus lanes. The driver claimed to have taken a longer route and made multiple phone calls while driving, causing the massive error. Uber initially denied the claim but later apologized and refunded the customer, stating it was a clerical error. The customer disputed the amount, claiming they were not aware of the driver's actions and expressed concerns about trusting the app again.

A large cloud formation resembling the global Wi-Fi symbol appeared in central China, specifically in Xiangtan city in Hunan Province, last week. This unusual phenomenon was captured on camera by a student who took a photo of the cloud, which perfectly mimicked the Wi-Fi symbol. The image quickly went viral on social media, with many users commenting on its similarity to the global Wi-Fi symbol. The cloud formation was described as "God's router" by some, while others joked about it being a giant WiFi network.

Arsenal midfielder Jack Wilshere met Brazilian legend Pele at a launch party for 10Ten Talent, where he was interviewed by Pele himself. Wilshere posed for photos with Pele and shared some of the photos on social media, including one of the two of them together. Pele praised Wilshere's skills and mentioned that Brazil's Premier League-based players, such as Oscar and Ramires, have bounced back strongly after last year's disappointing World Cup campaign. The exhibition, "Art, Life, Football", celebrates Pele's 75th birthday and features works by international artists.

Migrants from Africa and the Middle East are attempting to cross the Mediterranean Sea into Italy, with over 8,480 rescued between Friday and Monday. A migrant boat carrying approximately 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean, prompting concerns that another may have been involved. The Italian coast guard has reported receiving 20 SOS calls from distressed boats, but has not confirmed any capsizes or identified the specific vessel. Despite increased rescue efforts, there have been reports of migrants being left stranded without aid, leading to deaths due to bad weather and overcrowding.

Jacques Burger, a 31-year-old Namibian rugby player, has been cited for alleged foul play during a European Champions Cup quarter-final match against Racing Metro. He allegedly struck Racing scrum-half Maxime Machenaud midway through the game. Burger faces a disciplinary hearing on Thursday and could face a two-week ban if found guilty. The incident occurred on last Sunday's match between Saracens and Racing Metro. Burger returns to action for Saracens on Saturday against Leicester, while Machenaud also plays for Racing Metro.

Chile's Calbuco Volcano erupted for the third time in recent weeks, producing a spectacular nighttime eruption and causing evacuations due to ash and lava flows. The volcano, located near Lake Llanquihue, had previously experienced two previous eruptions, with Thursday's event described as less severe than the first two. Over 1,500 people were evacuated, and a 20-kilometer exclusion zone was established around the crater. The volcano's seismic activity has been declining, but ash continues to be released into the atmosphere, posing risks to nearby communities. The eruption marked the first for many years, and it is considered a significant event by experts who note that it is similar to the massive eruption at Yellowstone supervolcano.

Six people, including five men and one woman, have been arrested in connection with suspicion of Syria-related terrorism offences in the UK. The arrests took place in the West Midlands, specifically at Dover, where six individuals were detained at the port. The suspects are believed to be from Birmingham, with four of them aged 20 or older. One woman, identified as a 26-year-old, has also been arrested.

Philadelphia beat New York City FC 2-1 in their first game of the season, thanks to goals from Vincent Nogueira and Zach Pfeffer. David Villa scored a classy goal for New York City, while Sanna Nyassi scored for San Jose Earthquakes. Meanwhile, Houston Dynamo defeated Montreal Impact 3-0, with Ricardo Clark doubling the lead in the 72nd minute. New England drew 0-0 with Columbus, while Real Salt Lake tied Sporting Kansas City 0-0.

A 41-year-old Ghanaian-British pastor, Eric Isaiah Adusah, is being held on suspicion of murdering his pregnant wife, Charmain Adusah, 41, in a hotel room in Ghana. The couple was married just nine months ago, following a whirlwind romance, and had traveled to Ghana together before returning to the UK. Police believe Mr Adusah killed his wife while she was in a bath, and hotel staff found her body face-down in a bath with a white towel wrapped around her. The incident occurred after Mr Adusah allegedly left the hotel without informing his wife or letting anyone know he was going, leading to a frantic search effort.

A former aide to Jeb Bush, Ethan Czahor, has launched an app called 'Clear' that removes tweets that may cause problems with employers due to offensive language or behavior. The app uses IBM's Watson supercomputer to analyze tweets and determine whether they contain potentially problematic content. It assigns a safety score to each tweet, allowing users to decide whether to share or delete it. The app aims to help individuals avoid being targeted by trolls and maintain a professional online presence, particularly for those in high-stress fields like tech and academia.

Justin Rose finished second at the Masters, marking his first second-place finish since missing the cut in his previous five tournaments on the PGA Tour. He hopes to build on this momentum with upcoming big events, including the US Open and other majors. Rose drew inspiration from Rory McIlroy's successful summer of 2014, where he won multiple tournaments before the Masters. Rose also credits his improved form at Augusta National, where he feels more confident than ever. He believes he can sustain his recent success and eventually surpass McIlroy's record for most wins at the Masters.

A college student at a Texas-based country music festival, Chilifest, used Rock Paper Scissors to beat three police officers, leading to her being let off with no ticket. The incident occurred during the festival, where she was caught drinking underage. The officers challenged her to a game, and she emerged victorious, winning with a choice of scissors. The incident was captured on social media and gained widespread attention, with some users expressing surprise and amusement at the leniency of the police.

A 14-year-old schoolgirl named Sally Gordon-Smith went missing near Melbourne after being last seen leaving her school in Keilor East at 3pm on Friday. Police are currently searching for her and are concerned due to her age. The girl was described as Caucasian, 150cm tall, with blue eyes and brown hair, and was wearing blue jeans, black jumper, and black shoes when she disappeared. Police confirmed she was still missing early on Saturday morning.

Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew has denied rumors of a potential transfer to Newcastle, insisting he is happy with his current goalkeeper Julian Speroni and has no interest in signing Tim Krul from the Magpies. Pardew claims there has been "no contact" with Newcastle or Krul since his departure, despite speculation surrounding a possible move. He also expressed disappointment at being linked with Krul, stating he's confident the Dutch goalkeeper will stay at Newcastle. Pardew has ruled out making any major signings this summer, instead focusing on building on the current squad.

British photographer John Daniels uses a studio setup to capture adorable images of puppies posing for the camera. His photography skills involve experimenting with various animal pairings, including kittens and puppies, and using props like comedy items and a hammock. Daniels works with experienced animal handlers to ensure safe and stress-free interactions between the animals. His photographs are sought after by greeting card makers due to their charm and quality.

A 54-year-old woman, Hilary Border, from Nottinghamshire, was sentenced to 16 months in prison after pleading guilty to stealing £20,000 from her 83-year-old mother's care home account. Her mother, who suffers from dementia, had entrusted Border with managing her finances due to her poor health. Despite efforts by care home staff to contact Border about an outstanding debt, she failed to comply and instead used the funds for personal expenses. Border was found to have committed fraud and will now serve 16 months in prison, suspended for two years.

David Suchet, a 68-year-old actor best known for his role as Hercule Poirot, is battling to help his grandson Todd, who has Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, an incurable genetic disease. Todd's condition requires expensive medications that are currently unavailable through the National Health Service (NHS), leading to delays in treatment. Suchet is using social media to raise awareness and funds for the Tuberous Sclerosis Association charity, urging others to use the hashtag #Fight4Treatment to bring attention to the issue. Despite being a devout Christian, Suchet remains hopeful that they will find a way to improve treatment options for his grandson.

Cheteshwar Pujara has been signed by Yorkshire until the end of May after cancelling his contract with Younis Khan. The Indian batsman will join the county from Derbyshire, where he scored 219 championship runs for the Division One champions. Pujara, 27, is expected to make his international debut for England, replacing Younis Khan, who is leaving to play for Pakistan. He will also link up with Yorkshire before returning to Australia to play for Mumbai Indians.

A Belgian Malinois named Layka, who was wounded in combat, has been adopted by US Army Staff Sergeant Julian McDonald, who rescued her from a Taliban compound in Afghanistan. Despite losing her front leg, Layka continues to thrive with McDonald, whom she has formed a strong bond with, and now resides in Ohio with him and his family. McDonald credits Layka's bravery and loyalty for saving his life, and has even received a medal of honor for her actions. Layka has become fast friends with McDonald's son Liam, and McDonald has vowed to continue caring for her.

A recent study questions conventional wisdom on salt consumption, suggesting that the average American's daily salt intake may not pose significant health risks despite warnings from health experts. Current guidelines recommend limiting salt to 2,300 milligrams per day, but some researchers argue that this amount is excessive and unnecessary. The average American consumes around 3,500 milligrams of salt per day, which exceeds the recommended limit. This excessive salt consumption may lead to various health problems, including hypertension and cardiovascular disease. Experts disagree on whether reducing salt intake can lower blood pressure or cause harm.

Several DEA agents participated in alleged sex parties in Colombia from 2001, with some admitting to doing so, according to a report. These parties were funded by Colombian drug cartels, which included sex trafficking victims. Lawmakers grilled DEA Administrator Michele Leonhart about the allegations during a recent hearing. At least 7 DEA agents admitted to participating in sex parties, although their names were not disclosed. The incident has raised concerns about the handling of complaints against law enforcement officials.

A 36-year-old Louisiana sheriff's deputy, Burt Hazeltine, was shot three times while directing traffic near a school zone in Paradis, Louisiana, during a road rage incident sparked by an argument over traffic. Paul Devillier, a 56-year-old Transportation Safety Administration worker, allegedly opened fire on Hazeltine, who was directing school buses on US 90 near Louisiana Street. Hazeltine was shot in the face, elbow, and eye, and is believed to be in stable condition at Interim LSU Hospital. Devillier was taken into custody after a brief "tussle" with Hazeltine, who returned fire, and is suspected to have lost his sight due to one bullet penetrating his lung.

A member of the House of Lords, Lord Janner, has signed a letter claiming he is still fit to serve despite being deemed unfit to face child sex charges due to Alzheimer's disease. The letter was allegedly signed by the peer, who has been accused of abusing thousands of boys at care homes, and is part of a case where he faces prosecution for 22 alleged sexual offenses dating back to 1969. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) has defended its decision, citing the need to protect the peer from testifying in court, but critics argue that this undermines justice and allows a convicted individual to remain in office. The controversy has sparked outrage among child abuse campaigners and politicians, with some questioning the legitimacy of the ruling.

Turkish authorities have blocked access to Twitter and YouTube due to a request from a prosecutor held during an armed siege last week, citing the images of the hostage were being shared on social media and causing "deeply upset" the wife and children of the deceased prosecutor. Mehmet Selim Kiraz, a 46-year-old Turkish prosecutor, was killed in a standoff with the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C), a far-left organization, while taking a judge and others hostage. The images of the siege and Kiraz's death were shared on social media, prompting a court to impose blocks on Twitter and YouTube. The blocks come amid growing tensions between Turkey and the DHKP-C, which is considered a terrorist group by Turkey, the EU, and the US.

David and Victoria Beckham, a wealthy couple, have won a planning battle against their neighbor over proposals to install air conditioning at their new $31.5 million West London mansion. The couple wants to install air conditioning in five rooms, including a luxury gym and wine cellar, but neighbors were concerned about the potential impact on the historic character of the property. However, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council has approved the plans subject to minor conditions, citing that the air conditioning would not significantly alter the property's historical significance or cause significant disturbance. The couple's plan to restore their previous home in Hertfordshire, known as Beckingham Palace, before installing air conditioning, may increase its value by up to £42 million.

California Governor Jerry Brown ordered a 25% overall cutback in water use across the state due to ongoing drought, affecting nearly 40 million residents. This includes cities and towns, as well as golf courses and residential areas, with some exemptions for agriculture. The cutback aims to conserve water, but critics argue it may not be effective given the state's reliance on agriculture, which accounts for 80% of water consumption. The move follows a previous effort to reduce water use, but was met with mixed results.

Furious 7, directed by James Wan, is set to open in theaters nationwide on Friday, April 3rd, marking the first time a film has opened on this day since 2008. The movie, starring Vin Diesel, Michelle Rodriguez, and Tyrese Gibson, follows Dominic Toretto as he seeks revenge against Deckard Shaw, played by Jason Statham, after his brother's death. With a domestic opening of $115 million or more, Furious 7 is expected to break the previous record held by Captain America: The Winter Soldier, which debuted to $95 million. This marks the largest three-day opening since The Hunger Games: Catching Fire, and the largest opening of 2015 to date.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas struggled in his second half of the season after a strong start, captainting Spain in a 2-0 loss to Holland. His form has dipped significantly, with only 4/10 received by one Spanish newspaper, despite being expected to lead the Barclays Premier League title chase. Fabregas' recent performances have raised concerns about his durability, particularly considering the pressure of the final stretch of the season. With Chelsea needing multiple wins from their remaining games, Fabregas' consistency is crucial to their title hopes. Manager Jose Mourinho is hoping for a late-season resurgence from the midfielder.

A group of 750 individuals, including Marta Orellana and Marta Ruiz, are suing Johns Hopkins University for $1 billion over a medical experiment where the US government deliberately infected them with syphilis in Guatemala from 1945 to 1956. The experiment involved injecting the disease into unwitting participants, including children, soldiers, and mentally ill individuals, resulting in severe physical and emotional harm. The victims claim that the government approved and monitored the study, despite knowing about the risks. The lawsuit alleges that the US government knowingly infected hundreds of people with syphilis, causing long-term damage to their health and well-being.

Nelly, a 40-year-old hip-hop artist, was arrested in Tennessee on drug charges after a state trooper stopped his private bus carrying him and others on Interstate 40. The bus was found to have marijuana, methamphetamine, and other drug paraphernalia, and multiple handguns were discovered. Nelly was charged with felony possession of drugs, simple possession of marijuana, and possession of drug paraphernalia. A state trooper noticed the odor of marijuana emitting from the bus and conducted a search, leading to the discovery of additional evidence. Nelly was released on bail and later posted bond before being taken into custody.

A Japanese woman gave her cheating boyfriend an unexpected surprise by dumping his expensive Apple collection in a bathtub after taking a single soaking. The woman scorned took great pleasure in ruining his prized possessions, including his iMac, iPhone, iPad, and accessories. Despite the potential damage, many people online praised the woman's "best revenge" for teaching her cheating boyfriend a lesson. Others commended her for showing strength and resilience in the face of betrayal.

Bayern Munich won 1-0 against Borussia Dortmund, with Robert Lewandowski scoring the winning goal. Jurgen Klopp's Bayern Munich deserved to win due to their superior quality, while Dortmund's captain Mats Hummels felt they should have been awarded more chances. Lewandowski's goal was the highlight of the match, which saw Bayern dominate possession and create few chances. Dortmund's defense was solid, but ultimately unable to stem the tide. Dortmund captain Mats Hummels disagreed with his manager, saying they created enough chances to win.

President Barack Obama visited Jamaica on Thursday, becoming the first American president to do so since President Ronald Reagan in 1982. He met with Jamaican Prime Minister Portia Simpson Miller and expressed his love for the country, saying "you're well-loved" in return. Obama also met with Cuban President Raul Castro, who attended a dinner with him on Friday, marking the first time the two leaders have met since the thawing of relations in December. Meanwhile, US Secretary of State John Kerry met with Cuban Foreign Minister Bruno Rodriguez, discussing ways to improve relations after the US removed Cuba from its list of state sponsors of terrorism.

Pope Francis delivered a powerful message during his "urbi et orbi" address, reminding the world of the importance of ending violence and promoting peace. He specifically addressed the conflicts in Iraq, Syria, Libya, and Yemen, calling for an end to bloodshed and urging humanitarian aid to those affected. The Pope also expressed hope for a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and for peace in other regions such as Ukraine and Nigeria. In a call to action, he asked for peace from individuals involved in oppressive systems, including drug dealers, corrupt officials, and arms dealers. Ultimately, Pope Francis concluded the address by wishing everyone a happy Easter.

In a steamy new campaign for Linda Farrow eyewear, model Irina Shayk poses in a series of sultry photoshoots, showcasing the brand's Spring Summer 15 collection. The campaign features Irina getting close to model Jarrod Scott, who joins her in a series of intimate moments, including a romantic poolside scene where they share a kiss. The collection includes a range of retro-inspired sunglasses, including a gold-plated pair that showcases Irina's stunning figure. Irina's style is updated with plunging metallic swimsuits and oversized aviator sunglasses, making her look incredibly glamorous.

Polish Prince Janek Zylinski has challenged Nigel Farage, the leader of Ukip, to a sword fight over his criticism of immigration. Zylinski, a descendant of a Polish war hero who fought against Nazi forces in 1939, claims he "had enough" of Farage's comments about immigrants. Zylinski posted a challenge online, saying they should meet in Hyde Park with swords to settle their differences. Farage responded by defending himself, stating that he would rather engage in a duel with Zylinski than accept the challenge.
people who live here who are scared and anxious about the situation.'

Barcelona defender Dani Alves has been offered a two-year deal by Manchester United, despite being out of contract at the end of the current campaign. Alves' camp says the offer is a "one-year deal" with an option for a second year, while his agent claims it's a "three-year deal". The offer includes incentives, such as increased earnings if Alves wins trophies or performs well in the second year. However, Alves' camp insists that a three-year deal is unlikely, citing the club's inability to find a suitable replacement for him. Despite this, Alves is reportedly hopeful that Barcelona will make him an improved offer, allowing him to stay at the Nou Camp.

Kate Temple, a 33-year-old hairdresser, was jailed for 20 months after admitting to inflicting grievous bodily harm on victim Shelley Williams, who had her ear bitten off during a dispute at a charity event. Williams, who had previously accused Temple of having an affair with her partner, claimed that Temple had attacked her while trying to buy another drink from a bar. Temple denied any wrongdoing, but was ultimately convicted and sentenced to prison after refusing to cooperate with police and admitting to the crime. The judge described the incident as a "significant injury" and noted that Temple had shown "limited remorse", despite the severity of the punishment.

Jenson Button believes McLaren is making progress in the new season, having improved significantly since their poor start in Australia. In contrast, McLaren's rival teams, such as Red Bull and Sauber, are struggling to keep up. Button hopes that McLaren's improvements will continue, particularly in terms of speed and performance. He also notes that the cooler weather in Shanghai may hinder progress, but still offers some hope for the team. Button is optimistic about his own chances of finishing the race strongly, despite recent retirements.

Claudia Martins, a 33-year-old woman from Portugal, was convicted of murdering her newborn baby girl by suffocating her with toilet paper and hiding the body in a suitcase. The baby was born alive, but died shortly after due to severe injuries inflicted upon her. Martins claimed she did not kill the baby, stating she did not put anything in her mouth. However, a post-mortem examination revealed a wad of toilet paper inside the baby's mouth, suggesting otherwise. Martins was acquitted of murder but convicted of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility due to her low IQ.

AP McCoy, riding Paul Nicholls' mount Mr Mole, will compete in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The event marks a significant milestone for McCoy, who announced his retirement from riding earlier this year. Mr Mole, trained by Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the field alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. This will be McCoy's last ride before he retires from professional jockeying.

A woman in her 20s was rescued from the River Cam in Cambridge after falling from a punt and struggling to stay afloat. She was found by two friends who leapt in to save her and were able to pull her to safety. The incident occurred after the punt hit another boat, causing the woman to fall underwater several times. Temperatures in the area reached 21C, making it an unusually warm Easter weekend.

West Indies' Marlon Samuels has shown remarkable dedication and perseverance in taking on the demands of Test cricket, particularly in the second Test against England, where he reached a century despite facing a tough opponent. As new West Indies coach Phil Simmons aims to create a culture of discipline and character among his players, Samuels' example will likely inspire others to follow suit. The traditional Test format offers a unique experience that cannot be replicated in shorter formats like Twenty20, where players often face less pressure and fewer consequences for mistakes. Samuels' grueling performance in the second Test demonstrates the rewards of putting in the hard work required to succeed in Test cricket. With a focus on taking Tests into five days, West Indies can build momentum and potentially set themselves up for success in future matches.

A police officer named Michael Slager shot and killed a 50-year-old man named Walter Scott while responding to a call about a broken brake light. Slager fired multiple shots at Scott, who was handcuffed and lying on the ground, and then used a Taser on him without administering medical aid. An internal investigation found that Slager's fellow officers, including one who searched Scott's body, failed to provide adequate care, and that the police department's own incident report contradicted the bystander video showing Slager using the Taser. The incident sparked widespread outrage and calls for greater accountability within the police department.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model, denied reports that she tried to take her own life after collapsing in a luxury apartment in Milan. Italian media reported that she attempted suicide but was later hospitalized and treated. Moric shared photographs of her injuries on Instagram, stating she was recovering at home after being treated in the hospital. Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, suggested that Moric had tried to kill herself, but she disputed this claim.

Juventus secured a 0-0 draw against Monaco in their Champions League quarter-final match, thanks in part to a gritty performance from Patrice Evra. The French defender prevented Yannick Ferreira Carrasco from scoring, while also urging Monaco's Geoffrey Kondogbia to adopt a more combative approach. Paul Pogba missed the match due to injury, which means Juventus will face Barcelona in the semi-finals. Evra praised Monaco's performance, saying they "deserved more" despite losing, while also acknowledging that Juventus' style of play can be effective. The Italian side will now move on to the semi-finals, where they will face Barcelona.

A gorilla at Omaha's Henry Doorley Zoo threw a pane of glass at a child during a family outing, causing significant damage. The incident occurred when the gorilla became frustrated and ran at the glass, followed by its companion, resulting in the glass cracking. The child fled in terror, while the zookeepers tried to intervene but ultimately retreated from the scene. The gorilla then smashed into the glass once more, causing further damage.

John Suchet, a British actor, lost his wife Bonnie in April 2015 after a decade-long battle with dementia. She died peacefully at the age of 73, leaving behind a loving family and a legacy through his charitable work with Dementia UK. As a devoted husband and father, Suchet cared for Bonnie for three years before passing away, sharing his experiences and emotions with the public. His openness about his struggles with dementia has raised awareness and support for those affected by the disease.

Ben and Shelby Offrink, a couple from Caledonia, Michigan, met in college and got married after Ben cheated on her study group to spend time with her. Eight years later, Shelby was diagnosed with a rare type of brain cancer called an intramedullary glioblastoma, which caused her to lose mobility and eventually paralysis. Despite facing numerous challenges, including a second diagnosis of multiple tumors, Shelby remains determined to fight for her health and the lives of her two young daughters. Her husband Ben continues to support her efforts, and their community has rallied around them, providing emotional support and financial assistance. With only six months left before Shelby's expected passing, Ben urges others to seek clinical trials and access to advanced treatments to help those fighting similar cancers.

Real Madrid coach Carlo Ancelotti faces a difficult decision when selecting his starting lineup due to the availability of several key players, including James Rodriguez, who has been injured since November. The team's attack is bolstered by Gareth Bale, Karim Benzema, and Cristiano Ronaldo, but Ancelotti must decide whether to include either Rodriguez or Isco in the starting lineup. Meanwhile, Paris Saint-Germain beat Marseille 3-2 in their match, which could boost Ligue 1's competitiveness. Real Madrid's attacking trio of Isco, Toni Kroos, and Luka Modric remain available, but Ancelotti may need to make a tough choice.

Manny Pacquiao and Floyd Mayweather will face off in a highly anticipated boxing match at the MGM Grand on May 2. The two fighters have been preparing for their bout, with Pacquiao seeking to dethrone Mayweather as the world's top boxer. Meanwhile, Floyd Mayweather has taken time out of his training sessions to meet with Motown legend Gladys Knight, who posted a picture with him on social media. The fight is expected to be one of the biggest events in boxing history, with a reported £120 million prize purse. Mayweather is set to take place on Saturday, May 2.

Ed Miliband has hired a leadership coaching firm called ExtendedMind to help him improve his public speaking skills and build "leadership" abilities through neuroscience and business psychology techniques. The firm claims to use these methods to enhance communication styles and persuade audiences. The firm's services include helping politicians learn to convey their messages authentically and build alliances. The firm's approach emphasizes the importance of practicing new behavior to become more effective, but critics argue that this approach may lead to insincerity.

A 32-year-old dispatcher for US Limousine, Geralyn Ganci, sued her former employer Raymond Townsend, the manager of a limousine company, for sexual harassment and refusing to engage in consensual sex. Ganci alleged that Townsend made explicit and unwanted advances, including sending her explicit texts and asking her to meet him outside of work for personal reasons. After being fired, Ganci received a settlement of over $700,000 from the company, but later sued Townsend and the company for $1 million in damages. A jury ultimately found Townsend liable for creating a hostile work environment and emotional distress, but he was not held personally responsible due to lack of intent.

Thiago made his return to action for Bayern Munich in a 1-0 win over Borussia Dortmund, playing for only 10 minutes due to fatigue. He praised the support of his teammates and fans, saying "football is my life" and admitting he was "crazy" to be back on the pitch. Thiago had come on as a substitute in the 1-0 victory, scoring no goals himself, but contributing to the win. This marked his first appearance in over a year since suffering a serious knee injury in March 2014. Bayern Munich coach Pep Guardiola expressed his gratitude to the players and staff for their support during this time.

David Cameron, the former UK Prime Minister, accused the BBC of peddling misinformation when he claimed his favorite sport was foxhunting. During an appearance on the Andrew Marr Show, he denied saying foxhunting was his favorite sport, despite earlier admitting to making a mistake on social media. The BBC presenter Andrew Marr had previously stated that Cameron's favorite sport was foxhunting, prompting Cameron to climb onto a wooden pallet to address the audience. Cameron's comments were met with criticism, with one heckler accusing the NHS of dying due to his stance on foxhunting.

Gwyneth Paltrow, actress and lifestyle guru, has participated in the #FoodBankNYCChallenge, where she spent $29 on a week's worth of groceries for a person living on food stamps. This is part of a campaign by celebrity chef Mario Batali to raise awareness about the challenges faced by those on food stamps. The program aims to show people what it's like to live on a limited food budget, with the goal of increasing public awareness of the issue. The challenge was prompted by recent cuts to food stamps, which have affected many families struggling to afford basic necessities.

Manchester United's Megastore, featuring mascot Fred the Red, is facing uncertainty due to a potential expiration of its world-record £750m kit deal with Nike. Staff, including Fred himself, are concerned about their future employment status, citing low wages and lack of job security. The club's official mascot, Fred, has been with the team since 1994 and is among those sweating over the situation. As the Megastore nears closure, some staff claim they are being used as scapegoats by Nike, while others fear losing their jobs if the deal ends.

Liverpool edged past Blackburn Rovers 1-0 in their FA Cup sixth-round replay at Ewood Park, thanks to a clever goal from Philippe Coutinho. The Brazilian midfielder broke the deadlock after 161 minutes, scoring in a 24-minute period where Blackburn struggled to create clear-cut chances. Daniel Sturridge was quiet throughout, while Raheem Sterling was kept under control by goalkeeper Simon Eastwood. Despite a lackluster display from Blackburn, Liverpool ultimately won the game through Coutinho's winning goal, which sealed their 24th FA Cup semi-final spot.

A heartwarming video shows six blindfolded children trying to identify their mothers by touch and scent, with the goal of understanding the special bond between mother and child. The video, called "The Unique Connection," features six children being guided by their mothers who are standing in a row, allowing each child to take turns touching their hand, hair, and face before locating their mother. The video aims to celebrate Mother's Day and the unique connection between mothers and their children. The video has gained significant attention online, with over 2.8 million views and praise from celebrities like Ashton Kutcher.

Ian Watson, a 38-year-old Salford assistant coach, is set to return to the club as a player-coach after stepping up his training ahead of their upcoming match against Castleford. This move comes after the team suffered a series of injuries, including suspensions and injuries to several key players. Watson played 41 Super League games for Salford between 1997 and 2002 before retiring as a player. He will now take over as a player-coach, becoming the oldest player in Super League history to do so. With Salford facing a depleted squad due to injuries, Watson's arrival could provide a boost to the team's chances.

Jordan Spieth sank a remarkable six birdies in his first round at the 79th Masters, taking the lead with a score of 64. Younger competitors like Justin Rose and Ernie Els, both 34 and 45 respectively, also performed impressively, tying for second place with Charley Hoffman. Spieth's incredible run included a birdie on the 18th, where he successfully sunk a 25-foot putt to take the lead. Rory McIlroy appeared relaxed throughout the day, while defending champion Bubba Watson struggled to find his form.

England's captain Alastair Cook must focus on the upcoming Test series against the West Indies, despite distractions from recent events such as the departure of Paul Downton and the emergence of Kevin Pietersen. Cook has worked with Pietersen in the past and hopes to keep his future in the team intact. The series is considered a vital one for Cook, who is desperate to avoid being distracted by the changes in the team. With a strong squad and a relatively unchanged lineup, England is expected to face a challenging test of their skills against the West Indies. The series is seen as a key moment in Cook's career, and he must perform well to maintain his position as captain.

A total of nearly 400 US sailors and Marines were killed when the USS Oklahoma sank in the bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941. The ship was hit by nine torpedoes and capsized, trapping many inside, resulting in the deaths of 429 people. The Pentagon plans to exhume the bodies of some 400 sailors and Marines who were killed, with the goal of identifying at least 60% of the group using DNA samples, medical records, and other evidence. The process will involve returning the remains to families, with the goal of providing closure to those affected.

A YouTube video featuring Yousef Saleh Erakat, a comedian and entertainer, shows him disguising himself as a homeless man and attempting to test whether offering money to those on the street is more effective than receiving it. In the video, Erakat attempts to flip the script by offering money to various individuals, with mixed reactions ranging from anger to disgust. Two people, one man and a woman, respond positively to Erakat's offers, while others reject him. The video ends with Erakat reflecting on the results and writing in his YouTube description that the true value of kindness lies in humility rather than material wealth.

A 18-year-old college student, Anjelica Hadsell, disappeared while on spring break in Norfolk, Virginia, leaving her family and police searching for her. Her stepfather, Wesley Hadsell, was arrested and charged with obstruction of justice and possession of ammunition after allegedly breaking into a home where she was last seen. His arrest sparked renewed hope for her safe return, but police continue to investigate, focusing on finding her cell phone, which was found near a pond in the Norfolk area. The investigation is ongoing, and police are still unsure how they were led to the pond, despite receiving tips and conducting searches.

A team of Australian researchers has developed a drone called Joggobot that can fly alongside joggers, tracking their speed and direction. The drone was tested with 13 participants who ran for an average of 26 minutes, and most reported feeling motivated and supported by the drone. The drone uses a camera to track the jogger's movement and can lock onto patterns on the wearer's clothing to monitor speed and direction. Researchers believe the technology could be used for various sports, including cycling, rowing, and even jogging, and aim to inspire designs that support exercise activities.

A New Zealander named Matthew Bird quit his well-paying job as an agricultural adviser to become a mechanic due to a $600-a-month increase in child support payments, which reduced his monthly payment from $1,900 to $554. This change affects over 700 families across the country. The Child Support Reform Act 2014 introduced a new calculation method, resulting in a significant reduction in payments for many families. Many individuals, like Matthew Bird, are now facing financial difficulties as a result of this change.

A British man, Navinder Singh Sarao, has been accused of causing the 2010 "flash crash" by making illicit trades back in 2009, despite being suspected by US authorities since then. Sarao allegedly used special computer software to manipulate the market on Wall Street, triggering a $850 billion price drop in the US stock market between May 6 and 11, 2010. The US authorities suspect that Sarao made around £26 million from these trades, which spanned five years, and were investigated by multiple agencies, including the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC). Sarao was finally charged alongside criminal charges by the Department of Justice in September 2023, after a lengthy investigation that began in 2009.

Lisa Webb, a Canadian expat mom, initially worried that her three-year-old daughter would starve due to the unfamiliar French meal options. However, after spending a week observing her daughter eating at a French state school, she discovered that the meals were actually quite varied and included many familiar foods like pasta, meat, and fruit. Despite initial reservations, Lisa found that the French approach to mealtime emphasizes sharing and trying new things, rather than forcing children to eat something they dislike. Her experience led her to appreciate the French approach to nutrition and education, which prioritizes socialization and exploration over strict adherence to traditional mealtime routines.

A survey found that 64% of adults who shop with friends tend to spend more money than they would if they shopped alone, citing factors such as showing off and succumbing to peer pressure. Many participants reported feeling pressured into buying things they didn't want due to social expectations, but still ended up overspending. Despite knowing they should stick to their budgets, 85% of respondents admitted to overspending on various items like food, clothing, and entertainment. The results suggest that prioritizing financial responsibility can help individuals make better purchasing decisions.

Phillip Schofield was left speechless after Ellie Grant, 22, blurted out "silver fox" during an interview on ITV's This Morning. The 22-year-old guest with Tourette's syndrome, who is deaf, was discussing how she met her fiancé Jordan, a deaf man, and how they met through mutual friends. The incident occurred during a pre-recorded interview, and viewers praised the couple's relationship despite the awkward moment. The couple has been open about their experiences with Tourette's and Tourette's syndrome, and have spoken positively about finding love with each other despite their differences.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old US citizen and al Qaeda operative, was killed in a US government counterterrorism operation in January. He was one of the organization's top leaders, known for his anti-American rhetoric and calls for violence against the US and its allies. Gadahn was killed while fighting alongside other al Qaeda operatives in Pakistan three years after leaving the US. His body was discovered in a cave in Syria, where he had been hiding with other fighters.

Jenson Button, a Formula One driver, completed the London Marathon in 2 hours, 52 minutes, 30 seconds, beating his personal best time. He ran on behalf of Cancer Research and expressed his delight at the "amazing atmosphere" and collective spirit of the runners. Button was particularly proud to be part of the event, which featured over 36,000 participants. Despite finishing behind fellow athlete James Cracknell, who also participated in the marathon, Button felt grateful for the opportunity to participate. His achievement was seen as a testament to the dedication and camaraderie among the runners.
